That thing is one of the worst connectors ever made - this is the flat skinny connector found on Kindles and other thin computer hardware. It is easy to get that connector upside down and force it into the socket - I hate the keying. I much more prefer the standard mini USB connector, about the same width, but fatter and a more obvious key with the two wider flanges at the top. The mini USB connector is found on a lot more equipment, portable hard drives, phones, and digital cameras.Yubi adds an LED flashlight that is surprisingly bright. That is a bonus. There are a set of blue LED's to indicate charging, power on, and charge level. I normally love blue lights, I am drawn to just about anything with a blue light. These are somewhat annoying. There is an LED pilot light to show that the battery has a charge. Oddly this is one of the brightest monitor LED's I've ever seen. In a dark room sitting on a table, the light casts a blue light on the ceiling. There is no way to turn off this light. When the battery is being used, more blue LED's light up indicating the charge level. Three is fully charged. These give off even more light at night. In normal daylight they are easy to see.There is one more package in the box, the adapters. The main piece is an eight inch wire with a flat USB connector on one end, and a mini female jack on the other end. There are four different adapters that can be plugged into that socket, a 30 pin iPhone, a micro USB, a mini USB, and what looks like a Nokia or cell phone jack. I'm just not a fan of this arrangement. It is too darn easy to loose these little plugs.Overall, this is a nice battery. It is a nice size and weight. Not necessarily something I'd carry around in my pocket, but could in a pinch. For cell phone power, it is a good choice, and can be pressed into iPad service in a pinch.I was provided a review sample.
summary: Good For Cell Phones

reviewText: This Yubi external battery is a well-made source of power for a variety of devices that use USB cables to charge, although its capacity makes it best for cell phones and cameras.  For an iPad or similar device, which take a lot more power, you'd be better off with an 8400mAh capacity battery.  When my iPhone 5 registered 6% or 8% battery life remaining, I was able to charge the phone three times without recharging the Yubi.  Yubi claims at least 88% efficiency with the battery, delivering at least 4576 mAh with loss, and given my experience, that figure seems to be accurate.  Other brands have a much higher attrition rate, thus giving you less power for the same size external battery.  Anker, for example, has a 30% power attrition rate on a similarly sized battery.The battery comes with a short (6") USB cable and adapters (micro-USB, mini-USB, PSP, and standard Apple.)  If you have a different, proprietary connection, such as the lightning connection for iPhone 5 or one for a camera, then you can use those USB cables in place of the supplied ones.  The battery does not come with a wall charger.  While you can technically use your own wall plug, the included USB cable is ridiculously short, and the battery will dangle off the floor.  You're better off using your own cable for that, too, even though that defeats the purpose of having a variety of adapters.The finish is a glossy black, and even though it is a fingerprint magnet, it looks and feels sleek.  The dimensions are small, hand- but not pocket-sized:  4" L x 1 5/8" W x 1" D.  It has an LED flashlight built in for emergencies.  Note:  The manufacturer provided this product for review.-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann
summary: Great Choice for Portable Power (5- stars)

reviewText: When I received this Yubi Power Bank it wasn't completely charged, but the LED lights were showing up.  I simply used the provided USB cable, plugged it into the Micro USB Input on the charger, and then plugged it into my PC for an overnight charge.  By morning it was fully charged and ready to go.  I've had one portable battery before and do have theYubi 8400 mAh High Capacity Portable Battery.  If you really need some power you might want to consider this Power Bank as it's a real power horse that I'm using with my biggest power hog, the iPad.  It will also charge a couple of devices simultaneously.The 5200 mAh Yubi is no slouch in the power department, but I'm using it primarily for items that don't draw or demand massive amounts of power.  Think Smartphones, Kindles, your GPS, or iPhone.  This Yubi is perfect to leave at work or take with you when you are heading to the library, a bookstore, or anywhere else where you'll need it and don't have access to a plug.  Those critters are out there, but I never manage to be the first one on the scene and once someone is using a plug in a Wi-Fi accessible area, they're reluctant to give them up.Portable devices aren't any good if you can't charge them up and this Yubi is perfect.  It's not only portable, but quite compact.  The LED flashlight is a total bonus, especially if you need a bit of light when you're heading to your car or trying to spot something when the lights go out.  Little touches such as this one are always appreciated.  I do like the accessories, but generally use the ones provided with any particular device I'm using.  The Yubi is high-performance and charged up my Kindle and Kindle Fire as quickly and readily as if I'd plugged it into an outlet in my house.  Good to go on-the-go is an important factor to a lot of us.Needless to say, I've been impressed and pleased with both of my Yubi Power Banks.  If you do need more than 5200 mA, simply check out the very compact and equally affordableYubi 8400 mAh High Capacity Portable Battery.  This Yubi purportedly has life cycle of more than 500 charges.  Durability and long-lasting items are a big plus in my department.  A friend carries a Power Bank to work to keep his phone fully charged.  The Yubi is one of those devices that is powerful, but can fit in the palm of one's hand, can be slipped into a pocket or purse, or into a carrying case.  Absolutely no complaints about either one of the Yubi Power Banks I own.  The Yubi 5200 Mah is an awesome little battery I'll get a lot of use out of.WHAT'S IN THE BOX:~  Yubi power bank (yp520A)~  USB cable - 8.5" (21.5cm)~  PSP~  Micro USB~  Mini USB~  iPhone /iPad USBSPECIFICATIONS:~  USB Input:  DC 5V 1A~  USB Output:  DC 5V 2.1A Max~  Charging Time:  Around 5-6 hours (via1A adaptor)~  Battery Capacity:  5200 mAh~  Dimensions:  3.94" x 1.65" x 0.9055" (100 x 42 x 23mm)~  Weight: 0.3042 lb. (138g)FEATURES:~  High-tech battery cells with protection board~ Smart power management controller, the power conversion efficiency is more than 88%~  Double protection:  Battery pack with protection board, charging system with over charge, over voltage, over current and short circuit protection~  Intelligent display of LED to indicate the charging status and power levels~  High bright LED for lighting~  Ideal for most digital devices with Dc5V input, such as iPhone, iPad, Smartphone, PSP, Mp3, GPS, Amazon Kindle and Google Nexus 7.The Yubi courtesy of the distributor with no expectation of a positive review.
summary: This Yubi Power Bank is perfect for devices that don't draw a lot of power, but need a quick charge ...

reviewText: I have had this charger for a few days and have used it on an overnight car trip to keep both my Kindle and iPhone charged. It is a handy size that fits into my purse.  I found the small light handy when I forgot to leave the porch light on and came home after dark. With it I walked to the door safely and could get the key in the lock easily.  I have ordered a new tablet and have the adapter to charge it when it comes.This device came with several adapters to charge various electronic tablets and at least the iPhone. It is self-contained and easy to plug in to charge from the wall. The instruction show, a wall plug-in devise but it is not included; I had one of the wall units that came with either my Kindle of iPhone. I found that my Kindle cord to charge the Kindle would also work to charge this charger. I am impressed at how easy it was to read the two-page direction sheet and have it working after the first charge, which took about eight hours.This was given to me as a gift and I did not purchase it on Amazon. This review reflects my initial use of the product and I am pleased that it performs as the description indicates.
summary: Small Yubi Power External Battery Charger

reviewText: The 5-6-hour battery life typical of many cellphones is barely enough for heavy telephone usage, much less the texting, emails, location services, and apps that drain batteries. Since it's not always possible to be near an AC charger or car charger, an external battery pack is a necessity for many people nowadays. (The recent storms that knocked out electrical power to millions of people is further proof of the need for external battery packs.) In my opinion, there are four key issues to take into account when buying an external battery pack:1. Form factor. I'm including both size and weight. You'll most likely be carrying the charger in your pocket, purse, travel bag, or glove compartment of your vehicle. Smaller and lighter are better.2. Capacity. Rechargers come in a range of capacities from about 2,500 mAh to as high as 12,000 mAh. Figure that 2,300-2,700 mAh is about the equivalent power of a typical rechargeable AA NiMH battery, and that may give you some idea of a battery pack's capacity. Mobile devices will vary a lot in how much capacity it takes to recharge their internal batteries, with the larger tablets requiring considerably more power than a smaller cellphone.3. Reliability. As with any other product, go with brand names you're familiar with, or ones with reviews that you trust.4. Value. Battery packs with higher capacities will generally cost more than ones with smaller capacities. Figure on some tradeoff between size/weight, capacity, and price that fits your budget and gives the capacity you need.---------------------------------------Yubi Power sent me one of their YP520A 5200mAh External Battery Pack units to review. The device appears to be well made, and it was very compact (3.9" x 1.6" x 0.8"). Adapter plugs are included for Apple devices and other devices that have Micro-USB and Mini-USB ports, which include the majority of mobile devices sold today. The output is 5 volts @ 2.1 amps. There's also a flashlight built into the charger.The battery pack can be recharged with an AC wall charger or car charger that provides greater than 500mA. I gave it a full charge in about five hours using a Kindle AC charger (5 volts @ 0.85 amps). Alternatively, the unit can be recharged from the USB port of a PC. Although the battery pack does not include a charger, most users will already have AC wall chargers or car chargers that will work.I tested the Yubi Power battery pack on my Samsung smartphone and my Kindle Fire HD tablet. I was most interested to see how long it required to increase their charge from about 90% to a full 100% charge. With the Kindle Fire HD, it required about 45 minutes; with the smartphone a bit less than a half hour. I also tried recharging my e-Ink Kindle reader, and it recharged it, too.Overall, I'm impressed with the Yubi Power external battery pack. It appears to be well made, it's compact, and it works very well with all of our mobile devices. Considering the size and weight, the 5200 mAh capacity, and the price, it's a very good value.
summary: A very compact but effective battery pack

reviewerName: Jeri Zerr "formerly a Road Warrior of the Nth...
reviewText: The Yubi 520 has been reliably helping me to keep my smart phones, tablets, Kindle Fire and numerous devices powered - no more lost communications due to dead cell phones!However, the real beauty came during a recent extended power outage.  We needed a light in our stairs.  I grabbed theSatechi Touch USB LED Lamp, plugged her into into this battery pack and had light for the duration of the power outage.I highly recommend the Yubi 5200 mAh battery charger.  You can never have too much backup battery charger capability when the power goes down or when you just don't have time to have your device tethered to an outlet.  I received this charger for reviewing purposes, we have put it to the test where so far it has held up flawlessly.  It has been working reliably for over a month and keeps on charging along. If anything changes I will be updating this review.
summary: Is reliable to recharge USB devices as well as power an LED USB lamp during a power outage

reviewText: I travel often for both business and work, and one of the hardest things about traveling is keeping powered on the go.  I have bought and own several power banks sold here on Amazon and some I have picked up in brick and mortar stores and by far, I really like the Yubi Power YP520A power bank the most.What makes it so great:+Lightweight- unit weighs less than 5 oz (138g), great for tossing in a ladies purse, keeping in your day bag or even in a digital camera bag+Sleek operation- unit is very responsive with two taps of the button to turn the light on, and two taps to turn the light off, a press to turn the unit on for charging and a press to turn it off when finished+An LED [Flash]Light- Work, play, or travel, there are so great uses for a flashlight, weather on a dark plane, in a dark car, or inspecting your hotel room for cleanliness, this is a great addition for such a small sized unit+Recharges with a Micro-USB cable-  No longer will I need to carry a specialty cable/charger to recharge my powerbank, I can use the same cable I use for my Nexus 7 or Kindle Fire HD to recharge this unitBeing an on the go person, I like to have options when recharging my phone and digital camera; this is perfect for that purpose.  Even for use with a Kindle Fire or Nexus 7, this unit can get close to, if not a full charge for these devices.What you must consider when looking to buy a power bank is the mAh the unit can hold, essentially, how much of a charge the power bank can hold total and provide to devices being charged.  This unit has a 5,200 mAh capacity.  Other reviewers have produced great reviews into what devices have what mAh battery.  When considering this unit, if getting a full charge for your device is important, think of this power bank as great for use with cellphones, and most Android tablets.  This unit will add hours of life to your iPad, but it does not have the capacity for a full charge.  There are higher mAh capacity power banks produced by this manufacture but you have to remember for higher mAh capacity, you are also adding weight and size to the power bank unit.Overall, this unit is perfect for the applicable uses.  This is not just a burst of power, but provides full charges and adds hours of life to your devices when getting to an outlet is just not feasible.  The unit is priced right and lives up to my expectations.Disclosure: I received a sample product from the manufacturer for the purposes of providing this review. A review in exchange for the review sample was not promised. The views and opinions expressed in this review are my own, and in no way represent the views or opinions of the manufacturer or vendor.
summary: Great All Around Power Bank...

reviewText: This is a power unit that holds a lot of juice for many portable devices.It comes with the unit, a USB cord with an open plug, and a series of plugs to connect to your device - iPod/iPad, micro USB, mini USB and 2mm round. This unit charged fully in about 6-7 hours using the provided USB cable into my USB wall charger. You have the option of charging it with your computer as well. I also really like the built-in flashlight which, in a very dark house, carried over 30 feet to dimly illuminate an area and close up did a great job.It has one USB port and one input micro USB port to flip your cable for charging the unit. There is an easy power button with three light indicator for remaining power on the unit. Three lights indicate more than 80% power remains, two lights mean 30-80% and one light means less than 30% power remains. I wish there were actually four light indicators but three will do.The unit has a solid feel is small and compact in your hand and will fit easily into a briefcase or pocketbook. I used it to charge a Droid Incredible 4G and my Kindle Fire. I was impressed with how quickly it charged these devices (that were not completely drained) and still had power left.If you've ever run out somewhere and forgot to fully charge a device, you know how convenient it is to have something like this in your briefcase or pocketbook. If you have ever been caught in a power outage, you know how frustrating it is to get to a power source to charge what is probably your only form of communication for awhile.It would have been nice to have a carry bag or pouch to contain the unit, cable and tips but it's easy enough to find something in my closet.I was provided a unit for testing and evaluation.
summary: Easy Portability, Packed with Power, Strong Flashlight

reviewText: After the 2012 hurricane, I'm a big fan of the little power banks with an LED flashlight to keep on hand at home and in the automobile for emergency use.The Yubi Power 5200mAh charger will charge most small electronic devices such as cell phones or MP3 players two, three or sometimes more times or provide a power boost to extend the usability of a larger device like a Kindle, iPad, or other tablet that uses more energy.  It will also power the built-in LED lamp for over a week when fully charged.Several adapters to fit various devices are included or it will accept most USB power cords supplied with devices.  The power bank itself charges through the micro USB to USB cable.  Using a powered USB wall adapter is much faster than using the USB port on a computer.  Yubi uses the efficient Samsung lithium ion batteries like the ones Apple uses.There are three blue LEDs to indicate the amount of power available:  when one is lit power is under 30% of capacity, two means 30% to 80%, and three means over 80% of capacity.  Press the switch once to start charging and remaining capacity and twice to turn the LED flashlight on or off. There is also another blue LED to indicate when it is activitated but I am not sure what purpose this serves as the capacity indicator is lit as well and this LED seems to stay on indefinitely unless you hold the switch down for a few seconds.The quality of manufacture is quite good, with a shiny black finish, stable ports, good quality button, bright LED, etc.  It's compact and fits well in the hand when used as a flashlight.A sample was provided for unbiased review.
summary: Compact power bank with bright LED flash light

reviewerName: Nathan Andersen "Gadget lover and author of S...
reviewText: This is a very handy "pocket" charger, that's always ready to deliver "juice" to a variety of small products such as tablets and smartphones. I've used it with an iPhone, an iPad, and a Kindle Fire. It can charge them up, but you can also run them from this device.What really got me excited, though, is that I can charge and run my Drift HD and Drift Ghost Action Cameras from this device. I often do time lapse photography with those cameras - I'll mount on top of my car and shoot up at the sky for a cloud montage, for example. The problem is that the batteries only last for a few hours. It can power via USB, but I rarely shoot near a plug and I certainly wouldn't leave my computer next to it. With this connected to the USB plug in the back, I can shoot for several hours. The Drift Ghost's battery has a 1700mAh rating, and this delivers over three times that much power. A very handy little device.I was provided with a sample of this product by the manufacturer, with the understanding that I would post an honest review.
summary: A very handy little "pocket" charger - that will charge or power a range of small devices

reviewText: I have to admit, I like most of the power banks I get.  I think I've only used one that was below expectations.  Most come with a variety of connectors, a charging cable, an embedded LED flashlight.  In those respects, the Yubi Power 5200 mAh meets all standards.FORM FACTORPower banks get smaller all the time.  I remember when 5000 mAh was the size of a small wallet, and I thought that was small.  This one is getting close to the size of some 2500 mAh power banks I've owned.  It is small enough to fit in my jean pocket, a good size for a purse.CONNECTORSManufacturers sometimes go crazy over providing every connector imaginable.  Only a few will ever be used.  Yubi Power provides the most common adapters needed:* iPhone 30 pin connector* micro USB* mini USB* PSPA big plus for providing the iPhone connector.  Only about half the power banks come with one.If your device charges via a USB port but doesn't use one of those connectors, you can connect with your own USB cord.CAPACITY5200 mAh is a good capacity for general purposes.  I prefer it over a 2500 mAh power bank, because it will charge an iPhone more than once.  After charging my iPhone twice, it still had one LED indicator light shining (less than 30% charge remaining).If you have an iPad or other large tablet, I would recommend a 10000 mAh power bank or higher; but for many people on the road, this will be fine.POWER INDICATOR LIGHTSThere are three power indicator lights.  I have to look to find the pinpoints of light.  On most other units, power indicator lights are much more visible.  Two pinpoints of light can indicate anywhere from 30% to 80% charge remaining, which is a wide margin.  The majority of power banks use four indicator lights for more precision.OTHER CONSIDERATIONSSome manufacturers will provide a short charging cord, some a long cord, and some will include both.  A short cord is good for on-the-go.  A long cord is not necessary, but I find it handy for charging the power bank.  This power bank comes with one short charging cord.No pouch is provided.  It is not standard issue, but a nice accessory to include.Like just about all power banks, this one will charge via a USB cord.  It does not come with a USB wall adapter, so you'll need to have a USB charging port available somewhere (computer, wall adapter, USB hub, etc.).  Only some power bank manufacturers will provide the wall adapter.  I find them unnecessary.PROS:+ includes four connectors, including an iPhone connector+ small size, fits in purse or pocket+ good capacity for general purposes, will charge my iPhone at least twice+ embedded LED flashlight+ includes short charging cordCONS:- only 3 power indicator lights- power indicator lights are pinpoint size- does not come with a long charging cord- no pouchSUMMARYThis is a very good basic set.  It comes with everything it needs to get the job done.  All you'll need to supply is the device to be charged and a USB port for the power bank.This product was provided for review by Yubi Power.
summary: Great for cell phones

reviewText: Yubi Power 5200 comes with 6 inch USB cable for charging.  It also comes with multiple adapters and connectors to fit different gadgets including Apple's 30-pin connector .  It is powerful enough to charge your smart phones multiple times and extend the juice on your tablet for many more hours.Pros:- Compact and portable- Fast charging. Rated at 5V,  2.1A- Handy LED flashlight.  Press the button twice to turn on the flashlight feature, and press it again twice to turn it off.- Very easy to use- Sleek looks, simple and clean designCons:- It doesn't automatically turns off if you detach it from your gadget. You will need to press the button about two seconds to turn it off.- No Lightning cable for newer Apple devices.Sample item was provided by the distributor for this review.
summary: Small and powerful.  Also an LED flashlight

reviewText: A straightforward, solid, high-powered external battery packA solid, compact, battery pack that can charge my Galaxy Nexus about 2, maybe 2.5 times on one charge.  No other bells or whistles other than the LED "flashlight", which is a nice thought, but is too weak to really be useful anywhere other than dropping your keys on the darkest of nights. I wouldn't miss its absence.Along the lines of weak LEDs, the power LEDs are hard to see from a few feet away-- they could be brighter.  There's only one charging output.  There's a set of universal adapters and a short cable, with a small pouch to carry it all.  There's no smell from the unit on first use (many battery units have a chemical scent when first charged up).My only real complaint with this unit is the on/off switch-- I have to turn the unit off after charging it, and turn it on to charge a device (and off when done)-- most powerbanks automatically feed whatever is attached and shut off on their own.It takes a while to charge the powerbank from a 1A AC adapter, maybe 6-8 hours?This kind of handy device fills the "in transit" gap, when I'm traveling and haven't gotten to the rental car or hotel yet, but really need my quickly-draining smartphone battery to be working-- charge it up on the go.  It could be just as useful during commutes, especially on mass-transit.  And after my experience with 2012's "Derecho" storm that left vast areas of my home-state of Maryland without power for days, I also appreciate having additional ways to keep my portable devices charged, when I'm most depending on them.[ I was given this product for the purposes of review. I received no other compensation, and my review is my honest opinion of the product. ]Recommended.
summary: good straightforward battery pack

reviewText: Disclaimer: I received this product in exchange for an honest review.Alright, I received this charger several months ago and have been debating how I wanted to review it. The charger does work well. I found the charge was sufficient to recharge my Droid three times before being drained. I also used it on my Kindle Fire and got two uses out of it. The charger attachments included are somewhat flimsy, but are sufficient for the task at hand. I was disappointed that it did not come with an actually charge cord. That may have simply been the one I received. Dunno. I did try to contact the manufacturer about this, but received no response. Overall, I would give this external charger 3.5 stars, but given as how it was above average functionally, I opted for four stars.btw, it's somewhat of an afterthought, but the LED light does work well enough to, say, light up your doorknob so you can use your key when it's dark, look through boxes, or presumably help find a cord and attach the charger to your phone in the dark. Again, very functional.
summary: Above average charger.

reviewText: My husband is willing to try anything once, especially when it comes to his phone.  I will spare the details, but he is no stranger to pushing his phone to the max.  So when he saw this ZeroLemon 7000 mah battery for his Galaxy S3 on Amazon, he was all for it.He realized going in for a battery this size, there would be some size to it and his normal case would never fit, but it did come with a soft plastic back for the phone.  When it arrived he was amazed that it was more like a really large size battery piggy backed on a normal battery.  The case fit on super easy and is a soft plastic which adds much more grip than the stock shiny plastic back that came stock from Samsung.  It looks like it will absorb a fall, but as to how long the case lasts is an unknown.  By the way, he is not adventurous enough to actually drop the S3 to test the back's protection.So he got it all charged and ran it for 24 hours under normal use, including some WiFi tethering and music streaming.  Really a normal day for him.  There was still 48% of the battery left after 24 hours.  For an S3, that is amazing.  Yes, he said it adds some weight and thickness to the phone, but it still fits in his car holder and he just carries it in his pants pocket so it fits fine.So now he is totally in love with this battery and singing its praises.  Then he took a little trip and clicked on the GPS for navigation.  Hmmm, no satellite lock!  Well, S3's are notoriously known for bad for GPS, but  he has always been able to get a lock outside.  He went through possible fixes on line and tightened all the screws, pulled the SIM card yada..yada..yada, but still no satellite lock.  He was not even thinking it was a battery issue until he thought about the size of the battery.  He looked on line and found the GPS antenna placement was in the top left side of the phone looking from the back and it is partially covered by the battery now.Still not wanting to give up the battery, he switched to his old battery and got an instant satellite lock.  Put the new 7000mah battery in and no lock.  Repeat it all again and the problem is always with the new battery.Verdict, it seems this battery just won't allow GPS to work on his phone and he is bummed.  He still uses the battery, only because his need of GPS is seldom, but when travels he will be taking it out.So, if you need GPS, I just can't recommend this battery.  If you don't use GPS, then it is a great choice for a long lasting battery.Disclosure:  I received a sample unit to test and evaluate in exchange for an honest unbiased review.
summary: Great battery..but whoa, what happened to GPS

reviewText: *Disclosure: I was contacted by ZeroLemon and given a sample of this product specifically for the purpose of reviewing it.*As smartphones get smarter, bigger, and thinner, battery technology has a hard time keeping up.  With my Galaxy S3, I needed to charge twice a day with the stock battery.  Overnight, and again in the afternoon so that I had enough power left to finish out the day.  If I spent the day texting a lot, another charge might be needed by midday.  On really slow days, I was looking at just charging over night.  After popping in the ZeroLemon extended battery, all that changed.  Once fully charged up, heavy days only dropped the battery to ~60%, average days to ~80%, and light days....well...it was still at ~50% two light days later. So now, I might need a charge once every other day.  Given that this battery has several times the capacity as the stock one, this information shouldn't be too surprising.The offset to all the run time is of course the added size and weight that has been added to my S3.  Roughly, it's double thick now with the case on.  And, you're going to have to use the included case, as no one else that I'm aware of makes a case to fit this monster in.  It's not bad though, allowing free access to all the ports and buttons, not to mention fits well.  If you use NFC, have no fear with this battery/case combo.  It works just fine.  And finally, it could be just me, but I've found that the added size helps a bit with texting, as in, it's easier to type.All in all, love it so far and still have 160 days to see if I can break it.
summary: Scotty, I need more power!

reviewText: A few months ago I decided to get my first Android phone. This was strictly for app and accessory development - I still use iPhone as my primary phone. After fiddling with several phones I finally settled on Samsung Galaxy SIII as my choice - it had the best price/feature set of all the phones that I've either tested or considered. However, it still has a fair share of shortcomings (and I'll probably write about those in another review). One of the more noticeable shortcomings was its unacceptably short battery life. Even on the full standby mode the battery would die after only little over a day of use. And this is without me even setting up the cell phone coverage! So when an opportunity presented itself to check out a bigger capacity battery I immediately decided to seize the opportunity.So far I have been really impressed with this ZeroLemon extended battery. It has about three times the capacity of the standard S III battery, and my rough estimate of its life on a single charge is that it's about two to three times longer than what you normally get. The estimate is only rough since the usage and circumstances may vary from day to day and from an individual to individual. In terms of battery capacity I am definitely impresses with this product.This extended battery attaches to your cell phone by removing the back cover and the standard battery. The ZeroLemon battery is too physically large to fit inside the regular cover, and hence the back of your phone needs to be covered with the included TPU cover. This is an effective, albeit not very elegant solution. The new cover dramatically alters the look and feel of your phone. Also, even though I have not had any problems with it so far, the cover doesn't feel as securely and snugly in place as a snap-on cover that fits in the back. I've seen some other products out there that completely place the extended battery inside of an external cover, which to me seems like a sturdier solution.The cover leaves all of your main ports accessible, but it covers the side buttons with its own version of the same. These are effective, but not as responsive as the "bare" buttons on the phone itself.The extended battery also makes your phone noticeably thicker and heavier. However, if neither the extra bulk nor the esthetical look of your phone are not a concern for you, and you really need all the extra power that you can get, then this battery/cover combo will do the trick. I am still not sure how well it performs in the long run, but when I find out I'll try to post an update to this review.
summary: Solid, Capacious Extended Battery for Samsung Galaxy S III

reviewText: These ZeroLemon batteries for the Samsung Galaxy S3 have definitely met my expectations, although they have a slightly larger capacity than the original battery these seem to last me about the same amount of time, maybe a little less; however, this is a possible conclusion because every time you use the phone you use it in a different manner, whether surfing the web, listening to music, or playing games, they all require different amounts of power, so the end result can vary. I am still very pleased with these batteries, what is great about these is that it keeps the phone in it's "natural" form since it isn't an extended battery that is usually way bigger than the old battery and you can keep your case on your phone without worrying that it will no longer fit. It's always a good idea to keep some extra batteries and these do just that since it comes with two batteries, and an extra charger that allow you to charge one of the batteries while the other is in the phone. I can highly recommend these batteries by zerolemon, you know that they will be good batteries.I rate this product 5 stars out of 5 stars!I hope this review has helped you out!I received this product for testing and evaluation, my review of this product is completely honest and unbiased, the words stated above are my own.
summary: It's always good to carry extra batteries

reviewText: I'm reviewing the 18600mAh external battery here. The 18600mAh battery is great. I travel a bit and when you are out of the house, an external battery is a necessity. I received this a sample for review. This 81600mAh battery is one of the most powerful I've ever seen and it's compact (the smallest I've seen for this capacity) and inexpensive.It has 2 slots (1A and 2.1A) so you charge 2 devices at once, a tablet sized one and a phone sized one. 81600mAh means huge capacity. On a 7 day travel, I did not manage to use it up at all. This would be great for a family traveling with a lot of devices. I only wonder if they could fit more than 2 ports on it.It comes with a nice mesh travel bag and a USB charging cable.So to summarize: A large capacity external battery that is not only compact but inexpensive. A winner all the way around.---------------This is a large extended battery for the Galaxy SIII. It fits on the back of your phone but because of the size of it you need to use the included case extension. Both the case and the battery fits on snugly.Before use, I charged the battery to its full capacity. I used a charger and just left it on the wall for about a day. I'm not sure of time as I charged it in the morning and just removed it at night.For a moderately used phone, the battery lasted 4-5 days. The charge is pretty incredible. In the first one or two days, I kept looking at the phone seeing that there was still juice in the battery when a normal battery would have long needed another charge.I highly recommend this battery for those going on trips or day trips. For someone going on a long hike or camping this would be excellent.Disclaimer: I received a sample from the manufacturer for the purposes of review.
summary: Excellent!

reviewText: For the intensive gamer, always on GPS, or road warrior, this is a great package.  TheZeroLemon 2x Samsung Galaxy SIII 2300mAh Slim Battery + Free Battery Charger with USB charge portgives you lots of options for staying charged on the go.The package includes two (2) 2300mAh batteries designed for the Galaxy S III, one (1) wall charger for the batteries that includes a USB charging port on the bottom.The batteries fit well in the phone.  As compared to my experience with the OEM battery (2100mAH) that came with the Galaxy, I'm getting noticeably more time as I would expect; a few hours more at least.  I'm still conditioning the batteries at this time, however I do have positive feelings about this set.  Even still, just for having spares in the event of a dropped call due to battery depletion makes this a great value. I'll update once I have more charge cycles and have a better feel but at this time, I'm very impressed.Disclosure: I received a sample product from the manufacturer for the purposes of providing this review. A review in exchange for the review sample was not promised. The views and opinions expressed in this review are my own, and in no way represent the views or opinions of the manufacturer or vendor.
summary: Great Value for Galaxy S III Owners...

reviewText: There are so many external batteries on the market and many are simply too expensive or don't have enough power to supply even one recharge of a phone or tablet.  This ZeroLemon SlimJuice has 18,600mAh of battery power.  I have only seen one other battery at 20,000mAh and it was more expensive.  This is a fair price.  Considering that it can charge your phone (I have an iPhone 4S) over eight times and a tablet (I have an iPad2) twice, before you need to recharge the device.It also has two ports (which is now standard) with one at 1.0A and the other at 1.5A for a slightly faster charge to your device being charged.  If you  do charge two devices at once, a full charge will take a bit longer than if charging just one.The size is perfect.,  It just fits in your pocket without bulk.  The only thing that it lacks is sufficient indication of remaining battery power.  It is shown (by shaking the device, which is cool) with three blue tiny LED lights.  These represent 33%, 66% and 100%.  Mine came about 2/3 full and took about two hours to fully charge 100%.  All external batteries claim more than 500 cycles of charging but that would take a few years to use up.  You've have to recharge it every other day for almost three years to get to that point.I have yet to fully charge from a zero or even 33% charge, but most take about 7-8 hours to charge, as stated in the specifications.  All external batteries are best charged overnight from a PC or a USB AC plug-in for a wall socket.  It also holds a charge a long time.  This is true for most external batteries.  I've had some that hold a charge a few months.  This is a great item for a vehicle, a piece of luggage or general traveling (great for a long plane trip - continuous power!).  Product supplied for a fair and honest review.
summary: THIS Is The Battery For A Long Lasting Charge

reviewText: Talk about power. There's enough juice in this power bank to charge my Kindle Fire HD 8.9" tablet about 1  times. It can charge my Android tablet and my HTC One phone both at the same time.This is a large power bank. I'd recommend it for large tablets or for long trips without power. It's a little too big and heavy to carry around every day in a purse, but it's not too big to carry on occasion.The exterior is rubberized and it comes with a pouch. These simple features add much to the aesthetics of the product. In the world of power banks, it does what it does and it does it well. No gimmicks here.  If you want embedded cords or flashlights, digital meter, or power indicator lights, you won't find it.  One 1 amp and one 2.1 amp port: it's raw power, simply power.This product was provided for review by ZeroLemon.  I received a black power bank, but only the white one is available at this time.
summary: Simply Power

reviewText: The biggest USB power bank I've seen, the 18600mAh in this SlimJuice is enough for several charge-ups, even for tablets. For the mere 2300mAh my LG Nexus5 needs, this thing is like a mothership.(Note the current listing for the product has a mix of reviews consolidated from various ZeroLemon items; this review is for the SlimJuice 18600mAh external battery)Build quality is solid, with a rubberized exterior over a dense rectangular battery. The rubber-like surface does a good job of not showing fingerprints and smears. Three blue LEDs are the only indicators. For this much capacity, a little more granularity would have been nice (5 or even 10 lights). There's a nice "cloth" mesh carry-bag included.The USB ports seemed a little "tight" until I had used them a few times. Even odder, the provided coiled USB to micro-USB cable (looks like old-style telephone cords) has a non-standard micro end. Compared to several other cables, the metal end of the micro sticks out a lot further than normal. It fits fine in the SlimJuice, but in other devices it protrudes strangely. I have plenty of other MicroUSB cables, so no big deal, just an oddity.As you'd expect for a battery this big, charging it up can take a while (but you don't have to do it often).Considering how important mobile devices are to modern living, I like carrying this kind of powerbank in every bag I use (laptop case, camera bag, airline carry-on, etc). This kind of unit also fills the "in transit" gap, such as when I'm traveling and haven't gotten to the rental car or hotel yet, but really need my nearly-drained smartphone battery to keep working. It's also better to not top up batteries for just a few minutes on a car charger (bad for batt life), so a powerbank allows you keep charging as you leave your vehicle. One other place that a powerbank is most useful is long coach-class flights (which usually don't have in-seat power). Coach is way more bearable when your tablet/e-reader doesn't run out of juice before the halfway mark![ A sample was provided to me for review. ]A good choice for users with multiple devices or needing extended run-time. Recommended.
summary: A huge external battery for multiple charge-ups

reviewText: I like this 6200 mAh power bank from ZeroLemon; it is priced very well as compared to others that hold this much charge, seems to be well constructed, allows two devices to be charged at a time, and it has a series of bright blue lights that give you an idea of how much power is left as you drain it. Very recommended.Most of all I like it's shape -- about 5.5 inches long x 3.5 inches wide and just 1/4 inch high off the tabletop... it's a perfect platform to put a phone on while the charge is occurring. If you would like to see pictures that I took of it in use, go back to the unit's main sales page, scroll down to where the "Most Helpful Customer Reviews" section starts, then look to the right of that area for the "Product Images From Customers" section. Took a few shots of it alone, and with an HTC Droid DNA being charged.This external battery comes with a USB cord that has a micro-USB end (or you can just plug your device's USB cable into it), we tested it with much success as summarized below.  Packaging was simple - a form-fitting, zip-loc style plastic shipping bag with accessories wrapped in their own plastic bag. It was easy to open. Even though this battery pack has an amazing capacity - 6,200 mAh - it is still of convenient size and weighs at just 5.7 ounces.Upon receiving the battery, we plugged the unit into our wall adapter (used my son's Samsung S3's wall adapter) and let it charge until 100% full which took about 4 hours to complete. When charged, all of its blue lights are lit.Operating this unit is a breeze -- just connect your device to one of the ports with the USB cable. Its ease-of-use is a good thing and the operating manual that comes with it is easy to read if you find that you need it.The storage capacity of this battery is outstanding and the charging times we experienced were impressive. We tested it with a Samsung S3, HTC Droid DNA, and an iPhone 5C... and, on average, we the device's battery gained about 1% per minute (it took the Samsung S3 60 minutes to go from 23% to 83% charged) when using the 2.1A port (charging times using the 1A port were about twice that of the 2A port).  As is typical, the phones did get a little warm during the charging process but no warmer than if put on its own charger.  The battery pack did not seem to heat up at all.The Amazon sales page and the documentation note that there is a 36 month (3 year) "Warranty Guarantee". If an issue arises before that period expires I will return here to update the review and let you know what the issue was and how resolution was handled. I did receive this battery gratis from the manufacturer, and have put it through the paces to objectively find out how well it performed. My statements here reflect that testing.This type of portable power for this price? What's not to like? Affordable, portable, and did the job as described by the manufacturer.If you are looking a battery pack of this size, style and capacity, for use as I have described above, then we recommend it highly.Go for it.
summary: ZeroLemon SlimJuice 6200mAh Portable External Battery Backup Power Bank - Dual Ports - Excellent Device - Large Capacity

reviewText: ZeroLemon 18600 mAh UP is a slim, 14 ounce, no-frills dual port charger which packs the largest amount of power of the ten chargers, both external and case chargers, that I have tested to date. By "no-frills", I mean there is no small on-board flashlight on the side and no exact digital meter read-out to divert the power of the ZeroLemon charger from its main function: to charge many USB devices from one fully-charged ZeroLemon 18600 via the two USB ports rated at 5V, 1Amp and 5V, 2.1 Amps, respectively. There are 3 small blue LEDs, each representing 1/3 of the remaining power. This charger is the first to conquer tablets without any problem other than the length of charging time: in this case just over 5 hours for one tablet, while simultaneously charging an iPhone 5, and still had 66% of capacity left. I basically then charged all of my spare USB devices and have 'two lights out of three' remaining. The manufacturer recommends fully charging this unit before use and states it takes a few re-charges before it begins to deliver its full capabilities. At 18600 mAh, I was impressed with the ZeroLemon's first performance after that initial charge, especially in tablet charging that has proved troublesome to other competitors' chargers. Charging the ZeroLemon itself is projected at 12 hours. My Highest Recommendation. 5 EFFECTIVE Stars! (1-ZeroLemon 18600 mAh charger, 24" accordion charging cable, iPhone 4 charging head, and knit fabric carrying case. 36 month warranty. This item was provided by the manufacturer for testing and an impartial review.)
summary: AT 18600 mAh, ZEROLEMON SLIMJUICE CAN CHARGE MANY USB DEVICES

reviewText: Disclosure: the manufacturer sent me a sample for review. However I write unbiased reviews and will not risk my reputation as a reviewer for the sake of a free item.This review is for the 18600mAh external power pack. Some reviews here seem to be for other items.This battery pack is slim and not very large considering its capacity. It weighs in at 9 ounces on my kitchen scale. That's heavy enough to be noticed but light enough not to be a burden in a briefcase.You charge this pack via an external USB power source (not provided). Depending on the source you use, charging can take a while, something like a "long overnight" of 12 hours or so. This is in line with expectations.There are two outputs, one a 2A and the other at 1A. Both can be used simultaneously. If you're not in a hurry and are charging a single device, use the 1A output for less heat at the cost of slower charging.Three lights on the pack indicate the approximate state of charge. When you're charging up the pack, three solid lights mean a full charge (although I always charge an extra hour beyond this point, as this type of indication system is approximate at best). On discharge, the lights tell you in very rough terms how much power is left. It also is only visible when actually charging or discharging. You can't press a button, as with some other power packs, to check the state of charge.The unit comes with a single cord, USB to micro-D, which is a standard charging cord. Most of its length is coiled, which makes for easy and neat storage. If you have an Apple or other device that doesn't use micro-D, you use the cord that came with your device. My unit did not come with instructions, either.Given that the unit is quite portable and simple in design so that usage is easy, how much can you get out of it? Typically, you ought to expect 70 to 80% efficiency and charging down to about 10% residual power. That would mean you'd get, in round numbers, about 12500mAh of actual charging power. I tried this out in a consistent mode, using it nightly to charge my Droid X. Based on the way I use the Droid X, to make a long story short I would expect 18 days of charging. That's quite a lot, and I actually got 20 days in the one test I ran (it takes too long to do multiple runs). So power output is somewhat better than expected. 20 days of charging is a long time to be able to use a cell phone without touching an AC outlet. (Keep in mind that I don't drain the Droid X beyond 50-60% most days.)More power-hungry devices will of course yield less running time. A modern "large" smartphone should get about half the run time as my less demanding phone, and a tablet maybe a quarter, but this very much depends on usage patterns. You should be able to deliver just about two full charges (from battery-out shutdown) to a typical tablet.Zerolemon offers a 36 month warranty, which is amazingly long for a power pack.This is a good power pack to take on a long trip, like backpacking, where you'll be away from AC power but still in range of a cell tower. It is also good to have for emergencies such as storms, when power can be out for days. You'll be able to keep two cellphones running for the course of a relatively long power outage. This can be a very significant safety feature.Summary of pros:-Delivers advertised capacity-Easy to use and suitable for a variety of use cases-Highly portable-Very long warrantySummary of cons:-No instructions-Power level indicator very approximate and only visible when charging or dischargingOverall, a very good unit backed by a strong warranty, and easily merits a five-star rating.
summary: Portable, powerful, easy to use

reviewText: I'll begin by saying that suction cup/permanently mounted holders are not my first choice for either a phone or GPS in an car. I don't care to have any unnecessary obstructions in my line of sight, I don't like the visible rings that suction cups leave on the windshield between cleanings) and I generally feel that visible mounts suggest to the dishonest that the car may be worth exploring for valuable electronics. So my first choices are a dashboard beanbag type point (for GPS) and a console-mounted gooseneck holder for phones. But that's just me...I realize many people are used to or prefer windshield suction mounts or a permanent mount applied with adhesive to their dash. This holder offers both, and includes both the suction cup and the adhesive disc for both mounting options.The phone/GPS cradle easily held each of an HTC Evo 4G, and HTC Evo Shift (both with their protective cases, one hardshell and one rubber) and a Garmin Nuvi 1300 1300LM. The cradle rotates 360 degrees, with an audible click/detent about every 12 degrees. The ball and socket connector between the cradle and the mount moves through more than 90 degrees.Overall, very solid feel. If you use a windshield suction mount or prefer a permanent dash mount, this would be a good choice.Note: This product was provided to me by the vendor for purposes of this review.
summary: If you like windshield or permanent mounts: works fine...,

reviewText: I think the concept of this was great.  It looks great, feels great but doesn't operate great.  It's okay but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.  I've seen better universal holders that work better.  The way you open this is by pushing the two grips apart but when I do that I get a squeaky spring noise.  I find that very annoying but what I also find annoying is how much force I must use to open it.  It takes a lot of energy to open it compared to others I've played with.Once you do get it in, it's great! I love how easy it is to rotate your phone in the holder.  The holder has a great suction cup and holds well to the glass or plate provided.  I've tested this on the Samsung Galaxy S2 with a silicone case on and it works.  It's probably going to be the largest phone you can put in because it definitely will not fit a Note 2.I like a lot of the Bolse products and I'm very sad to have to give this 3 stars but it really isn't up to par.  I was given this item for an honest review.
summary: Grips phone very well - A little uncomfortable to open

reviewText: I tested Bolse Mini Windshield mount with Galaxy Nexus phone with an extra large battery which makes it significantly fatter than a standard battery. The phone also has a skin on that adds to its sickness.I am attaching a collage of 5 photos that I will be referencing in this review. You can find the  photos by following 'customer photos' link under the main photo of this listing.Bolse windshield mount is pretty compact and I was not sure how well it would fit the phone as with its extra fat battery and skin it is pretty big. Photo #5 shows the fit.  To my surprise it worked!  I would say this pushed the capacity of this holder to its limit. If the  phone was any larger or thicker I would be worried that the grip would not hold.Photo #1 shows a close up of the grip of the holder. I put a circle around the arm that expands to grasp the phone.  The mounts grasps the phone on the sides while leaving ports exposed. This means the phone can be plugged in if you are using it as a GPS that uses a lot of battery power.The way this holder mounts on the windshield is different from other mounts that I have tried. Others create suction by a lever, this one is attached by rotating the base. The unit came with no instructions, and it took some fussing in the car to figure out how to mount it, especially since it was different from other mounts we have used in the past.The mount comes in two pieces, the base and the grips. I found that I got the strongest hold when I attached the base first, then mounted the phone to the grips (photo #5) and then mounted the grips onto the base.  I have a small piece of soap stored in the car, which together with my spit gives my windshield mounts a good grip.I really liked the flexibility and ease with which I could rotate and angle the mount.  Photo #2 and photo #3 show the phone positioned in different orientations as well as with different angles.  The mount gives you full 360 degree of freedom for positioning the phone.Update after several weeks of use: Bolse phone cradle mounts very close to the windshield, it has a shorter extension than the other windshield mounts we own.  Depending on the slope of your windshield this could keep your phone fairly far from the driver.  My car's electric plug is positioned fairly close to the floor level and the length of the charging cord for the phone also restrict where I can attach this mount.  The combination of these two aspects puts the phone into a position that makes it hard for me to make out street names on the map if I use the phone for navigation.  Someone with good eye sight will not have any issues, but my I wanted to update the review to add this note for those who don't have great eyes.The mount also comes with a second option for mounting with an adhesive disk (which also has tiny screw holes) to mount the holder on the dash permanently.  I don't like using permanent mounts for a number of reasons: I don't want to damage my car with permanent screw holes or hard to remove glue. I also rather not have anything permanent suggesting to passers by that the car might have "interesting" electronics hidden away.  I have not tried the adhesive disk and cannot comment on how well it works.I received an evaluation unit for test from manufacture to write an honest and unbiased review. I have described positives and negatives of my experience with this unit and if you have any questions on the features I covered I am always happy to respond to comments.Overall I am pleased with the unit, particularly how easy to is to change the orientation and position of the phone.  So far I have not had issues with the mount loosing suction (tested with the weather in the 50s).Ali Julia review
summary: Holds Galaxy Nexus phone with an extra large battery + skin

reviewText: I live in Western New York and it is currently early December and the temperatures in the morings are high 20 to low 30's.  I repeatedly tried to get the Bolse Mini Windshield Car Mount Holder to stick to my shield but nothing would work.  I cleaned the area thoroughly with alcohol, tried using water to moisten the suction cup and even tried what another reviewer mention - baby oil and nothing worked!  It would not stick.  I really did not want to use the permanent disk mount since I already have two others mounted on my dash for my GPS and radar detector.I brought it into my office, sat there and look at the really nifty gadget wondering what I could do with it and it hit me.  Why not try and mount it on my computer desk in my office.  I always have my iPhone laying flat on my desk and and since it is always on mute, I miss text and calls.  I had my doubts that the Bolse Mini Mount would stick to the side of my wooden computer desk but to my surprise it did!  Of course I used the permanent mount with it and it is staying in place.  I now have my iPhone vertically mounted eye level next to my computer. I am able to see text messages and calls coming in.  Have easier access to change music when using the iPhone with my Bluetooth speaker in my office and I can easily charge my iPhone when sitting in the holder.I thought about only giving this item 1 star after the mishaps I had trying to get it to mount on my windshield, but it has actually become very useful for me at work.  Instead of calling it a car mount, they should name it a versatile mount.I attached a couple of pictures under the main page showing how it is attached to my computer desk in my office.
summary: Would not stick to my windshield, but found a better use for it!

reviewText: When I first saw the design of the suction cup, I wasn't sure how well this would adhear to my windshield. The cup appears very shallow and I couldn't quite see how it would create the proper seal to hold my iPhone. After reading through the included information, I found that after pressing the suction cup up against the glass, you then turn the rotating base, creating a tight suction against the glass. Cleaning the glass well first to remove any dust/dirt definitely helps in getting the best results. I tested this out first inside my home on one of my mirrors. The mount was able to stay attached all day. However outside, we are entering into the heart of winter here in Minnesota, and it is quite cold. While the windshield mount was able to pass the first test of staying attached to my mirror in my house all day, it didn't do as well staying attached to my cars cold windshield. I could only get it to stay on for a short while before it would come down. I've found this to be the case with most all suction cup window mounts though.The grips on the holder can be pulled out and adjusted to fit a large number of cell phones and other devices, and are lined with a soft foam so it won't damage anything. The mounts arm can rotate in all directions and angles, so where every you mount it, you can turn it so the screen is facing you. I will probably use this windshield mount again this summer when it's warm. But right now, while it's cold outside, it doesn't grip as well.A product sample was provided for an unbiased review.
summary: Work as long as your windshield isn't too cold.

reviewText: This Bolse "Mini Windshield Car Mount Holder" is physically smaller than expected but still nicely holds my HTC EVO 4G, even with the extended battery back and a in silicone case. The actual usage of the holder in my car was best achieved by using the "permanent" dash mount option which placed it in easy reach in my truck.This is a good quality device that has padded grips the are easily adjustable to hold a wide variety of devices, including my EVO, a iPod Touch, a Samsung Epic, iPhone 4, and iPhone 5. It is also easy to rotate and position the phone for the best viewing angle. This can also be used anyplace you need a hands-free mount for your phone and would be very useful in a workshop.Recommended!CFHNote: Review unit provided by manufacturer
summary: Good Mount For my Smartphone - Recommended

reviewText: *SEE END OF REVIEW FOR COLD WEATHER TIPS!*After updating our GPS more times than I care to remember and despite that fact, getting lost more times than I care to admit, my wife and I decided to get rid of the thing altogether. By "get rid" I mean relegate it to the back of our glove compartment which is as good as for us! The only thing left to figure out was a good solution for holding an iPhone to use as our GPS. I would like to thank LowerPriceUSA for providing me a copy of this holder for evaluation purposes, in exchange for an honest review.IN THE BOX- Phone holder attached to swivel/tilt base- Smooth mounting plate with adhesiveBUILD/QUALITYDespite being a relatively inexpensive accessory, the quality of this device matches the mount that came with our $150+ Garmin GPS. The holder has a soft foam material that grips your device without harming it. After giving the dashboard a good cleaning, I stuck the mounting plate on using the adhesive. It stayed nicely and I will update this review as necessary. I also tried mounting it directly to the windshield, and while I prefer to have it on the dash so it doesn't obstruct the view, the suction cup kept it nicely in place.DESIGNWhat I really like about this holder is the way that it swivels and tilts. This means you can switch from landscape to portrait with ease, something you may need to do depending on your GPS app. Your phone will be held in via tension, and was large enough for an iPhone 4 with a case. As mentioned in the description, the holder fits phones with a width of 2" - 3.3", so I would suggest checking your phone before buying. Once mounted, there was no slipping that I could see - there is enough tension on both the swivel and tilt mechanisms that the iPhone stayed where I put it!OVERALLFor the price, this is an excellent accessory! It is well made, functions as promised and has ended my search for something that allows me to use my phone instead of my GPS. It seems as though the Garmin is going to stay in the glove compartment!------------------------------------COLD WEATHER TIPSOne of the reasons I don't like having anything on the windshield is that the cold really does mess with the efficiency of suction cups. It has little to do with the quality of the suction cup, and more to do with the physics of freezing and evaporation which (without some help) are mostly unavoidable. Below are some tips for those of you that understandably don't want to permanently stick something to their car:Method 1:Clean both the suction cup and the target area with glass cleaner. If applying to a cold windshield, blast the defogger for a few minutes while warming the suction cup with your hands, a seat warmer etc. Once both are reasonably warm, push HARD to stick suction cup. This won't work forever, but will work better than a cold suction cup.Method 2:Clean both areas, and apply a TINY bit of baby oil to the suction cup. Oil has a much lower freezing point than water, and also will evaporate at a much slower rate. This will keep the vacuum stronger and more durable. Too much baby oil, and your GPS/phone will start to slide down, so just use a little!Method 3:There are products  on the market for this very purpose. I haven't tested this particular one, but if you're willing to spend a few bucks to keep your expensive electronics safe, it has decent reviews:MawMaws Suck-It-Up Suction Cup Securing Liquid
summary: Couldn't really ask for more!

reviewText: This mini (and it IS small) car mount holder for smart phone attaches via included dashboard disk or, alternately, directly to the windshield.  My windshield is too sloped to use it there, so I attached it using a disk I had already installed for my GPS unit.  There, I had to adjust it to keep the weight of the phone from gradually pulling the viewing angle downward.  If you look at the product photo, you'll see that the iPhone is angled upward, but that requires either a low dashboard or a tall driver, preferably both.To use the suction cup, you must start with a clean surface.  It is even easier if one surface is damp.  You twist the base clockwise to attach the suction cup.  Just like GPS devices that use suction to install, the device will occasionally fall off with drastic temperature changes or dirty surfaces.  The side arms grip the phone tightly -- so tightly that I feared that they would crack my iPhone 5 with the pressure.  (They didn't.)  The arms are padded to keep them from scratching your phone.  The best part of this product is the mobility -- side-to-side, up-and-down, and everything in-between.  The ball joint allows the use to orient the phone exactly as she pleases.  Of course, this is also the feature that allows the arms to drift downward.For an occasional mount to use a smart phone as a navigation device, this is a decent option, especially if you have a windshield that allows a direct mount at a slightly upward angle.  Note:  The manufacturer provided me with a sample for review.-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann
summary: A Decent but Not Ideal Way to Mount Smart Phone for Navigation/Viewing

reviewText: If you are planning to attach this Bolse Mini Car Universal Holder to your windshield, don't consider buying it if you live in a cold climate.  I'm simply calling this holder a fair weather friend.  I wanted to like it, but it's simply not a practicable tool for colder climates.  Clean windshield or no, it simply won't stick to mine for very long without clattering down.  I've tried several Bolse products and have been quite satisfied with them, but this one is not a "universal product."However, if you are in a warmer climate, this mini holder may suit your needs.  It definitely is solid and I do like the way it rotates.  The inside of the clamp is well-padded and when closed will readily hold your iPhone, GPS (maximum width of 2 3/4"), Galaxy, or Mp3.  There are several nice things about it, but cannot recommend it to anyone living in any winter wonderland.Product Features:~  Material:  ABS & PVC~  Color:  Black~  Holding Range:  5.5cm ~ 8.5cm~  360 degree rotation in all directions~  You can put your cell phone (iPhone 5, Galaxy) in several positions.~  Quick installationSample provided by distributor.
summary: Nice concept, but this windshield car mount is a fair weather friend only ...

reviewText: This is a very ingeniously designed and versatile car smartphone mount. It is very compact, and at first I was skeptical about the suction cup's ability to attach securely to the windshield. However, a simple twist of the dial was all it was needed to attach it. Furthermore, I've left it attached for a few days used it with my iPhone 4S during that time, and it had remained firmly stuck to the windshield. However, there are a few things that I've noticed that you might want to consider. iPhone is a fairly light device, and that probably helps with preventing the cup from detaching. Also, I have not had the best experience with attaching this holder to anything but smooth, clean glass surfaces. It also probably helps that I am using it during the mild California winter - in my experience with other suction cups and windshield mounts they tend to come off in summer or really cold winter weather.The smartphone holding area is very versatile and can hold most smartphones that are available today. I would not try it with Galaxy Note or an even larger device, but short of that it should work well for most smartphones.The range of positions that you can put your smartphone in is one of this mount's greatest features. You can practically adjust it for almost any viewing angle, and it's relatively easy to adjust these angles while you are driving.The biggest shortcoming of this mount is its extension. It is a very small mount, and it will keep your smartphone very close to the windshield. This is problematic for two reasons. First, the visibility of the smaller smartphone screens will be diminished to the point of being useless. This could potentially be a safety hazard. Second, it may not be possible to extend the charging cord all the way to the smartphone from the cigarette lighter plug. This could prove particularly problematic during the longer drives.If you are looking for an easy and convenient "backup" smartphone mount, then this little guy might be just what you would want to get. It's compact, versatile, and holds firmly to the windshield. However, for longer trips or if you rely on a GPS device daily then you might want to get a more robust mount.
summary: Compact and Inexpensive, with Few Shortcomings

reviewText: After reading through other reviews, I had to check to see whether my state permitted objects to be mounted on a car windshield.  I was in luck.  (Google "windshield laws) to check out your state.I have an iPhone 5, and I use the GPS more frequently than I'd like to admit, considering I've lived in the same city for a decade and a half.  When using the GPS, I would typically stick the phone in my cup holder, which, for obvious reasons, is not the best way to try to get a full view of the maps.  When I was contacted by the manufacturer to receive this product for free in exchange for an honest review, I decided to give this a shot.  As others have mentioned, there are no mounting instructions, so I had to read directions from other reviews.  I'm not willing to risk damaging my dashboard, so this puppy will always go on my windshield. The holder grips my phone and slim-fitting case firmly.  The 360 degree rotation works like a dream.I live in a somewhat urban area where car break-ins are not unusual (it's already happened to me once right outside my house), so I never leave the holder mounted on the windshield when I'm not in the car.  Frequent attaching and removing from my windshield has so far had no effect on the performance of the holder.I live in a fairly mild state, so I have not have the problem with lack of suction that others in colder states have experienced.  Overall, this is a very inexpensive and useful device, but be sure to research the laws of your state.To reiterate my comment above - I was provided this product for free in exchange for an honest review.
summary: Great product, but check out the laws of your state re: windshield mounting

reviewText: Over the years, I've owned and used several window and dash mounts for use with various products (phone, GPS, etc.). With every mount I have tried, I have found both good and bad things with regards to functionality and design.  The Bolse Mini Windshield Car Mount has been a pleasant experience in comparison to most comparable mounts in this price range and unit size.The design of the Bolse mount appears to give you the most flex and rotation possible in such a compact mount.  There are some aspects of the mount with respect 'grip' and 'rotation' that I have concern with.  For those who like to grab their device and go, the phone/device gripping mechanism can require a little extra effort to release, especially for those who use rubber cases on their phone.  Nothing major, but it does require a couple more seconds to release; with that in mind though, the security of hold is spectacular.  I have absolutely no concerns that when my device is secured in the mount it could/might fall or come out.Suction to the window/dash is reasonably great.  I've had no issues with the holder coming loose from either the window or dash while driving.  I did use an alcohol prep pad to clean the surface first, which is often strongly recommended for creating the best bond.  Currently with the winter weather, there has been a morning or two I have come out and found the mount had popped loose from the windshield, but with extremely cold weather, I haven't been overly concerned.  I've had similar experiences with other suction cup mounts (radar detector, GPS, etc.) and can only blame it on the weather, not so much the mount.Something I have wanted to try, was to use this mount to hold a digital camera for the purposes of capturing video out the front windshield while driving.  I mounted the holder just below the rearview mirror and pointed it out with a digital camera secured inside.  The video I captured was fantastic, however there was slight bumping in the video (unit wasn't as ridged in keeping position, but that can be blamed on uneven roads and potholes).  I was impressed with the results of my experiment testing this as a dashboard digital camera mount.Overall, considering price and features, the Bolse Mini Windshield Car Mount is a respectable mount that is well worth the cost.Disclosure: I received a sample product from the manufacturer for the purposes of providing this review. A review in exchange for the review sample was not promised. The views and opinions expressed in this review are my own, and in no way represent the views or opinions of the manufacturer or vendor.
summary: Overall, A Good Windshield Mount...

reviewText: I've had my share of car mounts. This is pretty similar to others in the same price range. I think the problem with the suction coming off is pretty common to anything mounted on a cold windshield. So I use my car mounts in conjunction withUniversal Vehicle Cup Holder Adapter with Suction Mount Surface and Adjustable Base for Arkon , Bracketron , Garmin , Skiva , Sunpak , Midland mounts to hold GPS / Smartphones / Radar Detectors / MP3 Playerswhich, although it is somewhat large and bulky, keeps my phone in the perfect position and I'm not battling with finding a good mount location in a mini van.So this car mount holder is fine but the problem I have is the tension used to keep the phone in place. I like to be able to take my phone out fairly easily without having to battle with the holder. I also like knowing it is securely in place. This mount does one of the two. It holds my phone very firmly which creates a problem for a quick release. It takes some effort to get it out of the mount. I know this is probably a good thing for keeping it secure while driving and is the perfect solution to a hands free use system.So I guess it depends on how you want your phone holder to work. A solid product with limitations for my personal choices.I was provided a sample unit to test for an honest review.
summary: Moderate Car Mount, With Limitations

reviewText: With a 50 degree outside temperature, this mini mount holder was easy to apply to our windshield...just turn the 'Press n Twist' suction cup lock clockwise to adhere the suction cup to the windshield. I haven't tried it in cold weather yet.One of the arms  pulls out which extends the width of the holder from 2" to 3 1/4". This allows you to use a device ranging in size from approx. 2 1/8" to approx. 3.3" in width.Suctioning the holder to the bathroom mirror kept my IPod Touch off the counter & out of my way, making it easier to read my books or listen to music while I'm getting ready.  This holder also comes with a plastic disc which has adhesive on one side. This disc can be used if the suction cup won't adhere to your surface. Apply the adhesive disc to a clean surface, then attach the suction cup to the plastic disc. Using the mini holder with the adhesive disc opens up the mini holder for many different uses. One way that comes to mind is  applying  the adhesive disc to your wall next to an outlet, then suction the the mini holder to the disc which keeps your device off the table while charging. You can easily remove the holder to use in your vehicle. Of course, the adhesive disc would still be on your wall. The disc can also be attached using 3 small nails or 3 small screws depending on the surface you attach it to. Neither nails nor screws are provided.At approx. 2.06" wide, my LG Cosmos phone doesn't fit snugly into this holder. Concerned my phone could slip out, I rotated the holder til it was in horizontal position.  Problem almost solved; my phone can still be slipped out of the holder. This is the reason I suggested that your device be at least 2 1/8" wide.I was provided a sample of this product for an unbiased, honest review.
summary: Not just for cars...Holds devices ranging in size from approx 2 1/8" to 3.3"

reviewText: The Bolse Mini windshield phone mount is an inexpensive way to hold a cell phone to the windshield in an automobile for hand-free use.It grips from the side so that it doesn't block the ports on the bottom of the phone--the arm slides out to insert the phone and has a spring for tension.  It has neoprene padding on both arms and the base to protect the finish on the phone.  The holder rotates with firm clicks and the arm has a ball joint so the position is infinitely adjustable.The suction cup works quite well when moistened and applied to clean glass with a full twist although it can be difficult to remove.  There is also an adhesive plate for use on textured surfaces such as a vinyl dashboard.  I see other reviewers have noticed that suction cups can release when there is a wide change in temperature but this is so easy to apply that it wouldn't be a problem if it did fall off. The base could also be attached with adhesive for permanent application and that would be a good idea after using it a while to determine ideal placement.This handy little stand can also be used to keep a cell phone or calculator mounted on a desk at any angle.A sample was provided for unbiased review.
summary: Handy cell phone holder

reviewText: There are a lot of car mounts out there and the competition is tough.  Some states do not allow windshield mounts (like California), so you have to attach it to your dashboard.  No worries.  Bolse has it all figured out.Bolse had invented one of the most compact suction mounts available.
