With the great options like using an SD Card, FM radio, Aux in and Bluetooth connectivity, you are sure to find many ways to enjoy playing music from this speaker.  The sound quality is rich and impressive for the price.  I think this product is a great buy and worth the investment.Disclosure: I received a sample product from the manufacturer for the purposes of providing this review. A review in exchange for the review sample was not promised. The views and opinions expressed in this review are my own, and in no way represent the views or opinions of the manufacturer or vendor.
summary: Great Looking Speaker, Really Great Sound, Lots Of Options, Solid Buy...

reviewText: This is an attractive, sleek stereo Bluetooth set of speakers that sits about 10” long and a 3” wide cigar shape. An attractive circular blue light surrounds the top function area where the controls are for mode, play, pause, phone answering, volume and song forward/backward. The sound is similar to other speakers in this range, in that, the highs are crisp, but the lows are nearly absent. Don’t expect a punchy bass even though the two speaker drivers are 1.5”, there is only about 2 watts of power.The lithium battery takes about 2-3 hours to charge, but provides 7-8 hours of play time, depending on how loud you play your music. You can also talk on the speakers in Bluetooth mode, which is kind of cool. The range is also impressive, going up to 30-feet and I was able to transit it through a wall. The back allows enough slots for you to play from almost any type of device. Next to the on/off button is a USN port, an SD card slot, a mini-USB port, an input for 3.5mm auxiliary and a plug for headphones.The Bluetooth technology easily pairs it up to any device you own within 30 seconds. I’d say for the average user, this is not a bad device and I like the fact that it is so easily portable and is able to be used with almost any kind of device that can Bluetooth music. Product was supplied for an honest review.
summary: Sleek Look, High Functionality And Adequate Sound Quality

reviewText: I received this from the vendor to review. I will admit up front that I was expecting yet another bluetooth speaker. I actually got much more - and in a sense less - than I expected. I'll get the 'less' part out of the way first. The sound quality is not as good as some of the bluetooth speakers I have tested. However it is not advertized nor pretending to be a high-end speaker. Sound is more than adequate when I am multi-tasking.What made me fall in love is not only does this allow me to connect from my phone and stream music, but also to play from my SD card. I have a few micro SD cards left from other phones when I upgraded card capacity, and they all have a lot of music on them. I had intended to wipe them and give them to a friend, but when I saw the SD card slot I tried it and that was the selling point for me. You do need an SD card adapter to use a micro SD card, which I had. Simply insert it and cycle the mode button to the SD card input and you will be playing music. There are controls that allow you to also skip tracks back or forward and a volume control.  The max capacity claimed for an SD card is 16GB, but mine worked fine with a 32GB card. You can also insert a flash  disk into the provided port.Do note that the micro USB port for powering this speaker is right above the SD card slot and it just barely clears with the included USB cable. I have a different cable with heavier ends that does not fit. This is not a show-stopper, but you should know about it.For bluetooth you press and hold down the mode button until you hear two beeps, when scan from your phone. This speaker will show up as FB Wireless and easily connects. It breaks up about twenty feet from the transmitting device (my phone in my case), but that is on par with some bluetooth receivers that I own.You can also switch this into FM radio mode via the mode button and receive stations in the 87.0 to 108.0 MHz range.It has an internal battery similar to a cell phone type that, according to the documentation, provides three hours of music play time. Of course when attached to the USB power source you can use this indefinitely.There is one final feature: you can directly connect this to any sound source via a 3.5mm cable (also included), so a PC or other device without bluetooth can still play through this speaker.For me this is the perfect companion. I have it in my enclosed patio for when I am enjoying a cup of coffee and the beauty of nature with Bill Evans or Mile Davis playing in the background. It may not have the biggest, best sound, but it is certainly the most versatile and convenient speaker I own.
summary: One of the handiest bluetooth speakers I own

reviewText: This is a multi-function MP3 player, FM radio, and a Bluetooth player.  An impressive small device that can do so many things except open a bottle of beer. It is a sleek bullet style speaker that gleams of blue LED on top like a robotic eye.Some tips how to use:- To auto search for strongest stations, press and hold the button with the telephone icon.- To adjust volume, you would need to press and hold the previous or next button.Specs:2W outputBluetooth 2.1800 mAh lithium ion battery (uses a BL 5C battery similar to the one used in Nokia phones)Frequency response  - 150hz to 20 kHzOn and off button at the backPros:Easy to pairLight and portableAble to play while charging3.5 mm stereo line-in jackCan play MP3 straight from an SD or microSD card (with adapter)Headphone jackRubber footings prevent it from slidingCons:- Sound quality is very decent but not great.  A little more bass would make this Bluetooth speaker s real competitor.- Without an LCD screen, it is difficult to see which radio station you are listening too- it is nice to have the antenna inside and not protruding, but it does sacrifice some FM reception signal strengthSample item provided by the distributor for evaluation review.
summary: Bullet style speaker - impressive resume

reviewText: I am normally bringing along a couple of external battery packs for my devices but, for the purpose of testing I was able to charge 2 phones and the charged Okay while the car was driving so it really works if you don't mind two phones hanging off you 'cigarette lighter' port while driving. It should be great or near perfect or less distracting if you had a 'second' 12V outlet accessible from the back seats. The way this works is: you plug in the Yubi, you plug the charging wire into the Yubi, you attach your phone or phones and the Yubi charges your phone or phones.Should note that the Yubi people sent me a 'for review' unit and I didn't have to pay for it. I didn't promise a 'good review' either.Let's start with the positives:- Nice looking with a porcelain-like white plastic finish and chrome accents- Ring of power light turns on to show that it's working- Works with both Apple (very well) and Android devices (sort of) but is optimized for Apples.Now, the documentation claims that you have one 2.1A port and one 1A port, sharing 2.1A between them. The manual states that "the two USB charging ports [...] are specifically designed with DIFFERENT charging capabilities according to the Apple standard" (the all-caps is mine). The problem is that two 'different' ports are not labeled so there is no easy way to tell the 2.1A port from the 1A port. I emailed the Yubi organization, asking them to clarify.When it comes to Androids, ports that comply with Apple's standard are not as efficient as the specs might indicate. I believe that you will get about 0.5A but if most of the gadgets you're carrying along are Apple then 0.5A for the lonely Android is probably better than nothing. I also asked the Yubi people to comment on this and I will post an update once they respond.The charger gets high marks for the pretty design but loses one star for the ports labeling confusion, which will be addressed soon (see note and explanations below)._________________________________________________UPDATE:An email from the makers of Yubi clarifies some of the issues raised above. Here are the clarifications, only slighted edited.The 2 charging ports are with different current.  The top port is 2.1A and the bottom USB port is 1A. The first edition was not labeled, but the future ones will be labeled and are almost ready.For now, how to know which one is 2.1A and which is 1A, if you lay the car charger with the Logo on top and the specs label on the bottom position. Then the top charging port is 2.1A and the bottom one is 1A.It is not meant that each port has different charging capabilities, it really means that they used different types of charging capabilities but all were used based on Apple's charging method.Android phones will work just as fine as the Apple products, 0.5A is not the most you can get, you can get a full 2.1A or 1.0A depending on which port you use. While most smartphones only take 0.5A even though the port can deliver 1.0A or more. Because the phone only needs 0.5A
summary: For Apples all the way, good for Oranges (Androids) too

reviewText: Lets face it, in today's world everyone has more than one gadget that uses USB charging ports.  Nearly all electronics today can be charged by USB, making this device the must have for every car. The Yubi Dual USB Charger can charge cellular phones, tablets, digital cameras, Bluetooth devices, iPods, MP3 players, GPS systems, etc.The Yubi Power 2.1Amps 10W Dual USB Car Charger allows you to use one of your car's 12V power socket's to simultaneously charge two devices that use 1.1Amps or lower, or charge an iPad or tablet that uses up to 2.1Amps.  It splits the 2.1Amps when using both ports at the same time.The charger is sleek looking and the glowing LED rim is a nice feature to let you know it is properly connected.  It is not a low profile charger.  Every car really should have one.I received a sample to test and evaluate in exchange for an honest review.
summary: Dual USB charger

reviewText: Over the last year or two, I've had a few car USB adapters and have begun to find them invaluable, since they charge every one of my devices while I'm on the road. Instead of needing to buy individual car chargers for my iPad Mini, iPhone, Kindle, and my kids Nintendo DS and PSP, I can simply use the charging cables that came with them, and plug them into this USB car adapter. In addition, I can charge the internal battery of my Samsung digital camera and my Kodak digital video camera with this adapter as well. Anything that uses a USB cable to charge the device, you can use with this adapter.The design of this Yubi adapter is quite sharp looking. I have the black charging adapter, and it's accented with chrome details and a LED glowing ring that lights up when it's plugged into the charging port. It's a bit more eye-catching than the typical plain plastic USB car adapter. Also, it has two USB ports, so you can charge more than one device at a time. It's quite handy to have in the car and it charges all my devices without any difficulties. Very nice!A sample was provided for reviewing purposes.
summary: Sharp looking USB car adapter

reviewText: So many of my new electronics come equipped only with a usb cable and no wall plug.  This not only works with all of them so far, it gives me four outlets for the price of one wall plug.The folding feature is cool too for travel.  This thing is light and travels well inside of my laptop bag or backpack full of small electronics.  I have had a little trouble with it not staying flush with the wall socket, but not enough of an issue to complain.Highly recommended.Sample provided for unbiased review.
summary: Nice!

reviewText: *Disclosure: I was contacted by Yubi Power and given a sample of this product specifically for the purpose of reviewing it.*Test devices:Google Nexus 7Asus Transformer TF-101Kindle Fire HD 7"HTC OneSamsung Galaxy NexusHTC EVO 4G LTESamsung Galaxy S2Samsung Galaxy S3Samsing Galaxy S4Up until recently, I'd been using aScosche Dual USB Car Chargeror aSatechi Soundfly Viewwith a splitter for charging up the usual devices I carry about.  This is typically my phone and one or more tablets, though more than once I've had a friend along that was in need. The 500mA output on the Scosche isn't great, not giving much of a charge during my 45min-1.5hr commute, especially if was using one of the devices during the trip.  The Soundfly was a bit better, but still only half what I could get from an AC outlet and charger.  And then comes the Yubi Power unit.  The construction is solid, and it has a red LED ring along the outer edge to let you know that it's connected to power.  The red doesn't go with my blue interior lighting, nor the white housing with the rest of my interior, but oh well.  Overall, it looks good and the low profile keeps it from sticking out like a sore thumb.  On to the testing.Out of the gate, the Asus Transformer was not impressed with the Yubi.  The Yubi isn't the first of charger my Transformer refuses to play well with, so I wasn't surprised.  This is due to the Yubi being wired up to match Apple's charging method while the Transformer has it's own ideas, plus it is designed to pull more that 5V to charge.  My guess will be that a Samsung Galaxy Tab will having similar issues. Outside of that device, everything else worked great, both in single an dual charging setups.  I used a 2A wall charger to compare the charge rate on each device, then repeated with the Yubi.  As expected, the difference in rate was nil.  Things got interesting when I started comparing in dual charging mode.  What should happen, according to the secs and details on the Yubi, is that each device should charge at half the rate of a single device (2A/2 devices = 1A per device, or, 10W/2 devices = 5W per device).  What I found however is that in all dual charging scenarios, the devices charged at the same rate as when they were charged by themselves.  To verify that they would charge slower if not given 2A, I tested each with a 1A charger and the Scosche adapater.  Sure enough, there was a significantly lower rate of charge.  So, what does this mean?  The biggest thing is that the Yubi I got was able to charge two devices, at the same time, and at the same rate as if they were plugged into a wall charger.  That's huge for me.  I don't know if I got an extra special unit from Yubi, or if this is the norm, but it was sealed in retail packaging, and I'm quite happy with my new adapter.
summary: Bring on the power

reviewText: This is a nice looking little car charger.  It has two ports for charging two devices at once.  One port delivers the strong 2.1A charge required by newer tablets, like newer iPads and Kindle Fire tablets.  The other port is great for smaller devices like phones.Use your own USB cables to connect the devices to the charger.  It's great to be able to charge two devices at once.And in addition to being a powerful charger, this charger has a nice high-gloss finish that won't look junky in your car.I was provided this item for review.
summary: Good strong two-port charger

reviewText: This is definitely a sleek little car charger that is capable of charging a couple of your devices on the go.  It's very light-weight and actually quite attractive.  It's a dual USB port charger that will support just about any device you need to take with you, including an iPad.Although the ports are not marked, if you plug it into your cigarette lighter with the Yubi logo facing up, the 2.1A port for the iPad is on the top and the 1A port for all other devices is the one on the bottom.  The spring-loaded prongs keep the charger in place very nicely.  Altogether, it's a good little charger for the money.SPECS:~  Input:  DC 12 - 24V~  Output:  DC 5V 2.1A for 1st port (top)  /  1.0A for 2nd port (bottom)~  Material:  ABS~  Color:  Black~  Dimensions:  1 1/4" x 3"~  Weight:  0.9 oz.~  Certificate:  RoHs~  RecyclableSample provided for review.
summary: The Yubi is a nice, sleek, affordable dual USB charger ...

reviewText: This Yubi USB charger is just what the doctor ordered. My wife and I travel quite a bit together and between the 4 iProducts we have, there always seems to be one that's dead. Now that we can charge two at a time, we've been able to keep them all going, which is nice. On top of all our Apple gear, it was also able to charge our Kindles, which came in handy.The unit itself is well-built and seems almost too slick for such an inexpensive item. It looks great in my car and I like the red ring light around it (see the pictures above).Ultimately, if you have a lot of devices, this will be a life-saver.Note: A sample was provided for unbiased review.
summary: Just what we needed!

reviewText: Now that we have become dependent on devices such as iPads, iPods, iPhones, mobile phones, GPS, Kindle, digital cameras, etc that accompany us to meetings in different locations or, better yet, on vacations, finding a source for recharging these devices has become a significant part of our movement plans. Who gets the benefit of the car charger?YUBI has made that less of a challenge with this excellent car charger that is designed to comfortably share two devices at once. Sleek in design and free of safety problems, this smart new device plugs into your car source and then has two ports  - 2.1A port for your iPad's greater demands,  and one 1A port for your iPhone, iPod Touch etc. The built in safety device is an LED window that first, lets you know if the charger is correctly placed and second, prevents over charging or over heating.With this well constructed and even handsome appearing device there is no problem with getting your `travel tools' ready for the next meeting or next stop while you're driving there. Use both ports at one or use one at a time (ie, charge your iPad while you're on the phone or depending on your GPS). This device just makes life and getting there less complicated and assures you that there is a dependable power source at your fingertips. Highly recommended. Grady Harp, June 13
summary: On the go a lot? No problem with low charges on your equipment

reviewText: I've got other wall-plug chargers and several USB hubs that charge.  This is the only one that comes with a 2.4 Amp port.  Tops for my other chargers is 2.1 Ampere.  So, this is more than adequate for my Kindle HDX 8.9" and I believe it charges fastest when no other devices are plugged in.  The other three ports support up to 1 Amp each.With the bright red plastic tab in the lowest port, there is no doubt which of the four is the 2.4 Amp.  That's helpful.It is nicely constructed and solidly built:  Looks like a quality product.  It is a nice shape and fits in the palm of my hand.  I like the neon green trim band that frames it.  Great that the prongs fold down neatly, too.It would have been very nice if there were LED glow lights inside the ports, so I could find a port in the dark, but I can't knock it for that, as the product page didn't claim it had that feature.  And I wish it had been available in white, but it does what it's supposed to do and does look sharp in black and neon green.It's a great addition to my "family" of wall chargers, especially since it charges my Kindle.*I received a sample product from Yubi.
summary: I like that it has a 2.4 Amps port

reviewText: The Yubi Power YPCC-210W 2.1Amps/ 10W Dual USB Car Charger was a lifesaver on my trip this week to attend my grandson's graduation from boot camp at Fort Jackson, South Carolina with his mom (my daughter). Traveling from place to place we were able to keep a full charge on all our photo equipped devices between us using this charger so at the start of the two  hour graduation ceremony, we started with a full charge. That helped us get more of the graduation captured on her iPod and iPhone with the help of my excellent Yubi chargers. She didn't miss a picture that she wanted of the entire graduation of about two hours. Both of the chargers were also finished when we were done, so back in the car we recharged them and her iPod and iPhone with the car charger. The combination gave us a great picture experience to save for our soldier and also to send to all of our large family, including his sister, who is teaching at an International school overseas.The Yubi charger also works great on my Kindle and Smartphone to keep a charge when I am traveling on my own.The car charger was a gift to me from a friend and I can't thank him enough for thinking of me and giving me such a useful and powerful car charger.
summary: Yubi Power YPCC-210W 2.1Amps/ 10W Dual USB Car Charger

reviewerName: Jeri Zerr "formerly a Road Warrior of the Nth...
reviewText: I simply do not have enough USB charger ports in my vehicles anymore, the Yubi dual USB car charger has helped me double the capacity of an outlet.I've been using the Yubi to power both my navigational GPS while also recharging theStay Powered with Yubi Power YP520A 5200mAh External Battery Charger with LED Flash Light.  These two pair up very nicely to help me keep my devices powered as well as recharged. I received both devices for reviewing purposes, together they have helped me to resolve a problem where I was missing phone calls due to my smart phone dieing before I was able to get it recharged. They are both made to high standards and are withstanding the test of time.  If anything changes I will be updating this review.
summary: Reliably powers the GPS while recharging my cell phone or battery chargers

reviewText: There are so many car chargers available on the market for all types of devices.  I often prefer to have a charger that will let me choose the cable rather than having a built in cable that could bend, twist, and break making the whole charger useless.  TheYubi Power YPCC-210B Dual USB Car chargeris great because it offers two charging USB ports and you can use whichever USB cable you need for your specific device.The design of the unit is very sleek.  In a piano black finish, the plug protrudes only about a half an inch from the cigarette lighter socket (this may vary slightly from vehicle to vehicle).  The unit features a red indication glow ring that indicates it is powered and ready to use.  I say glow because, unlike most chargers on the market today with a bright LED light, the red ring light is soft and not distracting, especially during night driving.The unit features 2.1A total capacity.  One port is capable of 2.1A (great for an iPad or other tablet) and the other is rated at 1A (great for most Smartphones).  The limitation of this charger is that if charging a tablet and a phone at the same time, the total output will only be 2.1A; the unit will split that into 1.1A for each charging port.  It's not that big of a deal to me personally because it can still charge, only a little slower.  If you find that you are constantly charging a tablet and phone at the same time while on the road, this may be a consideration.This charger is great for doing double duty on small devices like music players, Smartphones and the like.  It is capable of tackling a tablet such as the iPad with a full charge capacity if only one port is used, if both are in use then the total Amps will be split between the ports as noted above.Overall, despite the minor limitation of splitting the Amps when charging a tablet and phone at the same time, I still think theYubi Power YPCC-210B Dual USB Car chargeris a great charger.  It's priced right and lives up to my expectations.Disclosure: I received a sample product from the manufacturer for the purposes of providing this review. A review in exchange for the review sample was not promised. The views and opinions expressed in this review are my own, and in no way represent the views or opinions of the manufacturer or vendor.
summary: Must Have Car Accessory For iPhone/iPad/iPod and Android Devices...

reviewText: This great little car charger does a good job of powering/charging two products via USB port. It has a smooth finish and is compact enough to fit into fairly tight car spaces.When properly inserted, the charger emits an orange light indicating that it is powering your devices.I've been using it for a many weeks and it is a solid unit that has yet to fail me.I was provided a unit for evaluation and an honest review.
summary: Sleek Looking, Slim Design, Smooth Finish

reviewText: The Yubi Power YPCC-210B car charger will charge two devices at once. It features two USB ports specifically designed according to the Apple standard - a 2.1A USB output designed for charging an IPad (can also be used to charge other devices), & a 1.0A USB output for charging an iPhone, iPod & other devices. However neither USB port is labeled. I guess if you own an IPad you'll know which port will charge it.Very important: The YPCC-210B also features over-heated, over-current, & over-charging protectionI was able to use my IPod Touch 4G & my Kindle Fire HD while they were both being charged, at the same time.  Be aware that if you use this car charger to charge your IPad, you will not be able to charge another device at the same time.I tried this car charger in our Civic & our Malibu...it didn't fit in either very snugly, but  wasn't so loose that it would easily fall out. The red LED indicator ring,  which isn't as bright as Amazon's photo,  lets you know if the charger is properly connected.A sample was provided for an unbiased, honest review.One year limited warranty.
summary: Features over-heated, over-current, & over-charging protection

reviewText: The Yubi Power 2.1 A - 1.0 A Dual USB Port Car Charger plugs right into the cigarette lighter and stays securely in place but removes easily. The design is unobtrusive, sturdy white plastic with metal accents, lightweight but solid.  A red LED ring lights up when it's plugged in to show that it's powered and ready for use.There are two standard USB slots, one at 2.1 Amps and the other at 1.0 Amps. They can be used at the same time to recharge most small electronics (or to help maintain the charge while they're in use) with a total output of 3.1 Amps. For instance, you can use an iPad in the 2.1 Amp slot while recharging an iPhone in the 1.0 Amp slot. Input is 12-24V DC.  This charger will even charge up a power bank for use away from the vehicle.Having this in the car is not only handy for everyday use, but is almost critical for long-distance trips or when there is a power outage.  Several people I know were only able to use their cell phones after the 2012 hurricane because of car chargers like this one.This Yubi Power car charger will will work with most USB-powered small electronics and has a 1-year limited warranty.A sample was provided for unbiased review.
summary: Handy USB car charger with 2.1 A and 1.0 A ports

reviewText: This is a solidly built car adapter that can charge any device that uses a USB port. The unusual thing about this adapter is that it has two USB ports; one emits 2.1amps and the other 1.0 amps. Obviously, the 2.1 amp will charge approximately twice as fast as the other. You can also charge two items at once, however it will charge slower. There is also a nice LED status light that shows it is working. The 2.1 amp is best used to charge larger items like an iPad and the 1.0 amp is best for iPhones or other phones devices, (Blackberry, HTC, Digital Cameras, PDAs, Mobile Phones, etc.). This charger is universally usable for almost any chargeable device that can be charged using a USB port. Plus, it is guaranteed not to over-heat, over-charge (THIS Is a BIG one) or over-current. Plus, the price is absolutely right-on. This product was generously supplied by the manufacturer for an honest review.
summary: Charge Fast Without Overcharging!

reviewText: First, at the time of this review reviews of a two-port car charger are intermingled on this page with the product that I am reviewing: Universal Quad-Port USB Travel & Wall Charging Station. If my comments seem out of whack with other reviews it's because of a glitch on the page.While the review sample I received is designed with foldable prongs for travel I use mine as a home solution. For me it's perfect because I have a bevy of speakers, cameras and other devices that all charge via USB ports, and the three 1 Amp ports in this charger are ideal for those because some devices will not work with chargers rated higher. The fourth port is rated at 2.4 and is ideal for my Samsung Tab 3 tablet.What makes this useful is I can simultaneously charge my tablet, phone and two other devices all at full speed. No one port or combination of ports diminishes the charging rate of the other ports. There is integrated circuitry that balances the charging rates, so there is no danger of overload.Although I use this as a home charger it's ideal for tourist travel where you have a camera, and more than one phone to charge if traveling with a family or companion. The prongs fold, and are polarity independent. What I mean by that is it can be plugged in upside down in a wall outlet, unlike many appliances and chargers that only go in one way.I love this unit so much that I am planning to purchase a few more for other rooms in the house. I am embarrassed to admit that I have that many toys.
summary: Perfect solution if you own many devices

reviewText: Cable-Mix sent out review units to some people, and I am one of those people.I've collected multiple car chargers that came with cell phones or other portable devices, but the Yubi Power is substantially nicer.  A glowing ring lets me know where it is in a dark car and also reminds me to unplug it when I park.  Two ports mean that I am not limited to one device at a time without a bulky adapter.  It is also a bit sturdier than the type that are pack-ins.  It is not remarkably nice, but it is a good value and is high in utility.
summary: Practical

reviewText: This is a great multiple use car charger...... It feels very solid in your hand.  I feel that it will last a long time....will update if that turns out to wrong.......I like the glowing aspect of this charger........ It is easy to see that it is powered up and for night time driving no more turning on the overhead lights to find the usb plug.I tried this with every phone, tablet, game player etc......and it charged them all.I plugged in two units and also plugged in two smartphones to one and one tablet to the other.  Then we took a planned road trip.  The devices worked flawlessly for the whole two hour trip and never go hot......and they stopped charging once the device was fully charged.A good product.  Major selling features for this are: 1. small form factor...does not stick way out of the dash and get in the way.... and 2.  the glow feature.I received a sample of this product with the understanding that I would write and honest review.  That is precisely what this is.
summary: SOLID, Pretty, and it works.

reviewText: A nice-looking car charger that could match up to your white smartphone style, and is easy to find in the dark.My favorite feature is the glowing LED rim around the unit's outer face.  The ring makes it easy to find the USB ports in the dark, and also easy to tell that the unit is properly plugged in.  I've more than once not-charged a device by accident because the charger wasn't properly seated (and checking from the phone was distracting while driving).  The ring isn't bright enough to be distracting, but bright enough to light up the little compartment where the charge port is hidden (at least when it's fully dark outside).The white color, besides being stylish and a little less "common" is easy to notice even when the LED ring is not powered, preventing you from leaving it in a rental car-- thus, this is the charger I carry in my travel kit.I only tested my common 1A smartphone (Galaxy Nexus), but having the higher-powered 2.1A outlet in the car would be handy for you tablet users.  Dual outlets also provide space for his-and-hers phones (or his-and-his or hers-and-hers, depending on your taste).  The specs indicate the unit has features to prevent over-charge, over-current, and over-heat conditions.The finish is polished and feels solid. My unit was made in China.  Recommended.[ I was given this product for the purposes of review. I received no other compensation, and my review is my honest opinion of the product. ]
summary: a swank little white car charger

reviewText: Yubi Power Universal Quad-Port USB charger is a nice USB Charger. It has four ports (Three 1.0A, and one 2.4A) so you can charge four devices at the same time. It's perfect for those who have multiple devices or to be used at shared office cube where your cube mate can use one of the ports without having you to remove your device/cable.  It is light and has foldable prongs so it's good for travel as well. It works with pretty much all devices. It's bigger than the original apple iPhone charger but this Yubi Power charger has four usb ports and the original apple iPhone charger doesn't have foldable prongs. Thanks Yubi Power for sending me this product.Sidarta Tanu
summary: 4 Port USB Charger, great for sharing.

reviewText: The Yubi Power YPCC-210B Dual USB charger plugs into your cigarette lighter, and provides two USB ports that can be used for recharging, or powering various USB devices.  One port supposedly delivers 2.1 amps, and the other 1.0 amps.  This is useful feature, but there doesn't seem to be an indicator which of the two ports provides more power.  The charger is available in either black or white.  When the black colored unit is plugged in, a red circular LED comes on to indicate the availability of power.This charger is well constructed, and seems designed to last.  The appearance is slick, with no exposed screws, with a nice polished finish.  The contacts are solid, and won't easily unscrew apart, unlike similar more cheaply made devices.  These types of adapters are convenient, and easy to use, and the price of the Yubi Power unit, is comparable to other twin port USB adapters on the market.  .I've got a few too many cigarette lighter adapter cords in my vehicle, so when the people at Yubi Power offered me the chance to evaluate this product, I welcomed the opportunity.  I may not use a device like this very often, but it's nice to have available, just in case.
summary: double the USB power...

reviewText: This is a great charger and probably the only one that comes with adapters to charge almost any device.  Now, I'm not one to need one of these since I can just use the micro usb cord without adapters but it's really nice to know that companies like them are thinking of the customer.After a full charge of the battery, I tested it on my phone (Samsung Note 2).  At the time of charging, my phone had 26% left.  Almost 2 hours later it charged all the way up to ~96% and I still had 3 dots on my charger.  This probably could have charged another 2-3 more times.  It's actually quite small but a little on the heavier side compared to a few others that I have.  It's got really smooth edges so it feels nice in your hands.To me, the flash light is a little unnecessary and not really friendly with the button.  I sometimes have to keep pressing it to turn it on and I'm not a fan of it.  There are no instructions included with this so it's kind of frustrating at times to use the flashlight.  However, as a battery it's great.  Easy to use and easy to charge.  I like the fact that it can be charged by the micro USB.Overall, it's a great battery and that's what it should be used for (not the flashlight).  I definitely think this is one that can be used by anyone.  I received this item for an honest review.
summary: Very handy little charger with many adapters

reviewText: This winter we had several major storms which knocked out power in our area for a couple of days. Being without television and lights (and even heat) is bad enough. being without my iPhone, and any way to connect to the outside world to find out what was happening is even worse. Fortunately, I did have a battery charger, and while we were without a phone, television, or internet for awhile, we had the basics.So, when I was offered a sample of this battery charger to test and review I was happy to add to my back up power supply.One of the key things to look at when you are purchasing a power backup is to see if it includes the specific connection for your phone or the item you need to charge. In this case, my iPhone 4 charges on the 30 pin connection, so it was perfect for me. This also charges at a level that allows me to charge up my iPad as well, so it is perfect for me.There are many chargers out there, this particular one is the perfect size to fit into a small area and keep on hand for emergencies (even if the emergency is that you forgot to charge your phone). Just remember to charge it back up once you use it, or regularly if you don't, so you won't be caught with two dead batteries at the wrong moment.Nice, handy, has everything I need.
summary: For when the power goes out ...

reviewText: I tested Sendy 5200mAh power bank with Nexus 7 Tablet (JellyBean 4.2.2), Samsung Galaxy 7.7 Tablet (ICS 4.0.4), and Samsung Galaxy Nexus cell phone (JellyBean 4.2.2), iPad Mini and Sansa Clip+ MP3.I received this power bank from the manufacture for an honest review be it positive or negative. One of the benefits of being requested to test different power banks is that it gives me an opportunity to compare them to each other using the same charging test, so I can compare them using "apples to apples" comparison. This set of tests allows me to provide unbiased results as the numbers speak for the performance of each unit.These comparison tests reveal that Sendy power bank works very well with Android devices (particularly the Galaxy Tab which is often the worst performer), but did NOT work with my iPad Mini.The size of the power bank is 4" x 1.75" x 0.75". It weight 4.5 oz on my digital scale. In addition to being a charge it also has a built-in LED light. The light is not very bright, but better than nothing in an emergency situation.My methodology for testing power banks is to charge each mobile device for 10 minutes and measuring how much each unit was charged in that 10 minute period. Each line in the table below represents a separate 10 minute test.I use Battery App by Elvison to determine how each device recognized the charging source. 'AC' status means the charging is at full charging rate. 'USB' status indicates charging at a lower charging rate. 'Discharging' status means that the charging rate is below the power that the device is consuming so it slows down the discharge rate but does not re-charge.✔ Nexus 7 Tablet--------------Charging cable -- AC ............. 1% change in charge in 10 minutes✔ Samsung Galaxy Nexus Phone--------------------------Charging cable -- AC ............. 4% change in charge in 10 minutesData cable ------ AC ............. 1% change in charge in 10 minutes✔ Samsung Galaxy Tablet 7.7--------------------------Charging cable -- AC ............. 5% change in charge in 10 minutes✔ iPad Mini--------------------------iPad Mini cable -- power source not recognized ............. 1% dischage in 10 minutes✔ Sansa Clip+ MP3--------------------------When I charge Sansa MP3 with a standard AC charger, the MP3 player goes into charging mode, displaying the charging animated icon. When it is plugged into the Sendy power bank the MP3 continued to play the content. This is a great benefit for MP3 player with built-in battery, this means I charge and listen at the same time and I do not have to wait for the battery to recharge.I am attaching a collage of 4 photos, which can be located by following 'customer photos' link under the main photo:Photo #1 shows everything that came in the package, USB cable with interchangeable tips and a small bag for carrying the power bank.Photo #2 shows the power bank next to Sansa MP3 player for size referencePhoto #3 shows Galaxy Tab with the battery app showing resultsPhoto #4 shows iPad Mini which did not recognize the power shot (when it does a white plug icon is displayed on the app screen)Overall:------------------Excellent performance for Android devices, does not work with iPad Mini. Nice size for travel.Ali Julia review
summary: Tested with Nexus 7 Tab, Galaxy Nexus Phone, Galaxy 7.7 Tab, iPad Mini and Sansa Clip+ MP3

reviewText: Disclosure: I was contacted by the manufacturer and given a unit specifically for the purpose of reviewing it.*See update at bottom of pageTest devices:Google Nexus 7Asus Transformer TF-101Kindle Fire HD 7"HTC OneSamsung Galaxy NexusHTC EVO 4G LTESamsung Galaxy S2Samsung Galaxy NoteSatechi Touch LampLittle battery packs like this can be quite handy to have around in a pinch. Providing a whopping 5200mAh worth of power, that's more than enough for refilling most any device out there.  It's also a fair amount to use with just about any USB powered device, like a lamp or light.  Besides capacity, one of the things that can be important is the output rating.  The Power Bank is rated at 5V/1A, which is larger than many last gen phone chargers, but half or so than that of many modern devices.  What does that do?  I'll tell you in a bit.Cosmetically, I thought the Power Bank a pretty good looking device.  Sleek gloss black with silver accents and muted blue LED lights.  The included cable and adapters for various devices gives the Power Bank owner the option to leave their own cables, or, have a spare to keep with the Power Bank.  Sendy got clever by using a power input connection, micro USB, that is also one of it's output adapters.  This puts micro USB adapter and the included cable on double duty, used both for charging the Power Bank and pushing power from it to a device.  The Power Bank's power efficiency is rated at 88%, which is pretty good (88% of the power pulled into the Power Bank is stored there), and the LED flashlight function was a nice touch in my opinion.  The rated storage temp is something one needs to be aware of though.  Only -14-140F max.  In other words, don't leave this in your car during the summer or winter if you live in a harsh climate.Putting it to use ran into a snag for me pretty quickly.  No matter what, the Power Bank would not charge the Asus Transformer.  Setting that one aside, all the other devices had no issues.  Digging through the included User's Guide, there is a note that the the Power Bank is designed to use Apple's charging scheme.  As such, not every device out will be compatible with the Power Bank.  Specifically mentioned is the Samsung Galaxy Tab, for which there is another adapter that Sendy will provide for free if you contact them.  Ok, fair enough.  How about the device charging rate that I mentioned earlier?  On all devices, the Power Bank provided 8-12% charge over the course of an hour.  Compared to the rate of charge when using an AC adapter, which was along the lines of 44-50% per hour, that's a steep difference.  Because of this low charge rate, I decided to check out what would happen if a given device was busy while connected to the Power Bank.  Could the Power Bank keep the device charged under these circumstances?  For this test, each device's screen was on, Pandora running in the background, and a looped YouTube video playing.  The Power Bank was indeed able to keep up, and even give a 1% charge per hour.  Good to know.Remember that special adapter for the Tab that I mentioned?  There is one little problem with that offer.  Nowhere, not in the user's manual, nor on the box, is here any contact info for Sendy.  Even if you don't need that adapter, what happens if you need to do a warranty claim?  Again, no contact info.  Using Google to search for the company website turned up nothing.  My attempts to contact the representative that had first emailed me got no response.  Not cool guys, not cool. At the current price of 10 bones, it's probably worth a risk buy, but I think the problem big enough to take off a couple of stars for.*Update* 5/17/13 After posting this review a couple of days ago, the Sendy rep has contacted me.  They registered a domain (today), and set up a support email account (info@sendypower.com).  Customers can also contact Amazon seller "Super Deals" for support.  The rep also let me know that they agreed that contact info missing was an issue and that they are correcting this issue.  On the issue I came across with the Asus Transformer, they are going to look into this and get back to me.  I've adjust the star count on my review from 3 to 4 to reflect this.
summary: Good Deal

reviewText: This sleek little battery pack is a must-have for travelers who frequently find themselves low on smartphone power with no outlet in sight. With an 88% efficiency rating, the power bank gives me roughly 2.5+ charges on my iPhone 5 or a partial charge (a little over half) on my 3rd generation iPad. (Buyers should know that power banks rated at 5400 mAh -- or any mAh, for that matter -- don't give all that power since some is lost in the charging and power transfer.) This Sendy power bank comes with a short cable, a carrying pouch, and several adapters for various devices. If you have an iPhone 5, you'll have to supply your own lightning cable. It charges using microUSB and outputs power via USB, so that means you can substitute a longer microUSB cable for charging or any USB-ended cable for specific devices not covered in the adapters.My iPhone 5 charges fairly rapidly with this power bank, not as fast as if I had it plugged into an outlet but still not bad. The iPad is a different story since it requires a lot more juice; it takes several hours just to get all the power out of the bank. The Sendy is a 5 V power pack, and iPads, to get the fastest charge, need a 10 V connection. Still, the Sendy works, albeit slowly. If I'm running low on my iPad battery, I can plug in the Sendy, and it keeps me running. If I'm using power-hungry iPad apps, however, the battery level will drop a little, even with the Sendy plugged in. The drain is slower than it would be otherwise, of course. If you're looking primarily for an extra power source for an iPad, I recommend looking at a greater capacity battery and, if you can find one, a faster charge transfer.The build quality of the Sendy seems solid. I like the design of the blue semi-circle of LED lights on its face to show the current power level. Most power banks have some variation on this feature, but I found this to be one of the more attractive displays. The on/off button is located in the center of the semi-circle. This can double as an LED flashlight by double-clicking the power button. Again, this feature is found on different brands of power banks, and it's something that can come in handy in an emergency. (Imagine being in a hotel room when the power goes off.) I wouldn't expect to use the flashlight when camping or other outdoors-at-night activities since the beam isn't all that bright as it travels away from the source.This power bank has found a spot in my briefcase. An external battery is an important tool for the frequent traveler or anyone else who chews through smartphone batteries. (Note: I received a sample for review.)-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann
summary: Great for Smartphones -- but Slow for iPads (4+ stars)

reviewText: We have two young daughters.  They have completely taken over all of the portable electronics in our house.  If you are like us, you probably always have something that is low on batteries at all times.  A typical scenario in our house is someone piling the kids in the car to go to the store, or the mall, or out to eat or wherever and grabbing the iPods, only to find them dead.  Noooooooooooooo!  These are the only things that keep us sane!  So that is where a portable charging solution would be great.I was provided a Sendy 5200mAh Power Bank for testing and review and was asked only to give my honest review, so this is what I found.Initial Impression:  The product looks really nice.  It has a silver metal casing on the sides and smooth black plastic on the top and bottom.  It looks and feels very solid and substantial in your hand, but not too heavy.  It has one power button, four blue LEDs that act as a capacity gauge, a micro USB input for charging the Power Bank and a normal USB Output for charging your electronics.  It is very compact and sleek looking.  It also came with a small 9 inch USB cable with several tips that are used for charging the unit and your equipment.  It has a standard Apple 30-pin adapter, but no Lightning adapter (which is typical at this point because Lightning cables are so difficult to reproduce).  I used it with a new AmazonBasics Lightning Cable which worked great.  It also has an LED flashlight which you activate with a double click of the power button.It came with some charge to it so I plugged it in and charged it until it was full.  All four LEDs were lit when it was full.  It only took a few hours to top it off for the initial charge.  After it was full I did some testing with my iPhone 5.I took the fully charged Power Bank and plugged in my mostly depleted iPhone 5 that had only 20% charge remaining.  I got the following readings.Starting Point = 20% ChargeAfter 20 Minutes = 43% ChargeAfter 40 Minutes = 66% ChargeAfter 60 Minutes = 87% ChargeAfter 80 Minutes = 98% ChargeAfter 90 Minutes = Full ChargeOverall, great results.  It was averaging a little better than 1% per minute which seems about right for a 1 Amp charger.  The Power Bank had plenty of juice to fully charge a pretty low iPhone 5 without any problem and the indicator lights still had three LEDs illuminated indicating that it had 50%-75% charge remaining in the power bank.Conclusion:  Overall, the Sendy 5200mAh Power Bank worked great during my initial testing and usage.  I have tested several Power Banks of varying capacities and this one performed as well or better than all of them.  The product is compact and easy to use.  It looks and feels like a high quality piece of equipment.  The flashlight was a nice addition.  It was bright and easy to use.  The current price of $27 is competitive with the other Power Banks of this size that are available on Amazon.  I can see this as an excellent option for a long plane trip or other travel where you do not have access to a power plug.  Highly Recommended!
summary: A Lifesaver if you are Always Dealing with Dead Electronics!

reviewText: A couple of years ago for Christmas my children all got together and gifted me with a 64 Gb iPad.  They were kind of nervous about spending so much money on something they weren't so sure I would like, but WOW did they ever hit the nail on the head with that one.  That iPad has my life on it - my photos, my music, 10,000 books, my recipes, knitting directions, a half dozen full-length movies, games, contact information for everyone I know anywhere, my accounting program, my bank balance - everything.  Where I go, the iPad goes -  and I spend a lot of hours in a car.A full charge on an iPad is good for just about 10 hours of use, so it is not unusual for me to run out of juice halfway home just about the time that the cell phones are all needing a recharge too, so I've been testing several different external battery chargers.  A couple of weeks ago the manufacturer sent me  thisSendy 5200mAh High Capacity Portable Power Backup External Battery Charger with built-in Flashlightto test, and I must say, this is my favorite of the three that I've tested thus far.The unit is quite small and weighs a mere 126 grams (4.4ounces).  It comes with a short cord that has a USB fitting on one end and a variety of connectors (4) that plug in to the other end.  The same cord is used to both charge the device itself and feed power to a device that you wish to charge.  The built-in flashlight is a nice extra bonus that makes it easy to find the plugs that you need in the dark.  The four bright blue LEDs that indicate the charge remaining in the unit are easy to read in any light.While I've tried the device on a variety of cell phones, tablets and ereaders, I have been most interested in how it functions with my iPad and I must say that I am impressed.  Unlike one model I've tested recently, which had an extremely short cord, the charging cord is long enough that I can continue to use my iPad in a normal manner.  The variety of plugs make it possible to carry just one spare charger, which can itself be recharged using either the USB port on a computer or an Apple wall plug adapter.I have deliberately run the iPad battery down to the point that it shuts itself off and then recharged it using theSendy 5200mAh High Capacity Portable Power Backup External Battery Charger with built-in Flashlightseveral times.  Twice I recharged the iPad while allowing it to rest undisturbed.  In both cases the unit delivered 60-65% of a full charge to the iPad, or about 6.5 extra hours of use.  I also recharged it while using the iPad as I normally do, ending up with about a 45% charge over and above what I had used.The unit comes with a small black velvet pouch to hold the unit, the various ends and the cord, with plenty of room left over for the Apple wall charger and the iPad power cable  (which you can also use with theSendy 5200mAh High Capacity Portable Power Backup External Battery Charger with built-in Flashlightinstead of the cord that comes with it should you need a longer cord) making it very convenient to throw into a purse or backpack.One final note - the directions that come with this product are remarkably clear and easy to follow, printed in type that is large enough to see without resorting to your reading glasses. Greatly appreciated!Grandma's $0.02 -  Great backup power at a reasonable price point.  Best I've tried thus far.  Highly recommended
summary: Don't Leave Home Without it!

reviewText: There really are so many reasons this product is a great purchase.  I travel often for both work and pleasure, and one of the most problematic things about traveling is keeping powered on the go. I have bought and own several power banks sold here on Amazon and some I have picked up in brick and mortar stores, but I really like theSendy 5200mAh High Capacity Portable Power Banka lot.  It makes the best use of features, unit size, and power capacity.This is what makes the Sendy Power Bank so great:+Lightweight- unit weighs less than 5 oz (138g), great for tossing in any day bag or purse.+Sleek operation- unit is very responsive with two presses of the power button to turn the light on, and two presses to turn the light off, a press to turn the unit on for charging and a press to turn it off when finished.+One feature found on this unit, which is not common to find on most power banks, is that the charging port is automatic. This allows the unit to turn on, beginning a charge the moment you plug any device into it, and it will auto-shut off (after 10 seconds) when you unplug your device. It's an amazing feature that saves you time in both turning the unit on and off. The unit also features an LED display that indicates the charge level by how many of the 4 blue LEDS are illuminated.+An LED [Flash]Light- Work, play, or travel, there are so great uses for a flashlight, weather on a dark plane, in a dark car, or inspecting your hotel room for cleanliness, this is a great addition for such a small sized unit.  The light is bright and powerful.+Recharges with a Micro-USB cable- No longer will I need to carry a specialty cable/charger to recharge my power bank, I can use the same cable I use for my Nexus 7 or Kindle Fire HD to recharge this unit.  You can recharge the unit with the included cable via computer, or use a wall charger like the one that came with your tablet or cellphone; manufacturer suggests ensuring the output of the charger you would use is at least 500mA and 5V DC.In the package you will find: the Sendy 5200mAh power bank, a soft drawstring carrying case (great addition, not often included with similar power banks), an 8" USB charging cable that works with the 4 (four) included tips (Mini USB, Micro USB, Apple (30-pin), and PSP)Being an `on-the-go' person, I like to have options when recharging my phone, tablet, digital camera, etc.; this is perfect for those purposes. Even for use with a Kindle Fire or Nexus 7, this power bank can get close to, if not a full charge for these devices.A primary consideration when looking to buy a power bank is the mAh the unit can hold, essentially, how much of a charge the power bank can hold total and provide to devices being charged. This unit has a single USB 1amp port with a 5,200 mAh capacity. When considering this unit, if getting a full charge for your device is important, think of this power bank as great for use with cellphones, and most Android tablets. This unit will add hours of life to your iPad, but it does not have the capacity for a full charge.Overall, theSendy 5200mAh High Capacity Portable Power Bankis perfect for the applicable uses. This is not just a burst of power, but provides full charges, and adds hours of life to your devices; important when getting to an outlet is just not feasible. The unit lives up to my best expectations.Disclosure: I received a sample product from the manufacturer for the purposes of providing this review. A review in exchange for the review sample was not promised. The views and opinions expressed in this review are my own, and in no way represent the views or opinions of the manufacturer or vendor.
summary: A Great, Take Anywhere Power Bank...

reviewText: A power bank is essentially a portable battery charger. You charge the power bank and take it with you to charge your mobile devices when their battery power runs low.  This is especially handy for the times you're on the go & don't have access to a power source to charge your mobile device.The Sendy 5200mAh Power Bank  comes with a carrying pouch, a short USB charging cable & 4 connector tips (Micro USB, Apple 30pin for Iphone4/IPod Touch4G, Mini USB, & PSP).  4 LED lights light up according to how much charge remains in the power bank. The Sendy Power Bank also has a bright  LED flashlight. I like the sleek, attractive design of this Power Bank.It measures approx. 3 3/4" x 1 3/4" X 3/4", is easy for me to hold & feels good in my hands.Be sure to charge the Sendy up to full power when you receive it. It took me about 4 hours to charge the power bank using the included USB charging cable & my laptop.  The Power Bank can be charged even faster by using a USB AC adapter. The Sendy Power Bank will charge most digital devices with a DC5V input. Pressing the on/off button once, activates 4 blue LED lights which light up according to the remaining power. Pressing the on/off button twice turns on/off the LED flashlight, which is surprisingly bright. I really like having a flashlight available to me for emergencies.>>>  Features from the included manual/flyer:~High-tech, high efficiency battery cells with protection board. Long battery life cycle of over 500 times.~With smart power management controller, the maximum power conversion efficiency is more than 88%.~Allows the Power Bank to charge digital devices simultaneously while the power bank is being charged. (NOTE: this did not prove true for me. I was unable to charge my devices at the same time I was charging the power bank)~Double protection design: One protects battery board, the other is a charging system that protects against over charge, over voltage, over current & short circuit.~Intelligent LED to indicate the charging status & power levels.~Ideal for most digital devices with DC5V input, such as iPhone, iPad, Smart Phone, PSP, Kindle Fire HD, Google NExus 7, MP4, GPS, Tap PC, etc.Operating Temperature: 0 to 35C ... 32F to 95FOperating Moisture: 5-95%RHStorage Temperature: -10 to 60C ... 14F to 140F  <<<<My IPod Touch 4G battery was at approximately 10% power. I couldn't use it unless I charged it up a little. I used the Sendy Power Bank with its included USB cable & Apple connector to charge my IPod. It didn't take long before I was able to use my IPod at the same time the Sendy Power Bank was charging it. My fully charged IPod used 25% of the power bank's power (one blue LED went out). My Kindle Fire HD was at 26% power so I decided to use the power bank's remaining power to charge it. However, KF HD charged up to 60% before the power bank needed to be recharged. I was not able to charge the power bank and charge my KF HD at the same time so I disconnected my Fire & continued charging the power bank. I am going to run the battery down on my Fire then charge it with the Sendy Power Bank, and update my review with the results. The Sendy Power Bank got warm/not hot while charging my Fire, but did not get warm while charging my IPod Touch.This is a very handy device...I love its sleek look, the bright flashlight and most of all, I love being able to charge my devices on the go.I was provided a sample for an honest, unbiased review.
summary: Sleek, attractive design, bright LED flashlight...and charges your devices!  4 1/2 stars

reviewText: The Sendy charger is a nice small form factor that offers a punch.The other reviewers have done an excellent job of laying out all of the pluses and minuses of this product.For me the reason I like this device comes down to size.  It is small enough to carry in your pocket.  The tips that come with it are perfect.  I only have one device that can not be charged by this unit.  ipad4.It offers a flashlight which gives off enough light to help you find things in your travel bag.It charges fast using the provided mini plug to usb.I am now taking this with me for the purpose of keeping my Nokia 920 charged when on the road.  I really like the charging from usb as I can charge it in the vehicle in between usage.I could of course charge my phone in the vehicle but it far easier to charge just this one little device for those times when I am away from power for extended periods of time.The charger is very well made.  Tight seams and solid construction.For me once again the main selling point for this device is the very small size.  It works great in a small case that has a tablet and phone in it.I was provided with a free sample of this product with the understanding that I would write an honest review.
summary: Fair price and good performance mean this is worth your money.

reviewText: The Bolse 3.1A 15W dual USB port AC charger is an ally in the battle against power-depleted mobile devices.Note that that the two USB ports are NOT identical. One is a 2.1A port and one is 1.0A port. Devices requiring the higher 2.1A rate will charge on the 1.A port, but at a slower rate.The prongs fold in for easy storage in a travel bag.This model is available in both black and white.Note: This item was provided for review purposes.
summary: Toss in your travel bag with USB cables for your depleted devices...

reviewText: This compact USB wall adapter is great for charging both my iPhone 4s and my iPad Mini at the same time. It just a little more than twice the size of the small square wall adapter that comes with Apple devices. If you put two of the tiny square wall plugs together, you get the size of this Bolse Dual USB wall adapter. It's even the same depth as the Apple adapters.The metal prongs that plug into the wall outlet can fold into the adapter, for an even more compact shape while not in use. This is a handy feature for use when traveling, so that the prongs don't get bent out of shape in your luggage. There are two USB ports on it, and while one is meant for larger devices like tablets, my iPad Mini charges fine from either port. There is a small blue LED light that glows to let you know when it's plugged in and is powered. It's available in both white and black colors, so you can even get one to match the color of your devices.This charging adapter's compact size makes it great for travel, and dual USB ports lets you charge more than one device at a time. It works not only with my Apple devices, but also my daughter's Kindle Fire, my husband's Casio non-smartphone (that has a USB charging cable) and works with my son's Sony PSP. Anything you need to charge with a USB changing cable, this adapter can handle.A sample product was provided for reviewing purposes.
summary: Compact USB wall adapter that works great with iPhone and iPad Mini

reviewText: With all the devices I own, I can never have too many USB wall chargers, although I'm limited, of course, by the number of available outlets.  Hotels, in particular, are stingy with open outlets.  This Bolse high output charger solves part of this problem by having two USB ports, a 1.0 A port and a 2.1 A port for more power-hungry devices.  This means that I can charge my iPhone and my iPad out of the same outlet plug and at the same time.  Because the plug is not polarized, I can plug in one of these with the ports pointing down and another with them pointing up to enable charging four devices out of a standard two-plug outlet: iPhone, iPad, camera, and Kindle, for example.The prongs fold into the body for a sleek travel shape; however, the moveable prongs also mean that sometimes I fold the prongs into the body when I'm trying to plug them into an outlet.  Not a big deal for me.  The body is a glossy white or a glossy black plastic and feels extremely sturdy.  It handles 100-240 volts AC current, so it can be used in many different countries as long as I have a travel adapter. (No power converter necessary, only the adapter.)  A blue light illuminates when power is flowing through the charger so I can tell easily if I haven't plugged it in all the way, something that's extremely important when I'm also using an international adapter.  The charger measures 2 6/8" long by 1 1/4" wide by 1 1/4" deep (without prongs extended), making it extremely portable.This device is a must-have for frequent travelers like me; however, it is also useful in the home or to take to the office.  Note:  The manufacturer sent a sample for review.-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann
summary: Well-Constructed USB Charger

reviewText: I'm a real fan of little gizmos that come in handy when I least expect it.  This Bolse Dual USB Wll/Travel/AC Charger is one of those.  I was actually looking for one the other day to charge a battery pack that needed one and claimed it wasn't included.  This is a very reasonably priced charger and is perfect to keep in a suitcase or glove compartment.  One nice thing is that the prongs on the plug can be turned down and lay flush with the unit.  The box it came is an excellent case so to speak, but even putting it in a Ziplock bag will keep the ports from collecting any debris.The dual port makes it easy to charge two devices at the same time if you have to.  I also like the fact that the small LED light on the face lets me know it's properly charging.  This is definitely a versatile, functional product that is well worth investing in, especially if you travel frequently.  This is one little gizmo that I really do like and will be using frequently.WHICH PORT DO I USE?~  2.1A for iPad, iPhone, and Samsung Galaxy Tab~  1.0A for all other devicesSPECS:~  Input:  AC 100 - 240V, 50 - 60HZ~  Output  DC 5V 2.1A (Max)DC 5V 1.0A (Max)~  Dimensions  70 x 35.6 x 32mm (2.75 x 1.40 x 1.25 in.)~  Weight  56g (0.123459 lb.)~  Charging Time2 - 3 hours for iPhone/iPad5 - 6 hours for iPad~  Warranty - 12 months from purchaseSample provided for review purposes.
summary: This is an excellent dual port AC charger that is perfect for travel ...

reviewText: This compact dual USB charger does a nice job of charging two devices at once using your USB charging cables. It has an indicator light to show that it is plugged in and the plugs fold into recesses for easy storage.The USB ports are on the ends which makes it slightly less convenient to attach but if you are putting them on a wall plug and you want the USB cables to hang downward and more out of the way, this is a great unit for that.The finish is sleek, smooth and nicely made.I was provided a unit for evaluation and an honest review.
summary: Very Nice Finish, Quality Made Product

reviewText: This charger worked great for me. I charged my Kindle Fire HD & my LG Cosmos phone at the same time.I really appreciate the three, over-charging, over-current & over-heating, built-in protections. The flip down AC prongs make this charger much easier to carry around.This charger can be used for traveling too because it has an AC 11-240 150mA 50 - 60 Hz input.  You will need to purchase a plug adapter though. Check the voltagevalet dot com electricity guide to see what type of plug adapter you will need.Amazon's Product Description is very thorough, so I won't repeat it. But, please take note that this charger is not compatible with HP TouchPad, Asus transformer, Motorola Xoom or Blackberry Playbook.This charger is available in either white or black.I was provided a sample for an unbiased, honest review.One year limited warranty
summary: Over-heating, over-charging & over-current protection built in...

reviewText: This Bolse 3.1 A dual USB port AC charger has a beautiful and very compact design. It is available in black or white and they are both very sturdy and well-made.The prongs are non-polarized so it can be used in either orientation and they fold back into the body of the charger for convenience when traveling. There is a little notch at the base of each prong that makes it so simple to unfold them--this is a sometimes over-looked feature I really appreciate.The blue LED glows when it it is plugged into a live electrical socket. It doesn't get warm when used to charge small devices like an mp3 player but may get warm with a tablet. It is compatible with most devices that charge through a USB port but there are some it won't work with so check the product description.This charger recognizes the special technical protocols for Apple products and has two ports, one specifically for Apple devices and one for non-Apple devices, clearly labeled 2.1 A and 1.0 A, respectively The USB slots are close together but all of my USB cable heads are slim enough to use both slots at the same time. However, the maximum capacity of 3.1 A is then divided between the two and for some larger devices, charging time will roughly double.The size is compact enough that two chargers can be used in a standard double wall outlet: it measures roughly 2 5/8 in. x 1 3/8 in. x 1 1/4 in. deep.To get the best use from any USB charger, it is important to understand the requirements of each device and its battery. Manufacturers provide this information; Apple's website, for instance, provides a full page of information about each device's battery. iPad batteries should be completely discharged and then fully recharged monthly, while iPod batteries don't need to be cycled. Some electronics should be turned off or put in sleep mode for charging under certain circumstances. It definitely is worth the time to learn about these requirements.A sample was provided for unbiased review.
summary: Compact USB wall charger

reviewText: Tiny, compact and a simply designed white AC wall charger, this 2-1/8 oz. folding wall plug is a great home or travel accessory (rated to operate at 100 - 240 VAC and 50-60 HZ). When plugged in, a small blue LED light lights up. The two USB ports are 2.1 Amps and 1 Amp. You can charge two electronic devices at the same time such as your iPhone, iPad, iPod, GPS, Tablets, Samsung Galaxy Tab Series, Amazon Kindle Fire, other Kindles, etc. (using the 2.1 Amp port) and also the same devices (at a slower charge rate) using the 1.0 Amp port. Note that this does not charge HP Touch pads, ASUS transformers, Motorola Xoom or Blackberry Playbook.The compact size and the charging range is a real seller for me, particularly since it works overseas. There is also a protective feature that prevents overheating or overcharging. For the price, this is a no-brainer for double charging (wall socket charging is usually faster than USB charging). Product generously supplied by manufacturer for an honest review.
summary: Home Or Overseas - Double Charging!

reviewText: This is a beautiful compact charger with retractable prongs.  It came in an environmentally friendly recycled box.  Rated to work at 100 to 240v range,  you can bring it in your travels to other countries that use different voltages.There are two USB slots and each one is clearly labeled - 2.1A and 1.0A for a total of 3.1A.  Simultaneous charging works.Works great with my iPads, phones, Kindle and USB bedside reading light. The blue LED also serves as a gentle night light.I was provided a sample of this product, so I could use it and write my unbiased review.
summary: Impressive little USB wall charger

reviewText: This works pretty much the same as other USB travel chargers I own. There is a 1.0A port for non-Apple products and a 2.1A port for Apple products (other chargers label these ports N/A and A). Using the wrong port won't harm your device, but may result in a slower charging time. The plugs fold in easily for travel, and a blue light goes on when this is plugged in to indicate power.All my other wall USB chargers (three different kinds) have the ports facing out when plugged into an AC outlet. But this charger has the ports on the bottom (right below the blue light in the picture on Amazon). So why does this matter? Here's one example. The last time I stayed in a hotel room, the most convenient outlet had a digital clock plugged into the top opening, leaving only the bottom opening free. With the charger I brought it didn't matter because the ports faced outward whether it was plugged into the top or bottom. But with this charger my ports would have been facing the floor. Just not as convenient. Of course I could have switched the opening where the digital radio was plugged in, but then I would have had to reset it (been there, done that)Everyone's needs are different, so the port location on the bottom may not matter to you, but for me means that this is not a charger that I will bring when I travel. I received this at no cost from the manufacturer in exchange for writing a review.
summary: I wish the ports were not on the bottom

reviewText: This is a great little charger.  I actually replaced my Bolse charger with this one.  It's quiet with no buzzing noise and no LED indicator.  For me it's a change that I like.  I think for some other people, they may want an LED indicator which I think as a product should have it to actually show that it's working.  But like I said, I personally like it without it.As far as charging goes on the 1.0 amp, it's ok.  I think it charges as what it should charge.  The 2.1 amp works really well.  I was able to charge a Samsung S4 in less than 2 hours which was nice.  The size is nice.  It doesn't take up much space but I would have preferred if they made the charger flatter to the wall.  It sticks out too much and doesn't look to nice aesthetically pleasing but this is suppose to be a travel size so it's fine as that purpose.  As a home wall charger, I personally would have designed it flatter and have the charge ports on the side rather than straight on.I received this item for an honest review.
summary: Nice litter charger.

reviewText: I must admit I seem to now have USB chargers in every single room of my house! From my husband's Scanner, to my iPad (which also acts as my alarm clock), my iPhone, my husband's iPad, my granddaughter's iPod touch, cameras, and various assorted devices, these are important to me.There are two important things to look for in these. The first is power - this charger effectively has sufficient power to charge BOTH a 2.1A and 1.0A device concurrently. Note that many devices will do so but at a slower pace, so this meets that particular goal.The second thing to watch for is that the device does not overheat or overcharge your device. The UL certification on this along with the fact that charging stops when the battery is full puts this particular charger into the "high end" charger that allows you to not worry about your device overcharging.I am not certain if it is a good thing that it doesn't have an LED light to help me find it in the dark, but if I am using it in the bedroom, it seems that there are already too many "little lights" that glow, so it would be a good thing.I notice someone else mentioned that it "covers" a second outlet. After much frustration, I now use strictly side facing surge protectors (Belkin has many that work this way) which permit my larger electronic chargers to set properly without interfering with others. Since this device is narrow, it does not block any of the other outlets in my surge protector.I was offered a complimentary sample of this in order to test it out and consider a review, and I am happy to report that it has met all of my high standards for a USB charger.
summary: I'm using for iPad 2 and iPhone 5S - charges both

reviewText: It seems like everything that comes into the house now needs a USB port to power or charge it, so always on the lookout for good solutions. This is one of the smallest units I have ever come across, and it makes it easy to carry (and get carried off).=== The Good Stuff ===* The unit is compact. It measures 1 13/16" x 2 1/4" x 1 1/8", and weighs 2.4 ounces. It easily fits in a pocket, and I can pretty much palm the whole thing in my hand. It accepts 100-240V, 50/60Hz, so ideal for travel, and the plug folds into he unit making it a nice cubic shape. There are no LEDs, and there are two power ports rated at 1.0 and 2.1A.* There are no rough edges to the plastic, and the corners are nicely rounded. There is a little bit of a gap between the seams, but nothing major.* I was able to charge an iPhone4 and iPad3, and charging times seemed comparable to what I get with an Apple supplied charger. I charged both units at the same time, but didn't check to see if the total charge time slowed down.=== The Not-So-Good Stuff ===* The markings identifying the capacity of the power ports can be a little hard to read, especially in dim light.* As with all fold-in plugs, these are a likely first failure point. There is a cost for the convenience of not impaling yourself with the plug when you dig in your bag.=== Summary ===For a small form factor charger, I like it. It is easy to grab it and throw it in your pocket. The unit ships with instructions and a warranty card, but no USB cables. All in all, a nice little charger that comes in handy.
summary: Neat Little Charger

reviewText: This is one of the more compact wall adapters I've used, which makes it great for traveling. It fits inside my laptop case very easily in one of the internal pockets. It's only about 2 inches square and about 1.25 inches thick. The wall plugs fold up to keep it compact.The case is decently made. The edges are rounded, which looks and feels nice. The seam is a bit pronounced, but it's strictly an aesthetic issue - the two halves of the case are solidly attached. The ports are well anchored with no wriggling when inserting or removing the USB cables. There are two output ports - 2.1A and 1A - with each clearly labeled.One of the things I like about this is something it lacks - a power indicator. Those are kind of useless to have on the adapter since the device you're charging has an indicator that shows it is being charged. Having a bright indicator on the plug is just annoying, especially at night. This doesn't have one, which is perfect!No problems with operation - charged everything I plugged into it (various phones and tablets) without a problem.
