This has in no way changed my opinion on the product.Pros:Sleek lookBlack on white looks greatClear displayEasy setupEasy configuration (time)Clear speaker and microphoneCons:No adjustable wrist.Being a guy, I actually have small wrists. I was able to put this on and wear it around without any issues but it was snug. If this had an adjustable strap or something similar, I could have rated this at a 5000000000/5! I love feeling like a sleek undercover super spy!
summary: Sleek look, I feel like Bond...

reviewText: This bluetooth bracelet works as advertised. It keeps time nicely and I love the alarm clock. It allows me to answer phone calls without touching my phone.Also, this bluetooth bracelet wristwatch looks cool.Wristwatch provided by OXA.
summary: Cool wristwatch

reviewText: *Disclosure: I was contacted by a representative for OXA and given a sample of this product specifically for the purpose of giving my thoughts on it.*Let me start this off by saying that I was very concerned about what follows.  Looking at all the glowing reviews this item has, I figured I must have gotten a broken one or something.  Contacting OXA however revealed that no, the watch that was sent to me was not broken, it was functioning just as it was supposed to.  That bites.  I was really excited about getting this product, I wanted it to be great.  I understood it wasn't in the same class as myPebble Smartwatch), and that was ok. I do my best to be honest in my reviews and report only what I know to be true. Given how different my experience was with this watch, which is backed up by the company that makes it, I'm eyeing those positive reviews and reviewers very suspiciously.  Also related in my communication with OXA  is that they are committed to improving their products and have a new version on the way. It's a few weeks out from the time of this writing.  The new version will have the features this one was supposed to have but doesn't.  Nor will this version be upgradeable to the get those features.The construction itself feels good.  It's a solid bit of plastic, that's for sure.  The two buttons on the side are set nicely, not detracting from the look of the watch but also not being a pain in the rear to get at and use when needed.  The charging manner is, well, really goofy.  A custom two prong affair with a binder clip like thing to hold the prongs to the watch.  Ok, really, I think I've seen middle school kids knock up something better for their science fair projects.  Break that clip, lose that cable, and good luck getting it replaced.  The speaker are weak, but I'll get to that later.  The screen, which doesn't stay on full time so as to save battery life, is dim.  OLED is may be, but its hard to see even in the shade.  Taking it into sunlight and it's unreadable.For testing, I used two different phones.  An HTC EVO 4G LTE, and an HTC One.  The results of my testing were the same regardless of which one I used.  Both phones work just fine with other Bluetooth devices, including headsets, speakers, speakerphones, and in-car hands-free calling systems.  I thought at first maybe there was a difference between using an iPhone vs an Android phone.  But no, OXA didn't specify that it worked with one better than the other when I contacted them.  Directions were followed exactly according to the included manual.  Pairing up wasn't at all difficult, and worked consistently.  According the the ad here, the watch has an "Alarm clock reminder" function.  Yeah, no.  The watch tells time (military time/24HR clock only), acts like a minimal hands-free calling device, can play music/sound from your phone, but that's about it.  The "display the number of incoming calls while receiving a call or receiving a message" isn't there either.  (Next version, says OXA.)  When calls or messages come in, the bracelet shows the volume level it's set to, and that's it.Speaking of sound, now seems to be a good time to talk about that.  The watch has an independent volume setting from your phone, which, if done right, isn't a bad thing.  It's not done right.  The bracelet is 100% dependant on the volume setting on your phone for everything, which is common with many Bluetooth speakers.  But when it comes to headsets and hands-free devices, this isn't the case.  Say you want this watch to be what emits a ringtone when you get message, as well as vibrate.  It can do this, but only if the volume on your phone is also turned up.  If your phone is on vibrate or silent, the bracelet sits there like a lump.  If you have a short ringtone, the sound is cut off at the beginning.  When you're playing a game on your phone, the bracelet acts as a second speaker.  When playing music, or any type of media, the bracelet will again act as a second speaker.  The only way to get the bracelet to not to do the second speaker trick is to turn its volume all the way down and then hope to remember to turn it back up again so you can hear notifications.  It will not act as the only speaker for any media playback.Doing calls is a shaking activity.  If you sit real still, there is no breeze or background noise, have the call volume on the phone set just right, have the bracelet's volume set just right, you can have a good clear call.  Change any one of those variables and the call quality plummets.  Using it while driving?  Probably not.  Using it for a conference call?  Unlikely.To summarize, this watch doesn't meet it's own description of functions.  I wasn't expecting that it could do everything my Pebble does or that Galaxy Gear can.  But I did expect it to meet its claims, and it doesn't.  To add insult to injury, the features it does have are half baked and rigged to the point of making it more of a pain to use than anything else.  Other OXA products I've gotten have been pretty good quality stuff, so this was an unexpected disappointment and I do hope that the new version is a whole lot better.
summary: Save yourself some time

reviewText: Remember years ago when the Dick Tracy comics were in every Sunday paper and one of his many miraculous gimmicks was a wristwatch used as a telephone? Well, welcome to the future. This handsome bracelet can be paired with your mobile phone to vibrate when you have a call, display the callers ID, decide whether or not you wish to answer your phone while driving, even alerting you as to multiple calls coming in so that you can preferentially select which one you wish to answer. And it can even produce music pod castsAnother feature is an alarm clock and a time display in digital numbers easy to read in the dark. The only problem is the rigidity of the bracelet means it is a bit difficult to place on the wrist for men with large arms. Likely that will be addressed soon. For now it is a smart looking well behaved device that is very easy to install and is backed by OXAs usual fine service and guarantee. Grady Harp, March 14
summary: Dick Tracy is here!

reviewText: This OXA bluetooth wristwatch is so much fun and it works great, too. I have the problem of not always hearing my phone ring from inside my purse, but with this watch on, I never miss a call. It's sleek and stylish and helps me stay connected no matter where I am or what I'm doing.
summary: Feel Like a Spy

reviewText: I hate giving low ratings, but in the case of the review sample I received this bluetooth bracelet is not quite ready for prime time.  I'll get the issues out of the way first.The biggest thing I dislike is the clamp style charging cable. It takes some adroit maneuvering to correctly connect it. You are rewarded with a brief indication on the display when you do have the pins lined up, but to be honest, I get it about fifty percent of the time, and fumble in frustration the other fifty percent of my attempts. A micro USB port on the underside of this bracelet would eliminate one of my two biggest complaints.My other peeve is pairing and connecting. After I finally paired it successfully with my Galaxy Note 3 I went through the same drill with an iPad 2. Even if you follow the directions to a T you need to be lucky with the time when you 'lightly press' the B button. Speaking of which, perhaps a small middle button specifically for pairing would solve that issue. Or, if there is enough remaining electronic real estate on the circuit board, employ the newer style bluetooth that makes itself known to scanning devices automatically. There are a number of speakers on the market that do just that and it's a dream come true, especially for novices.As for the military time display, it is not a problem for me since I am a retired officer, but I can certainly understand complaints about that as a limitation. This would be a lot more appealing if it used twelve hour AM/PM format.The speaker itself is sufficiently loud and clear for phone calls and streaming music into your personal space. I made and received a few test calls and had no issues whatsoever. Music sounds adequate if you love having something in the background. It isn't designed for critical listening and does not claim to be.I've owned and reviewed other OXA products and love their quality. I have no doubt that their development team will take note of the criticisms and correct them in the next version. However, for now this bluetooth bracelet is a great idea that needs some refinement before it becomes the five star product that it has the potential to be.
summary: Not quite ready

reviewText: For those of us that are constantly on our phones, having options is the key, especially when those relate to charging and talking on the phone. I use my phone so much that I have to charge it a minimum of twice per day and normally three times. So, I often have my phone connected to a charger or at a docking station, which limits me by anchoring me to a place unless I have it attached to an external battery (which I then can move around). With this wearable wristwatch I am able to leave the phone charging in the dock and walk around the house or office and still be able to talk. This is a great feature.The wristwatch is a white hard plastic band with an black LED large display. The rest is made out of a white plastic that is not adjustable.➤IN THE BOX. The box contains the wristwatch and the charger. It also has a semi-useful manual (pretty badly written). The first thing I do when I try  new electronics is to try an use it without reading the instructions. Well, this one proved a little challenging with the pairing and I had to read the instructions to pair the device. This is when I realized a non-English speaker (or Google Translate) wrote the instructions and groaned since I want to "achieve the best using effect..." (Better wording please.) Unreadable or badly written user manuals have become an issue with so many products coming out of the country and it is often frustrating to be unable to find answers to your questions.➤PAIRING. As I mentioned above, I had a few issues pairing. After reading the manual, I was able to pair easily. So, that was user error on my part. Although, I would not make the pairing button the same as the Power button.➤WHAT YOU CAN DO WITH THE WRISTWATCH. Well, you can answer calls, talk as if in speaker mode, listen to music and...that's it. I use it to talk on the phone while I have the phone charging and for music.➤WHAT YOU CAN NOT DO WITH THE WRISTWATCH. You cannot read text messages or get notifications. You cannot activate Siri either. Names do not show up in the watch, just numbers.➤CALL SOUND QUALITY. I was pleased with the sound quality. Every single one of the people I called agreed that I was easy to understand and that there were no issues with sound quality. No skipping, no low volume. It was all good.➤SPEAKER SOUND QUALITY. The speaker sound quality is ok. This is not supposed to be a speaker system, so do not expect excellent sound quality, it does not have it. But, it does have good enough sound to offer clear call quality and sound. I listened to some music and audiobooks through this and whilst not ideal, it is ok if it is the only thing you have➤THE CONS.➤➤THE WATCH ONLY DISPLAYS MILITARY TIME. The wristwatch comes with a ... well, an LED watch. Duh! This is great...if I was able to change it to 12 hour based time, instead of military time. To date, I have not been able to change out of military time. It does not seem to be an option. If I am mistaken and you can change it to 12h based system, please let me know. I would love to change this.➤➤IT IS NOT ADJUSTABLE. I have seen some reviews where the band is snug and other where it is too big. Well, I may have small wrists (I thought they were pretty average) but this dances a lot on my wrist. The best thing to do for this item is to make it adjustable.➤➤NO NAMED CALLER ID. DOES NOT SYNC WITH ADDRESS BOOK. I thought that the wristwatch was going to display the name of the contact on the display, as it advertises. It does not do that. It only shows the phone number they are calling from. If anyone knows whether you can change it so that it displays contact's name, please let me know.➤➤DIM DISPLAY. The display is very dim.➤➤SMALL FONT IN DISPLAY. For such a large display, the size of the font seems quite ironic. It is very small. Nothing like the item picture here. The phone number displayed is more like size 8 font.This is a great idea and a very useful item. It needs a few adjustments to be much much better.*Sample received for review.
summary: Excellent idea, but a few drawbacks, military time only

reviewText: I have always wanted to wear my phone on my wrist. Finally, there's a way to do it. I've found the Oxa Bluetooth watch useful when driving or when going someplace noisy where I can't hear my phone in my purse. It's good for any time holding a phone in my hand is not convenient.FORM FACTORMy wrist is small. This Bluetooth bracelet is not adjustable. I have to wear it higher up my arm to keep it still.The watch face is large and clunky, which is deceptive, because the digital display does not fill the screen. It's very small. In fact, I still can't tell what one of the icons is supposed to be.I can read the time (military time, we have no choice), but only if it is indoor lighting. Dimmer light is better. It's impossible to read outdoors, even in the shade.The watch charges with a proprietary cord that is very sensitive to being moved. I prefer the more universal micro USB cord. If I lose the charging cable, I would no longer be able to use my watch.BLUETOOTHIt was easy to pair with my iPhone 4S. Reconnection is automatic when I turn on the watch. Range is excellent. It is better than any other Bluetooth device that I own, which is a lot. When I go out of range, my watch vibrates to let me know a connection has been lost. If I come back within a short period (minutes), it will reconnect. If not, nothing happens.This watch is supposed to search for a signal every ten minutes. Not true.SOUNDIf you want to listen to music on your wrist, it's just okay. I don't think it was made for that. We get that small speaker quality.If you want to make and take calls, it's much better. My daughter helps me with a lot of my Bluetooth speakers, most of which have failed in the phone call department. This is the first one where the first words out of her mouth were, "I love it!"I have to say, I can hear her and every other caller just fine on this watch. They come in loud and clear. No one ever asks me to repeat myself, either. I went and tried it out as a caller and found that there is a slight echo when I talk, but it's not bad enough to prevent a conversation.The one thing I would like for phone calls is a way to set the ring on vibrate. In fact, I'd like to be able to set the watch to vibrate only for texts and everything else. As it is, it will vibrate and ring for phone calls, and I get whatever tone the phone plays for messages.I'd like the texts to show on the face of the watch. Maybe they do. Most of the time, I'm in a place that's too bright for me to read the display.OVERALL IMPRESSIONI like the whole concept, and I like that the phone calls come in so clearly. I like being able to hold a conversation and I like the anti-theft or loss feature that vibrates when the phone is too far. I just wish the watch was smaller and the display was brighter and larger.This product was provided for review by Oxa.
summary: Good for Calls On the Go

reviewText: Have several OXA items and have found that they have excellent products and customer service. The OXA products we have used have been very effective and reliable, but this Bluetooth Wristwatch seems to have so much more potential than found in its current form. It is futuristic looking, keeps good time (military format) and plays music nicely over its speaker, but there are a couple drawbacks that need to be overcome for this product to really take off.To start -- pairing the wristwatch with our mobile phones was easy to do, and the contact list sharing made it so that inbound calls show the name and number of the caller on the wristwatch's display. That is a nice touch.However, the wristwatch has a very small wrist opening for the American market, and it is made of hard plastic that does not flex, bend or give in any way when trying to get it on. The youngest person we asked to try it on was able to get it on his wrist, but nobody over the age of 12 years old could comfortably get the watch onto their wrist. Those adults that were able to get the watch on found it to be less comfortable than desired, actually restrictively tight, because the plastic is so hard and the band so small.  If this could be made with softer, flexible rubber it would receive much stronger reviews.If you would like to see pictures I took of it, please navigate to the wristwatch's main sales page, scroll down to where the "Most Helpful Customer Reviews" section starts, and look to the right of that area for the "Product Images From Customers" section. Tried my best to take pictures that do justice to this nice case, but it is hard to take pictures of black items using regular indoor lighting. Cool looking futuristic wristwatch.In the Amazon listing, OXA states that the "Max circumference 6.5 inches, more suitable for girl's wrist". I think that OXA is trying to convey that it is best for young children with small wrists, and I agree with that. However, if marketing to young kids or to young girls, they might try colors like pink, green, yellow, purple, blue. etc... instead of just black or white. Our skinny teenager has a 7 inch wrist circumference and it wasn't comfortable for him to put on easily or wear.The charging device is very odd, hard to use and difficult to fit. A redesign using micro USB port on one end would seem a good idea here. Not sure if we ever got it fully charged.The biggest challenge for us was the one-way Bluetooth communication. The wrist watch plays music from your Bluetooth source device very well, and it does a good job as a speaker phone for inbound calls, but it does not have a two-way Bluetooth connection and is unable to initiate outbound calls or outbound voice-texts. To use with outbound calls you have to make the call from your phone and then 'transfer' the call to the wristwatch.  Two-way functionality would have made this a big hit even if the fit wasn't optimal, and we have other items in this price range with two-way Bluetooth capabilities... so it can be done.The OXA wrist watch keeps time very well, and the display is easy to read. We very much like the idea of the Bluetooth wrist watch, and hope to see additional functionality in your future offerings.I did not find warranty information with the product packaging or on the Amazon listing, but the OXAUSA website states "Any items sold by OXA have 1 year guarantee. What's more, OXA will extend the warranty time for half a year." The extension is typically if you go to their Facebook page and like them there... If an issue arises before that period expires I will return here to update the review and let you know what the issue was and how resolution was handled. I did receive this unit gratis from the manufacturer, and have put it through the paces to objectively find out how well it performed. My statements here reflect that testing.If you are looking for a fun novelty for a person with a small wrist circumference, allowing them to stream music via Bluetooth, tell time, and take incoming calls, then this item may be exactly what you are looking for. If looking for a full function 'Dick Tracy' style two-way wristwatch communicator, this product is not there yet.Again, OXA has a great product line and excellent customer service, and I would not hesitate to purchase products from them in the future.
summary: OXA Bluetooth Wristwatch Bracelet - Keeps good military time - Easy to read - Plays music well - Small - Inbound calls only

reviewText: Overall this is a 5 star for the idea and the execution.  I like the idea that music/podcasts and phone calls can be made from this device. It has a good speaker as well as microphones built into it. While driving, it is awesome to have it on your hands so that you can easily hear podcasts. I use it for this purpose. The charging is very unique. There is a clip which you attach it at the right points and voila! it charges. Very unique.Overall works well for phone calls, audio music/podcasts. For pairing, press B button for around 7-10 seconds. SomOne e of the improvements I suggest for next version is having a even more brighter display (larger fonts also). I would also suggest a bigger font for manual. It was hard for me to read. I just scanned and used the pdf to read easily.The packaging is awesome and very well protected. Overall nice idea and works great for the purpose. The bracelet itself is very sturdy and excellent build quality. I was provided this product in exchange of a honest and fair review.
summary: Love the idea of wearable bracelet

reviewText: This is, by far, the coolest thing I own! It is sleek and has a futuristic look. I love wearing it and everyone comments on it! I cannot believe the technology, I can listen to the music from my phone, answer calls or simply check the time. It is so convenient to have. I love hands free talking and this device has clear sound! The instructions are good and the set up was easy, after reading the instructions. It has volume control, displays the time and has clear sound quality! I want another one for my daughter. The only down side is that it is not adjustable to wrist size, but should fit most. I received this product for a fair and honest review.
summary: Very James Bond!

reviewText: I come late to review this product. But after reading all reviews previously posted, I find that I do not have much to add as far as functionality and quality of the watch.The promo tends to hype its capabilities (but isn't that expected...for any product?) I did not expect a super watch equal to Samsung's or Sony's, but this device is pretty good for the price, and considering that it is first generation.I believe that severe negative evaluations should be mitigated and tempered by more realistic expectations.I used it with an IPhone S5, Samsung Note 3 and iPad; my experience was imilar to other reviewers and I was not disappointed.It makes a great conversation piece for adults and is a "cool" gadget for youths at a reasonable price.A complimentary sample was provided for review.
summary: Inspector Gadget would approve.

reviewText: Ah, Bluetooth; a wonderful way to connect wirelessly to a multitude of products. While convenient to use at home, I would hazard a guess that most people mainly use this medium to pair a headset with their cell phone(s). And, as technology has gotten better and better, the availability of devices is as varied not only in their design, but also their functionality. But the coolest part about all of this? We are getting closer and closer to what was once Sci-Fi gadgetry and are capable of having a communicator wristwatch just like James Bond!ConstructionThe OXA Bluetooth Wristwatch/Bracelet (henceforth referred to as "OXABW") is constructed of durable plastic materials that feel both solid and lightweight. The face of the bracelet/watch is on the top of the unit as the center section; the battery charging contacts are located on the back side of the face. The curved part that is below the center section (with the OXA logo painted in silver) houses the speaker, while the upper curved portion has the microphone. The undersides of both curved pieces have a thin rubber backing so that the bracelet is comfortable against your skin. Finally, on the right side of the face are two buttons that you use to pair/set the time/connect & disconnect calls, and basically control the bracelet's functions.In order to charge the unit, you must clamp the charger using a spring clip from the left side (if looking at the bracelet from above with the OXA logo at the bottom). This clip "bites" onto the bracelet and has two prongs that line up with the two contact ports on the underside of the center section (the "face"). The other end of the charging cord uses a standard male USB adapter that enables you to plug it into your computer and/or other device that has an open USB port.UsageFirst, please allow me to be clear: while a nifty device, this bracelet is not as advanced as the Samsung Galaxy Gear Watch. On a spectrum, the OXABW is on the lower end of the price/functionality spectrum. Now, that does not mean that the bracelet is useless! In fact, I was very impressed with the features that it DOES have. To test this bracelet, I paired it with two different devices: the first was my iPod Touch (4th gen), and the second was my Samsung Galaxy S2 smartphone. Each device presented a different experience from the OXABW. With both of these devices, I was able to quickly pair the bracelet with no issue.iPod TouchWith the iPod, while the bracelet was able to play music, I learned that it was not something that should be your primary speaker source. The sound quality was "okay", but streaming music non-stop quickly drained the battery. In addition, the only three things that I could do while playing music was adjust the volume with the two side buttons, set/check the time, and/or check the (rapidly depleting) battery level. I could not even advance to the next song on the playlist; I had to do that using the iPod itself. So while you can use this bracelet to listen to music, I recommend investing in a Bluetooth speaker dedicated to just that task.Samsung Galaxy S2While the functionality of the bracelet with my iPod was lackluster at best, the OXABW comes into its own when paired with a smartphone. In addition to being able to answer calls and speak with the other party through the bracelet (it functions as a speakerphone), it has other handy features that I found to be convenient. For example: once the bracelet is paired, it will vibrate to alert you that your phone is more than 10 meters away, thus acting as a "finder" of sorts. It is also smart enough to know that your phone is on vibrate, and will not make a sound when alerting you of an incoming call (the caller's phone number will display, with no spaces, on the face of the bracelet; you answer the phone call by clicking the lower button on the right side of the unit). Conversely, if you have your ringtone turned on, it will vibrate AND make a noise to alert you to a call. When it vibrates/chimes to indicate that you received a text message, it will mimic the sound that your phone makes. Finally, if you have an alarm set on your phone, the OXABW will also vibrate/sound to alert you that the time has reached the point you designated!OverallIn the end, I can attest that the bracelet is a fun gadget to have, even with its flaws. The easiest way to explain this is below:Pros1. The OLED interface is simple but easy to read; you can see the time, battery level, and phone icon (which indicates that your device is paired to your phone/music player) clearly.2. The bracelet vibrates to let you know that you are out of range/left your phone behind to prevent losing it.3. As long as you are not streaming music or talking for hours, the battery life is excellent.4. The call clarity is excellent through the speaker; when speaking to a friend using the microphone on the bracelet, he indicated that the sound quality was even better than my Plantronics Bluetooth headset.5. Is lightweight and only slightly bulky; you will want to wear it on the wrist opposite your writing hand; otherwise it is uncomfortable to rest against the table.Cons1. The prongs to charge the phone are very narrow in diameter; if you are not careful when you are clamping the charger clip over the bracelet, they look like they will snap easily.2. Since the bracelet only has two buttons, you have to remember the proper way to sync, set the time, answer a call, and once a call is answered how to pass it over to the phone (rather than speaking through the bracelet), and it takes a few times to get used to the procedures.3. If you have the OXABW paired to one device, and then decide to use it on another, you need to turn the bracelet completely off and then enter pairing mode in order to recognize the other device; if you have the old device nearby, sometimes it will still sync to that unit and not the new one, even if the new one is in discovery mode.4. The Caller ID only lists the phone number (smashed together with no spaces); it should also be able to list the name assigned to each number from my contact list. In addition, when it alerts you to receiving a text message, it would be nice if it either showed the name or phone number of the sender.5. The answer button is touchy; I have answered calls more than once and accidentally hung up without even realizing I had.6. The instruction book has been badly translated from Chinese and can be hard to follow; for example: one page says to hold down the "A" button for two seconds to transfer a call from the bracelet to the phone; the next page over says to hold the "A" button down for two seconds to disconnect.As I mentioned above, ultimately this is a neat little gadget to have, and is definitely more in my price range than many of the other Bluetooth devices out there. That being said, the features that the OXA Bluetooth Wristwatch has are the bare-minimum, and I find it hard to justify paying the full $50 for this. If the device were updated to include the actual name of the caller (from your contacts), as well as the ability to read your text messages from the phone, I could see paying the full price asked. For now, though, while fun in a geeky kind of way, I would wait until the next generation of this product and a few more features before you commit to buy it.**Disclaimer: This bracelet was sent to me by the manufacturer at no cost to review. While I do not feel that this influenced me in any capacity, I am legally obligated to disclose this fact so that you can come to your own conclusions about the merit of this analysis.**
summary: *holds wrist to lips* This is Bond, James Bond...

reviewText: The OXA Bluetooth Wristwatch is quite peculiar. First, it only displays time in military time,which can be very annoying. Next, it doesn't really display notifications for texts, applications, etc. Also, the watch is fairly large and can be a nuisance when trying to wear However, I like the inclusion of the speaker, which is ideal for making calls, and some of the software features are really helpful, including the lost phone alert. In the end, would I purchase this product again? No, but if you can overlook all of the downsides to this device, then it may be the one for you, especially considering its price.
summary: Fairly Good

reviewText: This really packs a punch. I took this to the pool last week and when you turn it up, you can really hear it from the far end of the pool - it wasn't loud but it was clear enough to hear what was playing.  I actually think that this has a much better sound than the 5300 speaker that I received even though this is smaller and has only 1 speaker vs 3 speakers.Connecting the speaker to my phone was very easy and didn't really require much thinking.  The life of the speaker lasted about 5.5 hours before I noticed that the speaker started beeping to indicate low battery. Charging it was quick too though - it took me less than 4 hours to charge it.  Sorry but I lost track of timing the actual charge time.  At any rate, great bluetooth speaker that is the size of your fist.  I actually take this to work now just so I can listen to my pandora on this.  I received this item for a honest review.
summary: Really loud for the size and great sound quality

reviewText: NOTE: I received a free product sample for review.I was surprised at the heft and sound quality (and loudness) of this speaker for its size. It also seems well built and looks attractive.I also really like the material on the bottom that keeps it from sliding around.The aux-in port with included cable is a big 'plus', as well as is the microSD slot.To charge, the unit uses a Mini-USB connection, not a Micro-USB one.The negatives are:* Terrible manual that is printed so small you really need a magnifying glass (unless you're Superman). I don't think I've ever seen a manual printed in smaller text. It was rather useless.* When there is a Bluetooth sound connection, I can hear a little background noise & interference, at least in part caused by the units own flashing blue LED lights... but the noise/static isn't so loud that most would consider a big issue, but it is there, unfortunately.I'm deducting 1/2 a star for the above negatives but overall I think this little speaker is pretty darn solid.Other:* When connected, there are two flashing blue LED lights on the bottom. You might like or not like these, but they can't be turned off. They do seem to contribute to some static/noise per the above negative.Overall 4.5 stars so I'm rounding up to 5.
summary: Pretty solid little device but...

reviewText: I was more than surprised to find that this speaker worked as well as it does. The bass is even wonderful, which REALLY surprised me. This speaker is probably 5x louder than my standard Macbook Pro. A wonderful addition, with a great battery life! Not only is it bluetooth, but you can just use it as a standard USB speaker too!
summary: Small Bundle, LOUD Sound

reviewText: This is a terrific little speaker. It delivers great sound for a small unit, and—without making a fool of myself attempting to explain the electronics—seems to do so rather effortlessly. I’m no tech genius, and I still was able to handle the initial connection in a snap and from that point on I was enjoying clear, solid sound.The speaker delivers a pretty full-bodied sound, creating a better bass end than I thought possible for such a small device. I mean, your coffee cup won’t vibrate off the table, but it’s still stronger than one would expect. The high end seems fine, and while some might niggle at the whether it could be a little richer at the low end, I thought the speaker offered a pretty commendable package.As to its design, I really like the minimalist, clean look the device has. It comes in five finishes (mine is black), and it is as economical an appearance as one could hope for. Smooth, small, and spare, yet still managing to be sleek and modern, the speaker has rubber pads on the bottom so that it will grip the surface upon which it is placed.  As I mentioned, setup was a breeze…the Bluetooth connection went quickly and easily, and the lithium battery took about three hours to fully charge (the cable is included). The speaker’s features are also streamlined—its controls are there, but they’re modest and out of the way: volume up, volume down and speakerphone. Likewise, the port for connecting it to a device (should you need to physically connect it) are equally easy to find, but tucked out of sight.About the only real problem I have at all is the set of directions: they are abysmally small and almost thoroughly unreadable…the print reminds me of those books one hears of that are printed on a grain of rice. Even then, what letters and words you can decipher are lost in a poorly translated gobbledygook. But it is all for naught: the speaker is so good that I think we can forgive it this fault (albeit richly deserved).NOTE: I was supplied this product free of charge with no other conditions other than my writing a fair and honest review -- which this is.
summary: The Sound Is Anything BUT Tiny

reviewText: This very attractive OXA Bluetooth Speaker paired with any device that I attempted with no problems pairing..Note that this speaker has Bluetooth capabilities as well as audio in out (with a cable included) so that you can plug it into your radio, CD player etc when you don't want to use Bluetooth and just need the speaker part.In addition, it also has a slot for a MICRO SD card (no SD card is included, just the slot for it). Since the manual is small, I am giving you helps here on how to use this should you buy this speaker.Also, I am able to leave my micro SD card in the speaker's slot, I use the MULTI MODE BUTTON to change the mode and also play from this speaker while it is charging.**This unit uses a MINI charger port meaning that any mini USB charger will fit into the port and charge up this speaker. Since I had an extra Motorola Mini USB Wall charger, I plugged this into my unit and it charges it well and it charges very quickly.PROS:+ MULTI MODES AND USES ETC FOR THIS SPEAKER - Bluetooth, Auxiliary and Micro SD Card:1) MP3 Player/SD card mode - To keep the SD card in the unit when it is turned on it will automatically see that there is a card in the unit and play music from the SD card. If you want Bluetooth instead just press and hold DOWN the Play Button, then the Bluetooth with turn on (you will see the blue lights flashing fast so you can then pair and connect without having to remove your SD card.2) Bluetooth Mode. If you Do Not have an SD CARD in the unit, when you turn on the speaker (on the bottom of the speaker) it automatically turns on the Bluetooth mode so you can pair. You will know this because the blue mini lights flash very fast.3) Auxiliary Mode (this is for your Audio cable to listen to a radio or CD Player etc). Step one: Plug in your in and out cable to the speaker and your CD player, radio, etc. You will need to press the Play (multi mode) button and hold it down. The speaker will realize that it has an audio cable in it so it will be ready to play in regular mode in the speaker (like a regular non Bluetooth type of speaker). This means that you can now play your radio or CD player etc through the speaker (make sure that you have the In and Out Cable (included with speaker) plugged into the speaker and the CD Player etc).4) + Charging - This Bluetooth speaker came with USB Charger cable and charged very quickly (less than 2 hours for a full charge).Charging suggestion - This unit comes with USB charger that you can plug in to a computer to charge the unit. However, since I always have micro USB chargers lying around the house, I used one of my micro chargers and plugged it into the wall to charge. It charged much faster that way. Also, most any brand of micro USB charger should work fine on this unit and it charges very quickly+ Pairing/Connecting - The speaker very quickly paired with my tablet, phone and MP3 player in just seconds!+ Sound Quality / Loudness /Adjusting the loudness- For a very small personal speaker, I found the sound clarity excellent and the sounds of high and low notes good to very good. In fact the sound of this tiny speaker is VERY LOUD better than I expected for such a very small speaker!On this speaker, there is a volume control.  *To up the volume hold down the + Key, to lower volume, hold down the - Key.5)To go to next song, quickly press the + key, or to go to previous song, quickly press the - key.+ Phone Reception - When I had my phone paired and I was listening to music, then my phone rang through the speakers, I was able to use this as a hands free speaker. Very clear reception.Very highly recommend this personal speaker as it plays loud, clear and treble and bass sound great for a portable speaker!
summary: Best Personal Bluetooth Speaker that I ever used! Loud and clear, plays from Micro SD card--Detailed Review!

reviewText: The design of the speaker is rather unique, it is a perfect blend between the standard round and square shape. The body is made of plastic, which keeps the weight down.The sound quality is great with ample bass and treble, even sounds good at higher volumes. For the small of the speaker it produces some room filling sound.There are other great features such as the phone function, Micro SD Card Slot, and AUX port. When making phone calls call the microphone makes good clean clips calls. The SD card slot is perfect when wanting to play music from a storage card. Also, there is an AUX input for a wired connection, which increases battery life.I was supplied a sample for the purpose of review.
summary: Great Bluetooth Speaker

reviewText: My family and I find ourselves gathered around the iPad quite a bit these days. Mostly it's to watch a funny video, like a baby rollerskating, etc. Recently, however, my kids have started making crazy rubberband bracelets, and they work together at the kitchen table following these youtube videos. This speaker has been great to allow them to pump up the volume a little bit higher so they all can hear the steps required for their latest creations. My wife and I also use this to pump some Pandora piano music into our bedroom when we want to escape a bit. Although the instructions for this little wonder were poor, I've paired enough of these things to figure it out on my own. The sound quality is nice and clear, and pleasantly good for such a small and inexpensive unit.
summary: Makes it easier for my family to gather around!

reviewText: This the cutest little wireless speaker that I've seen in a long time:  It has a nice saucy little shape, the finish is shiny and pleasant to look at.  The screen is nicely fitted and flat.  It has just the right weight, angled out at the bottom for a lower center of gravity, and it's got a nice circle of rubbery grab pad on the bottom.  This little gem of a speaker is not going to hop around on the counter top, and won't be easily knocked over.  The shiny coating over the color resists scratches, too.But those are all secondary features compared to its sound.  And it sounds great:  Nice balance of bass and treble, sound is deep and lush for its one tiny speaker.Volume can be controlled from the speaker itself.  You can answer the phone, pause, go forward and backward from the speaker, too.I got 35 feet blue tooth connectivity before it started to skip and blank out.  I got about 10 more feet if I positioned it just right.  And for such big sound it kept playing for the 5 hours that OXA claims on this product page.Be aware that the USB port is mini, not micro.  I have a lot of micro USB cables laying around, but very few with mini plug ends.  So I've had to mark this one as special to this speaker.I almost knocked it down a star because of the horrible tiny instruction "booklet"  It is a good thing that I've had previous experience with several blue tooth speakers, because I could not rely on the instructions in this "booklet" because I could not read them:  Such tiny type that--even with my magnifying glass and a high-powered desk lamp--I could not decipher the words.*I received a sample product from OXA.
summary: Big, full sound in a tiny, tidy package

reviewText: I have owned perhaps five or six similar mini-speakers in this price range, both bluetooth and non-bluetooth, and this one blows them all away.  Even at the highest volume, the sound is rich with very little distortion.  And it's worth noting that this speaker achieves a volume that is not possible with my other speakers, even WITH their distortion.Let me get the negatives out of the way before I move on.  Other reviews mentioned the tiny font on the instruction manual.  I suppose they're better off than me, because my speaker had NO instruction manual.  The other problem is that the control buttons are somewhat difficult to use.  They require a surprising amount of force to get them to respond.Back to the positives.  This paired very quickly with my iPhone and Ipad.  I was able to get about 20-25 feet of distance before the sound started to break up, but this is more than sufficient for me.  (The description states up to 30 feet.)  The design of the speaker is very clean and simple.  I have it in the brushed silver color, and it's quite pretty.  Included with the speaker is a USB charging cable and an audio cable, for when you'd like to use the cable without its bluetooth functionality.  It also has a Micro SD slot.  All of these bells and whistles are just icing on the cake, because I would have been thrilled to have the quality of this speaker, even without the bluetooth or the Micro SD or the telephone capabilities.Note - I received a sample of this product for review.
summary: I couldn't believe how great this little speaker sounds

reviewText: This is a little speaker with BIG sound! It's bluetooth and super easy to connect to your phone and use. My only complaint would be that it has a different type of USB charger than I'm used to. But, it works great and is so tiny I can carry it with me in my purse.
summary: Love This Little Speaker

reviewText: The price is right as is the size.  Now this company has managed to pack a lot of good things into this little package.First the sound is well balanced, but with a small speaker (I am guessing about 1” in diameter) you can expect clean balanced sound but not monstrous.  The internal \battery will play back up to about five hours of music without recharging.  Charging is done with the included USB to micro-USB cord supplied.  Charging is about 2-3 hours.The unit also will take incoming phone calls and has a tiny microphone so you can carry on a conversation that may suddenly come in while you are listening.  On one side are ‘small’ buttons for accepting phone calls, play/pause, song backward and song forwards.  The other side of the unit contains the charging micro-USB port, a 3.5 mm internal female plug for using outside music sources (other phones or tablets).One of the nicest things is the inclusion of the TF Card mini slot. With this you can store as much music as your memory card can hold.  This is an item that many Bluetooth speakers miss out on.The entire unit is solid with a grill protecting the speaker on top and the bottom has a non –slip circular pad. There are also two small blue lights denoting that the speaker is working via Bluetooth.This Bluetooth speaker has it all.  I wish the sound was a little stronger, but for the price, it still makes a great gift or office speaker.
summary: Little Genuis

reviewText: The review sample of this speaker that I received from the manufacturer is small, but surprisingly powerful. I was struck by the small size and had doubts about the sound until I connected my Galaxy Note 3 via bluetooth and started streaming music.First I want to talk about set up. It's simple! The earlier generations of speakers that I own required you to remember how long to press and hold a multi-function button to turn it on, off and to connect to a bluetooth enabled device. In some cases I think chanting was involved, but this one is refreshingly different. You turn it on and off with a switch on the bottom and the buttons, such as they are, work without knowing magic sequences. My speaker came up broadcasting its presence, which my phone immediately detected when I initiated a scan. It connected and within mere minutes of unboxing this thing I was streaming music to it. Granted I broke the cardinal rule of charging it first, but I did connect the included charging cable to my Galaxy Note 3's wall charger.Sound is the biggest surprise. I expected it to sound thin and tinny, but it has a much richer sound with good coverage of the frequency spectrum from bass through upper register instruments. The sound quality when it's within a few yards is perfect to my ears. The range of the device itself is within the limits in the product description (I test such things). In other words, this is everything claimed, including the five hours of total play time on a fully charged unit.One final note: this sounds as nice when attached via the 3.5mm port using the supplied cable. I mention this because some speakers work with bluetooth, but have poor hardwired sound. So if you are purchasing this as an axillary speaker for a computer it will work just as well as when receiving streamed music from any other device.Take my experience and the other reviews into account. If you are looking for a small speaker that delivers a surprisingly big sound this one merits consideration.
summary: Small with a big sound

reviewText: Bluetooth speakers are handy and useful, particularly for phones or tablets with speakers on the back that don't project well.  This speaker by OXA, who sent me one to review, is one that I would consider, depending on your situation.  Compared to some that I've reviewed, including an expensive brand, the sound is excellent.  Highs and lows come through clearly and I never felt like I was listening to a tin can.  It can also get pretty loud.  The only downside is that the range is short, even for Bluetooth.  To get consistent audio, the speaker had to be close and without anything in the line of sight.  Otherwise, a great value!
summary: Clear Sound, Short Range

reviewText: This little speaker can put out enough sound to fill up a small room.  The audio quality is good for something this size, great for personal use or a small gathering.Pairing is quick and easy and I reconnect automatically.  Range is not the best, about half the distance I can get with my other better Bluetooth devices.  That gets me into the next room, which is still useful.I can insert a TF card and make the speaker fully self-contained.  Just push the card in.  It knows what to do.  I don't need to punch any buttons or slide any switches.Phone calls are clear enough for me to carry on a conversation.  My daughter complains of hearing her voice echo when she speaks into the Bluetooth speaker.  I only barely hear it, and only because she told me about it.  The caller's end experiences no echo.  Voices are clear, not muffled, and there is no cutting in and out.I like it.This product was provided for review by Oxa.
summary: A Good Personal Speaker

reviewText: This compact speaker with a solid build suffers from inferior audio quality, and interference when playing intermittent sounds.While its diminutive size makes this speaker an easy addition to your laptop bag or tablet case, the 3W speaker is tinny and not an improvement over the laptop's onboard speaker. It may still be useful in a docked-laptop config, allowing the audio to be relocated.Tested on a 2013 Macbook Pro, bluetooth connection was easy, but did drop 1-2x during an hour of sporadic usage (notably not pairing back up when the laptop exited sleep mode). More annoying, the speaker remains "listening" for a moment before and after a sound is transmitted to it, and apparently plays whatever signal it receives. That means there's a buzz of static before/after playing intermittent audio like MacOS system sounds. Presumably it's picking up other RF transmissions and not filtering them out (no other bluetooth devices were in use at the time). A different brand of bluetooth speaker used on the same Macbook in the same location doesn't exhibit this behavior.Strangely, the power connector is the now-obsolete Mini-USB (not MicroUSB). Mini-USB is less common for several reasons including its larger connector and a design specification that makes for a less sturdy connector (shorter lifespan). I have other Oxa products, which all use the standard MicroUSB, so I'm not sure why this product has an obsolete connector.Also a little odd, the generic-looking box said this unit was OXA0041, the bottom of the unit says BL-03, and it shows up in Bluetooth as KR012. Directions are not necessary, but the included ones are in an illegibly small font.There's an on-off switch and an AUX audio input. Audio input cable is included. Rubbery edging on the bottom keeps the unit from sliding. There's a MicroSD slot (labeled somewhat confusingly by its less-common name, "TF card"). A small red light indicates charge is in progress and turns off when charge is complete.[ A sample was provided to me for review. ]A reasonable choice if size is your primary constraint, and the build is solid. But the low-quality audio, the static pauses surrounding intermittent sounds,and use of mini-USB suggest looking elsewhere for better audio quality.
summary: nice compact shape, but tinny, odd static behavior

reviewText: This speaker isn't the best portable one that I have. In fact I immensely prefer the BOOM Cube. However this one has a decent sound for a decent price. Charge time was minimal and battery life is sufficient.I plan on buying a few for some high school graduates for their dorm rooms. For that I would recommend it, but for me its not what I want.**I was provided a sample of this product to test and review. All opinions are honest and my own.**
summary: Not the best, however

reviewText: Four and a half HANDY Stars. The OXA Mini Bluetooth Speaker is a small but mighty, black plastic, squarish, lightweight (6 ounces) portable little  speaker that fits in the hand and puts out a clear, clean, audio spectrum with a reasonably good audible bass level. The cube-like device is readily identified on the Bluetooth screen of any transmitting device with which it pairs. The onboard Bluetooth mechanism paired with two generations of smartphones, and a MacBook Air computer. 2 blue LEDs on the bottom flash when sync is accomplished, as well as 3 audible tones. The rechargeable lithium ion battery lasts 4 to 5 hours. The side port allows a double-pronged audio cable to be connected between a non-Bluetooth device, such as an early generation Kindle, and the mini speaker, which disables Bluetooth when it is used this way. It takes about 4 hours to fully charge the speaker for use, although it comes already charged and ready for use out of the manufacturers box: just turn it on using the bottom switch.  The speaker has 4 onboard controls, but to use them requires the user to pick up the speaker and look at them in order to make an adjustment to raise or lower the volume, change tracks back and forth on the transmitting device itself. In testing, the mini speaker received the Bluetooth signal via an iPhone4 from up to 40 feet away, straight line-of-sight; also the unit was able to receive a clear music signal through the wall of an adjacent room transmitted by an iPhone, but this may vary due to local circumstances. The on/off switch is on the bottom of the speaker and be aware, the unit does not have auto-shut off. This is a great little portable speaker with big sound that can fill a room with music. Highly Recommended. Four and a half USEFUL Stars! (One OXA Bluetooth mini speaker with a 4 to 5 hour lithium-ion rechargeable battery, charging cable, audio cable, and a Manual printed with very small hard to read fonts. This item was provided by the manufacturer for testing and an impartial review).
summary: OXA MINI PORTABLE BLUETOOTH SPEAKER IS A WINNER

reviewText: (Disclaimer: I received a sample for review, but I write unbiased reviews and won't risk my reputation as a reviewer just to get a free product.)There are many of these little portable speakers on the market. The OXA unit features ease of use, good battery performance, and reasonable sound quality. What distinguishes it from others is that it puts out a surprising amount of power without distortion.A full charge took around an hour and a half. Running time depends heavily on how it's used, but expect about 10 hours worst case and more in general. (Running in Bluetooth mode at high output obviously drains the battery faster.)The speaker is lightweight and highly portable, perhaps the lightest Bluetooth capable speaker of its type that I've tested thus far. The unit has its own on/off switch, volume and mode controls. You can figure these out on your own, or you can attempt to read the manual, which is in the smallest font I've ever seen. I couldn't read it even with a magnifying glass, although my wife, who has better eyesight, could read it with strong reading glasses. But even if you can read it you have to puzzle out the fractured English. I took someone's advice and scanned it, then enlarged and did some image sharpening to get a usable manual; if you own this device and want the image I can send it to you, or you can do it yourself.Bluetooth pairing is dead simple and took me about 30 seconds. If you don't want to use Bluetooth, though, the speaker will work in wired mode (cables supplied), or you can plug in a micro-TF card (which I don't have so couldn't test that part).The sound is very crisp and clear with a decent mid-range and satisfactory high end. There isn't much on the low end of the spectrum, but what there is, is clean. In fact, you can push this speaker to its full 3-watt output with minimal distortion. With a typical input source, it plays really loudly for its size. It won't fill Carnegie Hall, but it will deal with a medium sized conference room or outdoor patio with no problem, making it excellent as the "speaker" part of a speaker phone. (In Bluetooth mode, you can use it to answer the phone and talk on the phone, but I generally don't recommend this, as it's easy enough usually to just answer the phone normally.)Bottom line: it's versatile, easy to use, highly portable, very powerful, and the sound is decent.
summary: Easy to use and good sound for a small form factor

reviewText: This is a very nice looking speaker. It is shiny black with silver trim and the white speaker on top. The on/off switch is on the bottom. It has blue indicator lights on the bottom to let you know it is on and working. It has a red indicator light on the back for the charging status. It has a micro USB connection for charging. It had a slot for a tf card so you can play music without an external device. It comes with the micro USB to USB cord and the auxiliary cord. You can plug it into your computer to charge or any wall USB charger. It came with a partial charge and It took about 4 hours for me to get a full charge from dead with the computer. It was faster with the wall charger. The sound is just as clear as others that cost $60-$70 dollars. It handled hip hop songs well with little to no distortion. It connected easily to the Bluetooth. The sound quality was good with phone calls, although it did have a little echo on the other side of the line. The only down side to this speaker was that the instructions are poorly written. I received this product for a fair and honest review.
summary: High Quality sound!

reviewText: As speakers go, their sound quality output is largely the deciding factor on whether or not to purchase one. For some, having a top-of-the-line, surround-sound listening experience is an all-consuming goal. While admirable if you can afford it, the standards of a small, portable Bluetooth speaker are definitely not as demanding. Now before you think that settling on the purchase of the OXA Mini Portable Wireless Bluetooth Speaker (henceforth referred to as "OXA PBS") means that you are sacrificing audio quality, I can attest that, for the price you are investing in a speaker that will simply WOW you.Use & FunctionalityWhile I normally elaborate on the construction of the product that I am reviewing, in order to keep this simple I will only briefly mention some features. First, this speaker has some weight to it, and while it is not heavy, you can definitely tell that it is well-made. The base has a rubber gasket glued to it to prevent the speaker from sliding on and/or damaging a surface. A power button is on the base; when turned on blue lights appear indicating that the device is ready to go, and if no SD card is inserted into the slot on the top side, the speaker automatically enters pairing mode so that it can sync with the desired device.What separates the OXA PBS from other speakers in both the same price range and functionality are the different features that it has:1. It can sync with your cell phone, so that you can use it as a speakerphone and to answer incoming calls.2. As shown in the product pictures, it comes with an audio cable so that you can use it with a music device that may not have Bluetooth capability and/or link the OXA PBS to other speakers.3.  Has a micro-SD card slot to enable you to listen to audio files.4. With the buttons on the front, you can change songs and adjust the volume using the OXA PBS.5. The speaker is smart enough to raise the volume only in proportion to the volume setting on your MP3 player. For example, if I have the volume on my iPod set to low and I max out the volume on the speaker, it will still be only as loud as the iPod setting.OverallFrom the quality construction, ease of use, variety of options for use, and most importantly, the sound quality, the OXA PBS is a purchase that gives you the best "boom" for your buck! Being able to sync it to your phone, plug it into your laptop, or just use it as a way to have a way to listen to your music without headphones gives this Bluetooth speaker a whole lot of utility for a very reasonable price. The sound is clear and of good quality, the unit itself is durable and well-made, and with the included charging and audio cables, you have the ability to link your OXA PBS to everything from a computer on down to an old Sony Walkman.In short, the only thing that I feel that the OXA Mini Portable Bluetooth Speaker needs is a bag to carry both the speaker and cables. That is so trivial, though, as to be inconsequential. So, summing this all up, you cannot go wrong with this purchase! Excellent construction, sound, functionality, and versatility all make the OXA PBS indispensable!**Disclaimer: This product was sent to me by the manufacturer at no cost to review. While I do not feel that this influenced me in any capacity, I am legally obligated to disclose this fact so that you can come to your own conclusions about the merit of this analysis.**
summary: Clean & Clear Sound in a Small Package!

reviewText: The OXA mini portable BT speaker is a beautifully styled speaker that looks, and most importantly, sounds good. It offers a decent range of low to mid, though if you are looking for Audiophile Quality, you will be better served looking elsewhere. If you are looking for good sound quality that you can take anywhere, and does a pretty good throwing sound around a room. It won't blow your ears off from 20 feet, but you can still hear it from that distance, which is great.Pairing is easy. As soon as you power on the speaker it is in pair mode. Simply turn BT on using your phone, connect to the new speaker and you are now ready to play music or take a speakerphone call.In terms of the added features, at this price you generally get just BT capability. The nice thing about this speaker is that yes, you have BT capability, but you can also use line in (in case your device doesn't have BT or you don't want to use the battery power for it) and there is also a micro SD slot. Simply drop you MP3s onto the microSD and off it plays without needing a device. This last feature is really, really nice if you have music you can put on a card as you don't need to waste battery power from your phone or other device, just use the juice in the OXA speaker.Overall the OXA is a great little speaker for the price that offers some great added benefits.Recommended.I received a free review sample from the manufacturer.
summary: Sounds good for the size, and has added features

reviewText: I own at least six tiny bluetooth speakers. They come in different shapes and sizes, but they all function in similar ways. They provide an improvement over the builtin speakers in your laptop or phone, and many of them also allow you to answer calls in a speakerphone capacity. With a flooded market for this sort of thing, how does the OXA model compare? Very favorably, it turns out!Some of these are just total rubbish: weak bass, muted highs, non-existent midrange, and low power. The OXA actually has a surprising amount of bass response. It’s nothing like you’d get from a regular sized speaker, but it’s very good for its size. The midrange is properly balanced so you don’t get certain frequency bands that jump out at you. The highs aren’t amazing, which may not be a problem for you depending upon the kind of music you listen to. I’ll elaborate:If you listen to music that primarily involves mids and highs, this isn’t your best choice. Acoustic music (jazz, folk, singer/songwriter stuff) sounds dull and lifeless. Conversely, if you enjoy rock or electronic music, the OXA really shines. I tried some trance music as well as some tech house and straight techno, and all sounded more lively, probably because the focus is on the bass and midrange. Really, it call comes down to knowing your listening habits.Realistically, a speaker this size isn’t going to sound great. That’s not what it’s about. It’s about convenience. The OXA is small enough to toss into a backpack or laptop case, and it gives you a notably louder sound than whatever device you’re using it with.The main problem here is the manual. When you turn the speaker on, LEDs on the bottom of the speaker let you know the bluetooth status. It turns on and goes into pairing mode automatically, but if you want to switch the speaker to AUX mode and plug directly into your laptop or phone, it’s not clear how to do this. That’s where the manual comes in. It’s approximate one square inch in size (no exaggeration), but it’s filled with text, as if it were much larger. Imagine a regular book with regular-sized letters that had been shrunk into a one-inch square. It’s impossible to read without magnification. Since the speaker’s operation procedure isn’t completely intuitive, this is a problem. A tiny manual is fine, provided the text is large enough to read.Overall, this is a very good speaker considering its size. The manual is the main drawback. Provided you’re not looking for something to beautifully render a Beethoven symphony or whatever, you’ll enjoy this.
summary: Good sound, convenient, terrible manual

reviewText: The title says it all. At first, I had low expectations for this device when I saw the packaging. However, when I opened up the box and felt the device in my hand, I knew it was going to be special. Honestly, there are NO downsides to this product. The build quality is stellar, and it is very compact. Also, the gels on the bottom provide great grip and prevent the speaker from sliding around. As for connectivity, pairing the speaker to your phone is very simple, either bluetooth or the 3.5 mm audio jack, and the audio quality is amazing. Not only is the speaker loud, but it is also clear. Anyways, the led light on the bottom is also unique and adds a sense of style to the device. In the end, if you are looking for a bluetooth speaker, this is the one for you. I RECOMMEND THIS DEVICE, and it  has to be the greatest portable speaker I've used.
summary: Best Portable Speaker I've Used

reviewText: I'm not overly fond of mini speakers. I've tried a few and while one was fairly decent, I still felt like I'd have been much happier with headphones. With that in mind, I nearly declined OXA's offer to review this thing. I try to stay away from situations where I accept a review offer if I know going into it that I probably won't like the product. It just doesn't seem fair to the seller, nor does it seem worth my time and effort. Since I've never tried an OXA product that I wasn't happy with, I decided to go ahead and see if they could succeed where others failed.My first impression upon opening the box was that the little thing looked nice and was much heavier than I expected, making me think that perhaps they didn't scrimp on battery power of magnets (most important part of a speaker). The speaker measures 5.5 cm x 5.5 cm x 6.5 cm high. There is an on / off switch on the bottom as well as two blue LEDs. On the side is a "TF" card slot that is the same thing as Micro SD, a charging port that is USB Mini-B (not to be confused with the newer Micro-B format), as well as next / previous song, play / pause and call buttons.The speaker automatically enters Bluetooth pair mode when it is turned on, and I had no problem pairing it with my notebook computer and my iPod. Once connected, you can control the volume either through your device or by holding down the "Next Song" or "Previous Song" buttons. You can listen to music and charge the battery using any USB plug, such as cell phone wall charger, car phone charger, computer etc.While sound quality and loudness are truly amazing, when connected via Bluetooth, it is much louder and richer when the speaker is connected via the supplied 3.5mm plug. I found this out at 4 this morning,while listening to a playlist on my iPod via Bluetooth. I decided to plug the speaker directly to the iPod and the volume instantly doubled and woke up my wife, who was sleeping at the other end of the house. That speaks volumes (pun intended) about the capability of this little thing.One of my two complaints is one that I almost always with OXA, and have mentioned it on more than one occasion to their reps... the user manual SUCKS. I don't know if there is such a thing as "negative font size", but this manual contains the smallest print I've ever seen. I have 20/14 vision, meaning it's better than 20/20, and I can barely make out the words. OXA has assured me that they're working on revising the manual and their website.My second complaint is their choice of charging plug. USB Mini-B went out of style two years ago and was replaced by the more durable Micro-B USB plug. Luckily I still have a bunch of old cords from my Blackberry days, but this could pose an inconvenience to more than a few people.Besides those two minor issues, I absolutely love this speaker and had I paid the current price of $26 for mine, I'd be very happy with my purchase.
summary: Pleasantly Surprised by the Solid Construction and Great Sound of this Little Speaker

reviewText: This battery combines compact size with a decent amount of power (fully charged my phone twice). This is the size I prefer to carry in my purse as it is not too big to carry with me yet big enough to provide more than just an emergency boost. It is 4" long, 1.75" wide, and 1" thick. It weighs 4.7 oz. This battery pack has one port and comes with one 20" charging cable. Not all cables are equal when used with Android devices, and this one performed very well (see tests below for details). The battery has a small on/off button on the side and it also has auto shut off. Four small blue LEDs on the top of the charger clearly show the level of the charge remaining in the battery. It has rounded form, and it looks nice and sleek.I tested AYL 6000mAh external battery pack with my Samsung Nexus phone, iPadMini, and Samsung Galaxy 7.7 tablet. For testing the tablets I used my own cables as the adapters for them were not included. I tested the Nexus phone with the cable that came with the battery as well as several of my own cables and AYL cable performed in line with my best charging cable and significantly faster than one of my data cables.If you are not interested in the details of the tests here is the summary of the results:The charger was very fast charging my phone. It charged both of my tablets but with below average speed. I was able to fully charge the phone twice.For those who are interested in the details of the tests I am including the details below.★ How I tested this battery pack==================================I own a number of external batteries and to compare them I run the same set on tests on each of them, so they can be compared to each other using "apples to apples" comparison. This set of tests allows me to provide unbiased comparisons between different external batteries. For those who are interested in the details of the test I include at the end of this review.I use a USB current monitor and a charging test to test each port. The current monitor shows the voltage and the current flowing between the battery and the device.The amount of energy transferred from the charger to the device is calculated by multiplying voltage and current. Most of the chargers are 5V devices and most devices show the voltage very close to 5V. The interesting number is the current as it varies from unit to unit and from port to port.The current varies based on what the device requires and what battery provides. This communication happens using different protocols depending on OS. Newer Android OS versions have adapted their protocols to get better performance from ports aimed at Apple devices. An addition variable for Android devices is whether a data cable or charging cable is used to charge the device. The charging cables short the two data connections together (rendering them useless for data transfer), but this fools devices to see the cable as an AC power connection, and thus accept the higher current of the charging source.The 10 minutes test consists of charging each mobile device on each port of the battery pack for 10 minutes and measure how much each unit was charge in that 10 minute period. Since the charging speed is non-linear I start charging each device from approximately the same charge level. I use Battery App by Elvison to determine how each device recognized the charging source. 'AC' status means the charging is at full charging rate. 'USB' status indicates charging at a lower charging rate. 'Discharging' status means that the charging rate is below the power that the device is consuming so it slows down the discharge rate but does not re-charge.★ Test Results:======================✔ Samsung Galaxy Nexus Phone--------------------------AC charging rate ----- 8% change in charge in 10 minutes (included cable)current monitor: ~~~~~ 1.04A and 5.03VAC charging rate ----- 8% change in charge in 10 minutes (my own charging cable)current monitor: ~~~~~ 1.03A and 5.03VUSB charging rate ----- 1% change in charge in 10 minutes (my own data cable)current monitor: ~~~~~ 0.42A and 5.04V✔ Samsung Galaxy 7.7 Tablet--------------------------AC charging rate ----- 3% change in charge in 10 minutescurrent monitor: ~~~~~ 1.1A and 4.97V✔ iPadMini--------------------------AC charging rate ----- 1% change in charge in 10 minutescurrent monitor: ~~~~~ 0.92A and 5.06V★ Summary------------------This pack showed very impressive performance with Nexus phone. It comes with an excellent charging cable. I like shape and size for taking along when I am away from home.Ali Julia review[sample received for testing and review]
summary: Tested with Nexus phone, iPadMini and Samsung Galaxy Tablet

reviewText: At first glance this looks like it is a basic flip phone. It’s roughly the same dimensions (about 1.75 inches wide, 4 inches long and just shy of an inch thick at the thickest point) as a flip phone and the case is styled so that it looks like it would open up. However, it’s a powerbank rated at 6000mAh. Given that most powerbanks are so utilitarian looking, I’m impressed with the thought that went into this design.The powerbank has a single USB output port rated at 1A (located at the top) and a micro USB input port for recharging the powerbank (located on the side). It also has a 4 LED “gas gauge” indicator to show the power level left in the powerbank, and a pretty bright single LED flashlight (turns on with 2 quick pushes of the power button). The power button is small, but is raised enough so it’s easy to find by touch. It has a nice positive click when pressed.The overall build quality is excellent. It is all plastic, but the plastic is of good quality, and the seams are even and tight. All the edges are rounded, as is the overall shape from front to back, making it comfortable to hold and easy to fit into a pocket. It’s mostly a high gloss black with a smoky gray accent strip around the front. All in all, it looks quite nice.Operation is easy and straightforward – just connect the device you want to charge to the USB port and let it charge. The 6000mAh capacity and 1A output rating makes it more suitable for phones and small devices rather than tablets.It comes with a decent mesh pouch that is padded, and a micro USB cable. The instruction guide is brief but mostly well-written (which is a refreshing change from the usual situation).My only quibble is that the gloss finish is a fingerprint magnet. Normally I’d drop the rating due to that but, given how nice this looks, I’ll keep the rating at 5 stars.Nice build quality, good looks, and easy to use. Well worth considering if you’re looking for a powerbank that doesn't look like the typical powerbank.[Sample provided for review]
summary: Well-built external powerbank that looks like a phone

reviewText: This battery pack is small to medium sized and it it's black with a mirror type of finish. It really looks like a small cell phone more than it looks like a battery pack. It has a power button on the side and four little LED lights on the front that tell you when it's charging how much it has left to charge. They also illuminate when you are using it to power a device and will tell you how much charge is left on the battery pack. It comes with a USB cable that is used for charging it and can also be used to charge most cell phones. You need to charge an iPad or iPhone then you use the iPad or iPhone cable to connect to the battery pack. It has a built-in flashlight that can come in handy on occasion. I use it sometimes in my dark truck if I need to see something.The only downside that I have found so far is that it only has a single USB port so you can't charge more than one device at the same time. I have many other battery packs that all have at least two USB ports so I found that a little disappointing. The single USB port does output 2.1 amps so it's good for charging high powered devices like an iPad but it can be used for any device. The battery capacity is 6000 mAh which is almost enough to fully charge my iPad 2 but not quite. The newer iPads have a much larger battery so it wouldn't even come close to fully charging one of them. I could have used a little more battery capacity in my opinion. This battery pack is better suited for charging a cell phone or other smaller electronic devices. My Wife, Daughter, Son and myself all have our own iPad so extra battery capacity and extra USB ports are important to us.Overall I like the appearance of this battery pack and it works well but its usefullness is limited only having a single USB port and a smaller 6000 mAh battery.Sample provided for review.
summary: Nice looking and works well but only has a single USB port and only 6000 mAh capacity

reviewText: For someone who hasn’t owned a portable external battery pack, it’s sometimes difficult to know which one to pick.  For example, if you have simple charging needs and only need a boost now and then, some of the lipstick style, or smaller mAh battery packs will be just fine.  For example, the iPhone 5 has a 1,440mAh battery, while the iPad 3 has a huge 11,666mAh battery.
