No way will the AYL 6000mAh fully charge the iPad 3, but could possibly give it a decent boost in an emergency.With the AYL 6000mAh battery pack you are realistically looking at a couple of full charges for your phone or, perhaps, a bit of a boost for a power-hungry devices.  If you know the battery needs for your phone and/or the devices you use on a regular basis, you’ll know what you want.  If you need portable power for an iPad, you should start looking at an external battery pack with a minimum of 10000mAh, perhaps more.I feel that the AYL 6000mAh is perfect for most people’s needs.  If you are an on-the-go person and need that extra power throughout the day, it’s ideal.  Simply making sure your battery pack is fully charged before you leave the house is a must.  You can either charge via your PC overnight or through an AC charger, a quicker option.The sleek look of the AYL with its beveled edges is quite appealing.  It fits in the palm of my hand, but if I want to travel with it, it can easily be tucked into its mesh travel pouch.  Of course black is a print magnet, but I think we’ve all come to expect that.  I tested it with my first generation iPad and was satisfied with the steady boost of power.No, it didn’t fully charge it, but I was assured with that steady performance, it would certainly give two or three full charges to a phone, depending on what size battery you have.  Simply check those specs out and chances are, the AYL will be something you could use.  The AYL 6000mAh battery pack is style and function rolled into one.WHAT’S IN THE BOX:☼  AYL 6000mAh external battery☼  Micro USB charging cable☼  User guide☼  Black mesh drawstring pouch with the AYL logo on the sideSPECS:~►  Input:  DC 5V/1000mA~►  DC 5.3V/1000mA~►  Dimensions:  4.06 x 1.81 x 1.02 inches (103x46x26mm)~►  Net Weight:  4.37 ounces (124g)~►  Input Charging Time:  5-6 hours~►  Charging speed for mobiles:  1000mAh/hourLED Indicators:LED 1  -  0%  -  25% capacityLED 2  -  25% -  50% capacityLED 3  -  50% - 75% capacityLED 4  -  75% - 100% capacityCOMPATIBILITY:Apple: iPad Air, iPad Mini, iPhone 5S, 5C, 5 / iPhone 4S, 4, 3GS, 3 , 2 / iPod (Apple cable required) Blackberry: Torch Curve 9900 9360 9320Google GlassGoProHTC: One X, S, V / Sensation, Sensation XE XL / DROID DNA / EVO 4G / Radar 4G / Inspire 4G / Vivid 4G / Wildfire S / ThunderBolt / Incredible 2 S / Rezound / Desire X, C, V, HD, S, ZSamsung: Galaxy S4 S3 / Galaxy Note 2 II / Galaxy S2 I9100 / Galaxy S I9000 / Verizon Galaxy S3 I535 / AT&T; Galaxy S3 I747 / Sprint Galaxy S3 L710 / T-Mobile Galaxy S3 T999 / T-Mobile Galaxy S2 T989 / AT&T; Galaxy S2 I777 / AT&T; Galaxy S2 Skyrocket SGH-I727 / Galaxy Nexus 4 7 10 / Galaxy Note / Focus S / InfuseSony: Ericsson Xperia Arc S, X10Motorola: Droid Maxx, Droid 4, Moto X, Droid Ultra, Droid Razr, Bionic / Atrix 2 / Atrix / TriumphLG: Nexus 4, Optimus 4X, 2X, V, S, T, 3D, 7, F3MP3, MP4, MP5 PlayersNokia: Lumia 920 900 710 800 / N8 / N9Nook: Nook Color, Nook HD+PSP, PS VitaSample provided for review.
summary: The AYL 6000mAh battery pack is style and function rolled into one ...

reviewText: There is no shortage of external battery chargers on the market these days, and it can be challenging to find the right one for you. The two main features that distinguish AYL from the competition are its relatively small size and its fun design that resembles a small flip phone.I’ve used the AYL 6000 mAh charger for a few days, and overall I am pretty impressed with it. 6000 mAh of charge capacity is enough to charge my iPhone two or three times, and to fully charge my first generation iPad 3G. This is a very light and well designed charger that easily fits into a compartment pocket of your messenger bag or a suitcase. In an emergency it can even fit inside of a larger pocket. It comes with a micro USB cable, which can be used for charging of various Android smartphones, Kindle book readers, or any other device that uses micro USB charging cables. Unfortunately, it doesn’t come with Apple’s charging cables, so you will have to use your own or the ones bought from some other manufacturer. The micro USB cable can also be used to charge the AYL battery itself, but you will have to either rely on another charger or use your computer for this to work. AYL comes with a nice carrying bag, with pockets for both the battery and the cable.This is overall a pretty decent and nicely designed external battery, but it has its share of shortcomings compared to the other such chargers on the market right now. 6000 mAh is pretty much the low end of the capacity for such devices. Many of other external batteries come with Apple connector cables or attachments, as well as the ability to charge the battery independent of other devices. AYL, on the other hand, is very competitively priced, especially considering its more than decent quality. It is definitely a good product, but perhaps not the best one you can find right now. Ultimately, it will all depend on your needs: for light, occasional smartphone charging (especially is you don't own an iPhone) AYL will be more than adequate for most users.
summary: Fun Small External Battery

reviewText: I was provided an AYL 6000mAh Power Bank for testing and review and was asked only to give my honest review, so this is what I found.What You Should Know Before You Buy:♦ Small power bank with enough capacity to charge a phone at least two times.♦ Has a single 1 Amp charging port.♦ Excellent charging speeds as compared to competing power banks for iPhones and iPad Minis.♦ Has a built-in flashlight.Detailed Review:♦ Look - The product came in cardboard box with an information sticker on the outside. Inside the box was the power bank, a Micro USB charging cable, an instruction manual and a carrying pouch all wrapped in a form fitting cardboard holder. It is a small power bank for its capacity.  About twice the size of the lipstick type power banks but more than double the capacity at 6000mAh.  It has a single 1 Amp USB charging port that was able to charge an iPhone 5S and an iPad Mini. It also has a built-in flashlight, which has good brightness. Overall, it seems to have a nice quality build.♦ Use and Performance - It came with some charge to it so I plugged it in and charged it until it was full. After it was full I did some testing. I took my iPhone 5S which had 49% charge remaining and plugged it into the charging port. I checked to see the progress periodically and found the following results:At after 10 minutes the charge increased to 60%.At after 20 minutes the charge increased to 69%.At after 30 minutes the charge increased to 80%.The speed results were great, and right in line with competing power banks with an average increase of 1% per minute. The overall capacity was great and had plenty of juice to charge my phone with plenty of capacity to spare.Conclusion:Overall, the AYL 6000mAh Power Bank performed great. It had a great capacity for such a small and sleek form factor.  I also gave it a try in my iPad Mini and it did fine charging it also, indicating that you are getting a full 1 Amp output from the port.  The charging speed was also great and in-line with competing power banks. If you are looking for a nice capacity power bank in a small package that can easily fit in a pocket or purse, the AYL is worth consideration. Highly Recommended!
summary: What You Should Know Before You Buy!

reviewText: Tell that to those people who were stuck in that mid-January 2014 winter storm on that Georgia highway!  After watching the story about that highway-turned-parking lot, I finally understood the frightening ramifications of running out of power for my phone.  I finally realized that nature could very well supersede my planning skills and leave me (Yikes! Gasp!) alone and vulnerable and out of touch.  Yeah, it is definitely worth some heavy-duty thought!There are all kinds of battery chargers available:  You can find one the size of a business card, that fits in your wallet so you can make a few emergency phone calls.  And there are chunky chargers that can keep your phone going for days.  This 6000mAh falls in between those extremes and offers about a third of the charging capacity of the largest charger I've personally run across (a 15000mAh).  Only you can guess what your needs are--or would be--in a sticky, unexpected, situation.If you are looking for a very nice looking charger that will give you plenty of power to keep you running for many extra hours, and if you want it to fit in your pocket or small purse, this may be the one for you.To help in your decision-making, here is what this baby can give you:  With the power available in this charger (after about 6 hours charging time), you can add to your phone a little over 20 hours talk-time, or 25 hours web browsing or video/game-play, or 75 hours music-play.  On a tablet it is less:  Maybe a little more than 4 hours talk-time or web browsing, 15 hours music-play, or 5 hours video/game-play.And, not that beauty is a external charger's most important feature, but it sure does help, this one is definitely great-looking.  It is the size of one of your old-fashioned flip top phones.  It is of a size, with nice sloping curves, that fits nicely in the palm of your hand.  The one in my hand right now has a very shiny black body, with a very dark bronze frame.  It looks a bit different from the picture on the product page.  What amazes me, is that I would expect that "very shiny" would also mean a lot of finger prints.  But I have to say that no matter how hard I try to leave a finger print on this material, it will absolutely NOT take one.  (Okay, I admit I might be able to leave a print if I don't use a napkin while eating...)It has a four-LED-light power-level display, which give you a better heads-up than a two- or three-light display.It also has a flashlight!  Love the flashlight feature.  And it looks like many manufacturers are offering the flashlight advantage now, since it is such a popular feature.  (I'm just saying, don't end up with a charger without a flashlight...)Size-wise:  It is about 1 3/4" x 4" and weighs 4.7 ounces.Comes with a simple layered mesh bag that will help guard against normal daily wear and tear, but it does not provide padding to protect it if you drop it.  It also comes with a basic--and average--USB cord.If not used, it holds its charge for a long time.And here is a FYI that I picked up while investigating these external chargers:  It is advisable--if you only use this charger for emergency situations--to recharge it every few months in order to keep the battery working at peak performance.*I received a sample product from Accessorise.
summary: What?  You don't think you need something like this?  You can't imagine not being able to find a charge?

reviewText: Oh, chargers.  There are so many that it is nearly impossible to choose one.  Well, let me make up your mind for you.  This charger, which was provided by AYL for review, has an LED flashlight.:: drops microphone :::: crickets :::: picks up microphone ::Tough crowd, I guess.  Well, it also charges things.  Unlike some no-name brands with equally overlong descriptions, this product actually holds a charge well.  It can even charge a phone/tablet while being charged, but the instructions warn this will reduce battery life.  The size is chunky if you are accustomed to slim 2000mAh chargers, but it also will provide more run time and it is still pretty small.  It is basically the size of a flip phone, while the lower power versions are the size of an iPhone.So, it may not be the most unique product, but it is priced well and do I need to remind you that it has a flashlight?
summary: ... and it has a light

reviewText: This AYL power bank really packs a punch.  It can give my 7-inch Android tablet a full charge with enough power remaining to power my dash cam for hours.It's a beautiful little thing.  I'm not normally a fan of bright shiny surfaces, but this one is sleek and pretty.  It even comes with an LED bulb for a flashlight.  I don't always use the flashlights on my power banks.  I often forget they have them, but this one fits naturally in the grip of my hand.  It feels like a flashlight.  Also included is a mesh drawstring pouch and a micro USB charging cord.  I like pouches and it's nice to have more cords, especially micro USB (they are the most universal).Ah, AYL did it right.  Small enough to carry with me everywhere, enough juice to power a small tablet and more, and pretty to look at besides.This product was provided for review by Accessorise.
summary: Perfect

reviewText: I have a lot of experience with power banks. As this is the case, I always have certain things I am looking for in a good power bank: fast charging battery, easy to use and portability.The AYL 6000 mAh offers all of that, and a bonus flashlight option.The capacity, 6000 mAh is enough to charge an iPhone 5S 3-4 times. My Lumia 1020, 2-3 times. For most occasions, this is likely more than enough for most use cases. I can't seem to find out if this is a 2A or 1A charger, so be aware if you are using this to charge an iPad/tablet, it could take a lot longer to charge than you are accustomed to.Charge time from complete depletion is about 5.5 - 7 hours from my experience. Not bad.Do NOT charge the battery AND charge a device at the same time. Apparently this can affect the life of the battery cells in the power bank and is not recommended specifically in the manual.Before you buy, however, ensure it meets your needs. There are other power banks out there that offer higher capacity and/or ability to charge more than one device at a time. For me, this is easy to travel with and takes up a small amount of space. It isn't however, necessarily something you would want in your pockets. It's a bit on the "fat and short" side, over longer and skinnier, which doesn't lend well to being in the same pocket with your phone OR being in your back pocket, ready for use. If you carry a hand bag or man purse or whatever, it's definitely easy to carry along as it is fairly light though.In terms of price for what you are getting, I've seen and own less expensive options, though this is the only device I own that specifically calls out premium Samsung manufacturer battery cells, so I know this one will last quite some time and won't have capacity issues (not that the other devices I have had issues - it's just a peace of mind kind of thing).One thing I do hate about the AYL is the finish. If you want a fingerprint magnet, this power bank is perfect for you. I clean it frequently as I use lotion/hand cream frequently for my eczema. It's easy enough to clean though, so no big deal, just slightly annoying.The flashlight is a nice addition. It won't replace a MagLight, but if you want something that will help you see a keyhole at night, this is perfect.Overall, this is a great device, with the fingerprint caveat.I received a free sample from the manufacturer for review purposes.
summary: Good power bank device

reviewText: I’ve had the opportunity to evaluate many different types of power banks, and the AYL 6000mAh power bank is one the coolest looking ones I have seen.  Slick, sleek, and shiny black, this device has a single 2.1A USB output port, and as is becoming increasing common, it also has a built-in LED that serves as flashlight.  Light output is not bad, for close up applications.With an appearance similar to a flip phone, this simple to use power bank has enough capacity to handle many high input type smart phones, and when pushed, perhaps even a higher capacity device like a Kindle Fire.  A set of four blue lights provides information regarding the available power, when either charging or when being recharged.The unit comes with a draw string carrying bag, and a micro-USB cord.  To keep this striking looking device looking as pristine as possible, you will probably want to make sure that it is kept in the provided bag, or some type case.
summary: slick, sleek, and shiny…

reviewText: I really like this case.  I like everything about it that I don't even know where to begin.  I like the fact that you can charge your phone and battery through a micro USB port instead of the special lightening port that Apple uses.  I like the fact that this can extend your iphone's life with a simple touch of a button on the back.  I like the fact it has a kick stand also for better viewing purposes.  I like the thickness isn't horribly large for an extended battery.The case itself can use just a little of work.  It felt a little flimsy when I snap the bumper around the phone to the battery.  It didn't feel secure - like I wouldn't feel safe dropping the phone which is the point of a "protective" case.  If there was a 4.5 star, I'd give it but other than that it's a great phone case that looks good and feels good in your hand.  I feel safe knowing I have extra battery life in case of an emergency.  I received this battery case for a honest review.-------Update, I let my brother use this battery for a few days now and he really likes it too.
summary: Great phone case with a battery

reviewText: I am preparing for a 10 day trip and am testing different ways to keep my phone charged during the trip. This case is a wonderful option! It comes in two pieces, and snaps on easily and removes easily as well, with the place to slip your fingernail into the bottom and pulling.Weight-wise, it only weighs 3 ounces - and while it WILL add weight and a bit of bulk to your phone, it is one of the lighter options I have tested. The holes for the speaker aren't problematic, and all of the buttons can be easily reached (and are not covered). The one adjustment you will have to make to your routine is that you need to add a dongle (included) to your plug in earbuds. This seems to be true on all of the battery cases.I like the textured feel of the case, but more importantly, I like the fact that it does NOT hold fingerprints! This keeps it looking professional.I don't usually watch videos on my phone, but I DO read, so the little stand is a nice addition. It pops out to a 90 degree angle, which places your phone at a 45 degree angle to the surface you place it on. The port for USB is a micro, and it charges both the battery and your iPhone. Best of all, it permits you to synch seamlessly with your computer without using the standard iPhone cord!I have given the case (without my iPhone in it) some rough treatment, and it holds up well.I received a complimentary sample of this item to test for a review, and am happy to report that it passed all of my tests with flying colors.
summary: Practical, portable, and professional

reviewText: This review is from: Maxboost Atomic S External Protective iPhone 5S Battery Case / iPhone 5 Battery Case with Built-in Kickstand - Matte Black / Black (Apple MFI Certified, Fits All Versions of iPhone 5 / 5S - Lightning Connector Output, MicroUSB Input ) [100% Compatible with iPhone 5 / 5S on iOS 7.0+ , Strengthened MicroUSB Input Port, No Signal Reduction] (Wireless Phone Accessory)This review is from: Maxboost Atomic S External Protective iPhone 5S Battery Case / iPhone 5 Battery Case with Built-in Kickstand - Matte Black / Black (Apple MFI Certified, Fits All Versions of iPhone 5 / 5S - Lightning Connector Output, MicroUSB Input ) [100% Compatible with iPhone 5 / 5S on iOS 7.0+ , Strengthened MicroUSB Input Port, No Signal Reduction] (Wireless Phone Accessory)This review is from: Maxboost Atomic S External Protective iPhone 5S Battery Case / iPhone 5 Battery Case with Built-in Kickstand - Matte Black / Black (Apple MFI Certified, Fits All Versions of iPhone 5 / 5S - Lightning Connector Output, MicroUSB Input ) [100% Compatible with iPhone 5 / 5S on iOS 7.0+ , Strengthened MicroUSB Input Port, No Signal Reduction] (Wireless Phone Accessory)I love the lightness of this small battery case. It definitely is the lightest iPhone 5 battery case I've come across yet it can discharge 120% of the iPhone's power. This means one can use their iPhone literally all day if just the phone and this battery case are fully charged. Or, for an average user, go two days between charges.The cutouts are well-engineered. Volume controls, headphones jack and more - easy access.Hold firmly - place phone into battery terminal and then snap on outer tight-fitting cover.Appearance - Nice black finish that doesn't show fingerprints, very soft and easy on one's eyes.I recommend this external battery case and think it's a great deal. I was provided a sample and this is my honest opinion.
summary: Extremely lightweight iPhone 5 battery case

reviewText: *Disclosure: I was contacted by a representative for Maxboost and given a sample of this product specifically for the purpose of giving my thoughts on it.*Battery life can make or break a mobile device.  The longer it lasts, the happy the owner is.  With devices such as an iPhone, which do not have a battery that can be swapped out easily by the consumer, battery life is all the more important.  To meet this need for juice, the industry responded with a wide variety of external batteries to give your phone/tablet an extra boot of power.  Later to market are items like this Maxboost Atomic S, which encases your iPhone instead of being a standalone product.  The thought here is that some owners will be willing to add a little girth to their iPhone in exchange for not having to plug into a charger as often.As with theuNu Aero Series iPhone 5S Battery CaseI previously reviewed, the tailored fit of the Atomic S is spot on.  Everything lined up correctly and the phone is snug inside the case.  The matte black plastic is of good quality, and ignores fingerprints in a way that a glossy material can never match.  The Atomic S is a bit bigger than the uNu, true, but it has a slightly higher capacity battery inside.  Also tossed to the wayside is the wireless charging function the higher priced uNu model has going for it.  While not a trade-off exactly, the Atomic S does have a kickstand/prop which the uNu model doesn't.  On the rear, the unit sports a series of muted color LEDS  for indicating battery life of the external pack.In operation, both models work the same, somewhat not-so-seamless way.  You have to manually enable the external battery for it to function at all.  Neither does this automatically, which is a bummer. When enabled, they will push their power reserve into your iPhone, keeping it alive and charging up the native battery at the same time.  When plugged into a charger, the iPhone's native battery gets charged first, then the external pack.  The external pack's charge level can only be manually checked by pressing the button on the back of the case.  Both charge and sync with your computer via micro USB instead of Apple's Lightening connector, which is a design decision I don't understand.  Why force the buyer over to a different cable standard?In three weeks worth of usage, the Atomic S functioned flawlessly and without fail.  The extended up time was a definite benefit, especially when the plugging in at night routine was forgotten.  Just hit the button and the phone was getting charged up.I believe the Atomic S to be a solid product, even with the kind of clunky manner in which it works.  It's not a fault in the design the makes it not so seamless, but rather Apple's rules for what manufacturers can and can't get access to in terms of the iPhone's hardware and software.  I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this unit.  The sampled I was sent has been given away to a friend, which is what I do with most samples, and she's been loving it.  Unless you really want the wireless charging option, and are willing to pay the premium for it, the Maxboost Atomic S is one of the best options available for the iPhone.
summary: Feel thepower

reviewText: I have been using battery cases since I bought my first iPhone! the 3G. I love them when they are made well, and dislike the poor quality ones. A well made case is really an asset as it allows you to have an extra full charge, and lord knows the iPhone needs all the juice it can get!The Maxboost Atomic S battery case is a winner! It fits sleekly on your phone, has 4 lights to let you know how much battery power is left, recharges your phone 100%, has a lightening port, is Apple certified and most uniquely it has a kickstand. I just love a kickstand on my phone and don't understand why more cases do not include one.This case is "the" case for your IPhone 5S. Love it. If my review helped you, please click "helpful" below. Thank you. :)
summary: Very good battery pack...

reviewText: I've used a lot of battery extender cases in my lifetime. Most have compromises, but this one by Maxboost is just about perfect. It's small, lightweight, and sturdy, yet it doubles my the battery life on my phone. On a typical day, I need about a battery and a half, and this does just the trick without adding all the bulk that some others I've used do. Plus it looks great and I'm actually getting quite a bit of use out of the kickstand, which I didn't expect.All this and it's Apple certified, which means you know it's legit. Good times!
summary: The real deal!

reviewText: MAXBOOST does it again - they have improved on the usual cases for the Apple iPhone 5 and 5s by creating a hard shell case to protect the phone while keeping it slim, and adding a 2400mAh built in battery to assure that you always have backup power and the phone can ne charged and synced while it remains safely in the case by using the included MicroUSB cable. Yes, Maxboost made the progenitor to this but this one is far more capable of a longer holding power resource. It also has an LED battery charge level indicator for easy reference when you are near a charger, a headphone jack cutout, and a hands free kickstand.All aspects of this case have passed Apple's tough inspection standards so you know the case and battery are up to Apple's high level of reputation. This is a comfortable to carry, easy to access, safe, and handsome case with added power. That is about all you can ask for! And remember, MAXBOOST gives excellent customer support. Grady Harp, February 14
summary: Protection, sturdy good looks and power backup for the Apple iPhone 5/5s

reviewText: Gosh, there are a lot of iPhone case from which to choose!  Fully charged this one will provide you with an extra two charges for your phone.  In bad weather, standing in long waiting lines, or in emergency situations, the peace-of-mind that this extra charging power can give you is priceless.The fact that this one gives so much battery power with such a small increase in weight to the case is super convenient.  A lot of external chargers are separate from the phone; they are bulky and heavy.  While this case weighs a bit more than a regular case, I hardly notice the extra weight and it's quarter inch or so extra thickness.I love the matte finish of this rubbery material:  It feels classy and doesn't show fingerprints.  The kickstand is a little wimpy, but it clicks in tightly on the back.  I think it feels wimpy because it is thin and lightweight.  Use it, and you will need to avoid bending it unnecessarily backward; don't use it, and it will stay tucked out of the way and you won't even notice it is there.I like the added touch of the audio plug-in extender:  It is of good quality.  The USB cord is nice and thick, with sturdy plug ends.I love a good product page, and Maxboost always provides one.  They make the features of the product very clear and easy to understand.  After reading this product page, you will know what you are getting.*I received a sample product from Maxboost.
summary: Classy case with potent, incorporated, slim and lightweight extra battery power

reviewText: This is a nice, quality charging case for the iPhone 5/5s. It has a matte texture on the outside and a hard gloss texture on the inside. The matte finish on the outside looks aesthetically and texturally pleasing.The case offers some protection with the battery adding to the thickness of the phone but the sides are thin. It also comes with a little stand on the back which is pretty useful when you want to prop the phone up to watch something.The plug fits well and doesn't wiggle. To start charging your iPhone you have to hold the power button on the back for a few seconds. It charges your phone at a normal speed and it's great to be able to charge your phone without a cord.To charge the case itself you use a universal charger and you plug it in the bottom side of the case. It's also pretty easy to take the case on and off. The only problem I've found is that it's a little difficult to lock it or to change the volume. Due to the recessed headphone jack an adapter is provided.Overall, very convenient and useful for people who are on the go. Sample was received for review purposes.
summary: Excellent!

reviewText: First, there are some excellent reviews posted before mine that cover most of the facts. I will focus on subjective reasons why I love this case and try to not parrot what others have already said.I carefully examined and tested my review sample. At the core of this product is the battery, which is an impressive engineering feat because the manufacturer managed to achieve respectable power storage with very light weight.It at least doubles your use time by adding 2400 mAh to your phone's 1420 mAh. Even factoring in heat and other losses you increase your capacity twofold (or more) as soon as you charge it encase your phone. That alone is a powerful value proposition.The protection afforded by this case is basic. Don't get me wrong, it will protect your phone in controlled settings like offices. I do not view that as a detriment because this is designed to be a battery extender with collateral benefits of physical protection. The compromise is it does not add bulk or weight to your 5S.One final note: I first though the 'kickstand' was a gimmick to differentiate this from other battery packs. I have actually grown to love it because it allows me to easily view my phone's screen when I am working at my desk. A simple glance shows new events and notifications without craning my neck. It's also great for watching Youtube clips, which I spend too much time on.Bottom line is this is a great battery extender in non harsh environment, and the extra use time it allows makes it a true value.
summary: Impressive performance with basic protection

reviewText: If you want to use a case, it is better to get a integrated battery+case. This has great advantage of doubling the battery capacity. The maxboost Atomic battery case is very elegant for iphone 5/5S. I tried on my wife's iphone 5S and she loves it. The black color blends well with iphone color and does not add much heft to it. The phone also becomes a microUSB phone like android! iPhone 5/5S Atomic S Battery Case, Micro USB Charging cable, and Audio Jack Extension are included in the package.iTunes sync up was no different. The extended battery is a powerful 2400 mAh. You don't have to remove the case for charging or syncing. I did not feel any reduction in call signal strength and data speeds. The LED indicator is bonus. Also some cases I have tried heats up. I did not notice much heating with this Atomic maxboost case. Overall impressive!I was provided a product for review in exchange of a honest and fair review.
summary: Solid and rugged

reviewText: From package design to the product itself, it's a little deceiving.  The package box shows the speaker with a clock on it but on the product itself there is no clock function or at least no real way to get to it.  The package does not include any instructions so basically you'll have to catch on by playing around with it.On the back of it, there is a port for you to dock a flash drive of some sort to play mp3's and only mp3s. Just by looking at its size, you would imagine that it would be fairly loud but it isn't as loud as I thought it could be - this could be a personal preference but I am comparing this to comparable sized speakers.All the buttons on screen on capacitive buttons. The second you turn it on, it goes to bluetooth mode and is ready for pairing.  The connection is easy and works well and it can even accept phone calls.  You can switch functions by hitting the "M" button. which has the FM mode, Line mode, and mp3 function.  All the modes work fine but the FM mode.  What I find hard and difficult to use is the FM mode.  Once you are in the FM mode, you would imagine that the tuner buttons (left and right arrows) would change the station but they do not.  I keep getting stuck on 87.5 FM and it will not change.  I've tried every button on that screen and nothing seems to work.  Overall, it's a nice speaker but I probably wouldn't use this for other than the external speaker function. I received this item for a honest review.
summary: Design is nice but there's a limit on functionality

reviewText: This beautiful bluetooth speaker is perfect for my desk. With bluetooth improving exponentially, the sound outputted through this speaker is just as good as a wired speaker, if not better! This system is completely wireless (has a built in battery that charges through USB) and it includes an FM radio that delivers a variety of music.It also includes a standard audio cable (3.5mm) and a slot for a TF card.Perfect for an office, a kitchen, or even a bedroom
summary: Beautiful blue box speaker

reviewText: If you wonder how one speaker offers stereo sound, one look at the device straightens that out: the box has three speakers. The stereo sound is good...it is strong, has a pretty clear quality, and though it necessarily depends upon a good connection...so to judge it, I played it off some beautiful recordings I have that deliver a nice range of sound, and I think the speaker does a pretty nice job...not very heavy on the bass sounds, and quite pleasant on the higher end of the scale.  This speaker box delivers pretty good sound for a stand-alone unit, a good, full-bodied sound for a small six inch cube sitting atop a table. I wouldn't use it in an auditorium, but in a normal sized room in a house it does just fine.I found it easy to connect through Bluetooth airwaves to my phone (though I could not get my Kindle HD Fire to recognize it). One can also connect it via your computer's USB port, OR connect your through a 3.5mm audio jack to a small port located at the top of the speaker cube, OR insert a TF card into the appropriate slot on the top of the unit. Through a touch screen that takes a little getting used to, you can move from "Line" use or Bluetooth or FM radio, and the unit, if unconnected, is powered by a battery that will hold a charge for about four hours.As for looks, the box is said to be a wood finish, though my box's black exterior didn't really seem very "wood-ish." But I like the way it looks, regardless, and with two small exceptions I think the box is pretty nice: I'm not a big fan of putting the connectors ON TOP of the box, quite close to the front, as it clutters up an otherwise "clean" look. To a much lesser degree I think it odd that the inlaid labels for the connections face the wrong direction...they're opposite of the OXA label an inch over.As with the design of theOXA Mini Portable Wireless Bluetooth Speaker, I like the minimalist, clean look of this device. It also comes in five finishes, and I feel the black is as economical an appearance as one could hope for. Also, as with the Mini-speaker, there are four rubber pads on the bottom so that it will grip the surface upon which it is placed.  They also don't really have a conventional-looking screen easily enables one to use the device, but it's not difficult to learn.As is always the case with OXA, the directions are more than a little clumsy. I quote: "By activate the NFC and Bluetooth in the cellphone, hold the cellphone to touch this bluetooth speaker nearby the NFC logo will have bluetooth connection to connect automatically."As usual, all OXA products come with a 1-year warranty, which OXA will let you extend for another half year..NOTE: I was supplied this product free of charge with no other conditions other than my writing a fair and honest review -- which this is.
summary: Good stereo sound, pretty easy to use

reviewText: First, I almost knocked this a star because the directions are horrendous. However, once I played with it for a little while, I figured it out and gave it back the well deserved star. For this price, this speaker packs a lot into a small package. I've had it a few weeks now and am loving it. I have a lot of Bluetooth speakers and this one has become my goto.My first mistake was flipping the battery upside down -- my fault. My second learning opportunity, was how to program the FM stations. It took a little work. But I figured out that the M light scans and programs for you.The wood case seems to add some depth to the bass and sound over my other Bluetooth speakers. Plus, it is very cool to have a Bluetooth speaker that not only plays from my iPad, iPod and phone but also directly from a memory card or good old fashioned over the air radio.The speaker talks to you when you turn it on "Bluetooth Mode". Then "Bluetooth Connected". Clever for a nimrod like me.This plays seamlessly with all of my Bluetooth devices. It looks cool on my nightstand and now that I know how to use everything, I am very pleased. It has very clear sound that is loud enough. I won't be throwing a block party kegger with this speaker, but for my bedroom it is loud and clear enough to annoy the neighbors if I choose.This seems like a very well made, interesting Bluetooth speaker.Sample provided for unbiased review.
summary: This Does It All

reviewText: *Disclosure: I was contacted by a representative for OXA and given a sample of this product specifically for the purpose of giving my thoughts on it.*HTC OneHTC EVO 4G LTESamsung Galaxy S2Samsung Galaxy S3Samsung Galaxy S4Samsing Galaxy NexusiPad MiniiPad AirGoogle Nexus 7 (original)Tegra Note 7NVIDIA ShieldI've done so many reviews of Bluetooth speakers at this point that I'm probably a bit jaded.  Like almost every product I select to review, I wanted the Woody (OXA's name for this product) to succeed.  From the pics and spec sheet, it looks good.  In usage though, it becomes very apparent how thrown together this product really is.The Woody sports two side speakers and a third port up on top.  The built quality is pretty good, everything fitting together well.  The SD card, USB, Micro USB, and AUX connectors are a snug fit and functioned perfectly throughout my testing.  The unit that arrived at my door came with a dented speaker grill on top, but it wasn't horribly messed up.  The manual, as with all manuals that have come with every OXA product I've gotten, blows.  Not just because of the English and grammar, but also because of the size, lack of detail, and inaccuracies. (See their website for better manuals.)  Included in the box is everything one would need to get started.From here, we start finding the hokey stuff.  First thing one is supposed to do with a rechargeable device is charge it up.  The Woody is rated to provide 2+ hours of use time before the battery is depleted. This is way below the average for similar items, which are in the 8+ hour range.  The Woody doesn't particularly like to tell you when it's low on battery except when in Bluetooth mode.  In Bluetooth mode, a pleasant-ish voice announces that battery power is low and the battery indicator flashes.  In any other mode, the unit simply dies without warning.  When charging, the battery indicator and buttons are all illuminated.  Once charging is completed, the battery indicator turns off and the buttons do a slow fade in/out cycle.  In my use, charging from a 1A wall charger took about an hour or so.Bluetooth mode seems to be where all the attention was paid when the Woody was designed.  Besides the voice telling you when the battery is low, it also tells you when you've selected Bluetooth mode, when there is a Bluetooth connection, and when the Bluetooth connection is dropped.  The voice is not present in any other mode.  The controls all work fine across several apps including Pandora, but it should be noted that the Woody has its own volume control instead of controlling the volume on the volume on the device that is connected to it.  Audio quality and volume in Bluetooth mode varied between devices.  For example, the volume from the Nexus 7 was much lower and had less bass than the same track being sent from the HTC One, both with and without Beats audio being active on the HTC.  At volume level 6 of 32 on the Woody, nothing could be heard from the Nexus while the HTC could still be heard, (both were set to max Bluetooth volume).  Not having had this before with other devices of the same kind, my guess is that the circuitry in the Woody isn't smart enough to equalize input sources.  This is evidenced even more when other modes are selected.Playing back from storage, USB or Micro SD, the volume is substantially louder than the same track when played in Bluetooth mode. The loudest of all modes, according to the decibel metering app I was trying out.  The AUX is a close second.  The quality in USB and Micro SD modes is also superior to Bluetooth.  I can't tell with AUX.  In these two modes, the >> and << buttons on the front panel have dual functions. Short press to jump tracks, as when in Bluetooth mode, but also long press which does in-track fast forward and rewind.  When using the function, the time marker for the track is displayed, allowing you to visually narrow down where you want to stop.  Sadly, neither mode makes use of the tags embedded in your MP3s.  Instead of scrolling the track/song title, you get the time of how long the track has been playing.  There are no playback modes, as in, repeat track, repeat all, etc.  No playlist support either.  Woody plays what he finds in order from first to last in a never ending loop.The last to be mentioned mode, FM, is perhaps the biggest let down of all the modes.  I thought it pretty clever that the Micro USB charging cable doubles as the antenna.  But, why on earth did they put all the ports up on top, where they are more susceptible to getting damaged?  Anyhow, in my area, reception was almost nil without the cable plugged in.  With the cable plugged in, I picked up 4 stations, three of which were playable and one that was just clear static.  Holding the end of the cable got me 28, with a few being pure static and some bleed overs. Ok, that stands to reason, a better antenna results in better reception.  But the algorithm used to determine which stations are ok coming in clear and which aren't is clearly flawed.  As the Woody has no method for manually selecting a frequency, that's a major problem.  That's right, with Woody you can only listen to the stations that it thinks comes in clearly during an initialization scan.  You can repeat the scan at any point if you want to play around with antenna position, but that also risks losing some of the other stations which may now be too fuzzy according to Woody.Some misc notes on Woody.  For best sound in terms of quality and rooms filling, put Woody in a corner or other recessed area so that the sounds from the side mounted speakers can bounce and project out.  There is a major difference in the level of bass when this is done, which is a good thing as Woody doesn't have much on his own.  Woody has a mind of his own at times.  If you're in, say, USB mode and plug in the AUX cable, Woody jumps modes to the utilize the new connection.  Remove the cable, and Woody jumps to FM mode.  Make a Bluetooth connection while in any other mode, and Woody ignores it, forcing you to manually select Bluetooth mode. Plug in an SD card or USB drive and Woody jumps to that mode.  Remove either, and Woody hops over to FM mode again.  Maybe.  Sometimes he goes to Bluetooth.As I see it, Woody's design was never fully thought out.  Yeah, some cool features, but feel very half baked and tossed together like a kid adding different decorations to their art project.  Not because the decorations made the picture better, but because they liked the decorations.  The inconsistent volume and quality is not desirable, or to me acceptable, for a device in this price range.  Other similar products have these things sorted out, why not Woody?
summary: Feature packed but haphazard design

reviewText: This Bluetooth speaker will make some good sounding music.The design is nice, and sits nice on the nightstand or dresser. The body is constructed of wood, which produces some good music. The face of the speaker is made of acrylic, which gives it nice look. In the hand is nice and light, but feel sturdy. The entire speaker is coated with a textured plastic that gives it a good feel. The size is similar to box of "Kleenex".The two pairing modes are Bluetooth or NFC (Near Field Communication). Bluetooth pairs the same as any other Bluetooth device. In order to use the NFC pairing mode, pass the back of your phone near the bottom right hand corner of the speaker screen. NFC pairing is a much faster way to pair than Bluetooth. When playing music the sound quality is great at lower volume levels, but becomes washed out at higher levels.There are three input options, this makes the speaker versatile. The first method is AUX, which allows the speaker to be used as a wired device with supplied 3.55mm cable. The Micro SD slot will play music from a memory card. The USB port is perfect for music stored on a "Flash Drive".The speaker has a FM Radio function, I was unsuccessful on using this function, and your mileage might vary. I know it say up to four hours of playback, I have only been able to get two hours. For a speaker this size with two big speakers, I was looking for playback time. The instructions on the user manual were pretty vague and did not make much sense. I had to go to the company website to get a better version.This Bluetooth speaker is good, but I will be looking forward to the new revised model.CONTENTS:OXA NFC Bluetooth SpeakerMicro USB Charging Cable3.5mm Stereo Audio CableUser ManualFEATURES:Bluetooth Range: 33ft (10m)NFC Pairing Support: YesFM Radio: Yes (Stations 87.5 - 108)Inputs: AUX, USB, Micro SDSpeaker Output: 3W (Each Speaker)Speaker Size: 2in (50.8mm)Battery Size: 850mAhBattery Input: 5V/1ACharging Time: 2-3 HoursBattery Time: Up To 4 HoursCase: WoodScreen: AcrylicWeight: 19.93oz (565g)Dimensions: 4.33 x 4.45 x 4.33in (110 x 113 x 110mm)Warranty: 1 YearI was supplied a sample for the purpose of review.
summary: Good Speaker, Needs Improvement

reviewText: I really like the design on this speaker, and the sound is very good also.I like to listen to the radio, but that was a little tough to figure out (manual is not very good).  I am no techie at all, so the issue could have been me.  Eventually I figured out how to use it, but I would not buy this unit for the radio.  I was going to take a point off, but I am thinking it is partially user error.I will not write all the tech specs as there are already a lot of reviews with them already.I do love that it is made of natural wood, which seems to give it a very clean sound that is higher quality then you usually hear  on a unit this size.The pairing went fairly quickly, so I am happy about that.  Some units can really be a bear to pair.The unit has a digital screen display, and easy to use touch sensitive buttons.  On a single charge I got about 4 hours of use.  It has a replaceable lithium battery.This unit also has multi-function design, which  includes Integrated support for Micro SD Cards, FM Radio and Aux Line-in connection for use with your laptop or whatever.So, the unit looks cool and sounds very good, which is why I like and will use this wireless speaker.  I took off 1/2 star for the radio to give this a rating of 4.5 stars.A unit was provided for review, but the opinion is my own,
summary: Good looking and sounding speaker...

reviewText: In a sea of plasticky bluetooth speakers, this wooden one is a real standout. I use it right by my bed and it looks great, plus it the sound is warmer than an equally sized speaker because of the wood. The sound quality is excellent and the pairing was simple!The only thing that would make this better is if you could see wood grain. That would bring it to 5 stars!
summary: Rich sound, great looks!

reviewText: This quite handsome wholly portable wireless stereo speaker is just the right answer for Bluetooth and NFC sound production. There are two speakers unobtrusive place on opposite sides and the quality of sound is as fine as any you'll hear form Bluetooth transmission. Perfect for taking around the different rooms of the house or office, great for little minor OR rooms for patient's enjoyment and relaxation (use their own music source!), and a keen way to listen to the radio for news in between music periods. It has a digital screen and light sensitive touch buttons. The package comes with a USB Connector, Audio Line, Rechargeable Battery, and a User Manual that makes set up simple.But the main aspect - other than the portability and wireless aspect - is the quality of sound. No muffling or static, just pure clean well balanced sound throughout bass and treble. Another solid OXA addition to technology. Grady Harp, March 14
summary: Small size, Big sound

reviewText: Sound is decent for a speaker in this price range:  Rich and full, not tinny and hollow.  And, the cube shape is cute.But I just cannot get used to only two hours of battery life!  I feel defeated:  Here I find a speaker with a terrific range of at least 65 feet--double the distance of most of my other speakers--plus even further if I work hard to position it just right.  So, I can really move it quite a ways out in the yard and away from a power source.  But, I can only leave it there for a measly two hours.....Two hours is NOT a long time.So, I'm still tethered:  Not by range this time, but by a cheap battery.The ability of this speaker to bring in FM radio signals may be a big thing for you, but it did not affect my opinion of this speaker.  We get reception from just a few FM stations out where we live; this speaker found them.*I received a sample product from OXA.
summary: Love the blue tooth range; hate the battery life

reviewText: This OXA wireless speaker is wonderful. It's super easy to connect to your phone or tablet via bluetooth and it's so little that it's easy to take with you anywhere. The sound is great and I was really pleased with the look of the speaker as well.
summary: Love This Little Speaker

reviewText: This is not your average cube speaker. It is large, about 4 inches square. If you think that is small, get a ruler and draw a 4 inch square and figure on it being that tall as well.However, what you give up in a small footprint, you gain in sound and volume. It has great sound, deep, clear, crisp vocals, great for music, podcasts, streaming radio or whatever. It has a large face with onscreen touch controls, volume, forward backward, mode selection and pause. It also displays what the input is (blue, line or radio) and it announces (in a unique voice) when it goes into or out of bluetooth mode.I haven't tried it as a phone speaker but I tend not to want to use a bluetooth speaker for phone use, too many people in the house listening then!It takes a little finagling to figure out how to use it but really, it becomes pretty self explanatory after some use. It comes with a USB to micro USB cable for charging and it also has a USB port on top which allows you to power or charge a phone or other device while it is running. It comes with an audio cable for devices that don't have bluetooth. You can also use a micro SD card in a port on top to play music from if you don't have it on a phone or other device.It says it is "natural wood design" but I'm just not sure what they are referring to. There is no obvious wood in the exterior of this speaker.So there is some great sound, great volume, and many options for use.I was provided a unit for evaluation and review.
summary: Large, Clear, Took a Little Figuring Out

reviewText: This is a wooden box that is slightly over 4" X 4" X 4" and plays anything by Bluetooth, FM radio and external sources of music by an included 3.5mm double ended cord.  There are good and bad aspects to this Bluetooth speaker -mostly good.Con:The instructions are SO small they are illegible.The lithium battery (included) only lasts about two hours when playing music.The push buttons work well on the unit, but they are small and require the use of a felt tipped short-pen, similar to the ones used on tablets.  There is a wafer sized remote control if you don't like the felt-tip short-pens.The On/Off button is tiny on top and you need to see it - not feel it.Pros:It looks great with a red display showing FM or Bluetooth mode, icons for song forward/backward, volume up/down, pause/play and alternate from Bluetooth/FM.When the unit pairs or goes to FM, a voice clearly tells you - I like that.The felt-tip short-pen is handy.The speakers are stereo left and right with another middle speaker on top that brings out more of the bass sound.The lithium battery is easily installed.There is a charging cord that runs from your PC USB to the unit.There is a 3.5mm female jack for external sources of music with appropriate cord included.  There is a USB port on top of the unit for accessibility to other electronic devises.There is a micro-USB port (TF Slot) that allows you to store and play as many songs as you can depending on much memory the card has - this is a big plus, I think.  You don't need an iPhone/tablet or external Bluetooth memory source.The wooden unit keeps the music from sounding too tinny and it sits on four small pads to avoid scratching and vibration.The sound is well balanced.  You won't get screaming treble or loud bass, but the music is very pleasantly balanced.It comes in eight colors, but that's minor. The multi-uses and functions make this a great product and gift. The price is reasonable for a product like this.  Product supplied for a fair and honest review.
summary: All Bases Covered - Nice Unit

reviewText: The OXA Bluetooth speaker is not just a Bluetooth speaker.  It's also an FM radio, and it has inputs for a TF card and flash drive and auxiliary cable.  The speaker speaks to us in a pleasant female voice with an Asian accent.  Controls are on the face of the unit, basically a touch screen with LED display.  From the looks of it, I think it would make a nice clock.  Alas, it does not display the time.Bluetooth was easy to set up with my iPhone 4S.  It always reconnects automatically.  The range is not the best of my Bluetooth devices but still very good.  I can go down a long hallway and still get reception.  Documentation says it can get up to 20 meters.  I'd say that's about right.Phone calls are poor.  I can hear the caller, but the voice is soft.  The caller can hear me, buy my voice is muddled.TF card and flash drive work well with this speaker.  The display will tell me what track I'm on but nothing else.  The only way to pick and choose music is to skip forward and back.The radio will scan all the stations until his has a list of live channels in the area.  After I do it once, I don't have to do it again.  Reception is very good.  I don't get a lot of static.One thing I would like to see is a larger power button.  We get a small one I have to look to find.  Other than that, this little speaker puts out a lot of sound.  While it may not have the richness of higher end systems, it can fill a room.  That, along with its versatility, is enough to satisfy the average listener.This product was provided for review by OXA.
summary: Versatile Speaker

reviewText: This speaker is actually quite nice once I actually got it figured it out anyways.  The unit itself works for about 4 hours on a full charge and actually plays music louder via Bluetooth then if I connect it with the audio cable. The bass is actually pretty good as well which is always a gamble on these little portable speakers.I can't bring in any radio stations on this thing and it could be my location so if I can figure out the problem with that I'll update. I like that the speaker tells you not only when its in Bluetooth mode but it lets you know when you are connected to your device.The included instructions leave a lot to be desired, and the display on the front almost looks like it could display the time but it doesn't. An included cloth for smudges on the screen, an extra battery compartment door and all the hook ups you would need make the package complete.Overall its a pretty nice speaker and the one i'm using is all black so I don't know if the colors would be a nice touch or not. If I can get the radio station feature to work then I will adjust my rating.**I received this product to test and review, all opinions are honest and my own.**
summary: Big sound from the cube

reviewText: This is a nice-looking, cube-shaped battery-powered speaker that has a wide variety of usage possibilities. I wouldn't call it briefcase portable, but you might take it along on a vacation trip by car. It's useful when you want more sound from a portable device and don't mind a little more size and weight (in return for better audio quality).It's really versatile, with several modes: bluetooth, line-in, USB or TF card, and FM radio. Yes, it has a built-in FM radio that works rather well on strong signals (heed the manufacturer's advice to connect the charging cable to act as an antenna). The radio has an automatic scanning function that you activate on first use or when changing geographical locations. The unit will remember the scanned stations between uses but unfortunately won't remember what station you last listened to, which is inconvenient.Line-in works with the attached standard 3.5mm TRS to TRS stereo cable, a widely used standard. You can connect to the headphone jack of most portable devices with no problem. By the way, the charging cable is USB to micro USB, another standard. It's always a plus when the manufacturer uses standard connections. (No charger is supplied.)Bluetooth is also available with a choice of conventional or NFC pairing. I found it paired very easily with no fuss. Sound quality (which I'll discuss further in a minute) seemed to take quite a hit, though, in Bluetooth mode. I think this had to do with the Bluetooth mode not being particularly sensitive, resulting in a relatively weak output. Line-in sounded a lot better.The volume output for reasonable input levels (1V RMS, more or less) is undistorted at max volume. Higher input levels cause distortion; that's to be expected. The maximum output of the unit is nice for a living room or patio, but not for a gymnasium ... it's a small speaker and works well within its design range.Sound quality? I had expected a little more, but again, it /is/ a small speaker. The best sound is in FM radio mode. Line-in is pretty close in quality. The high end is satisfactory, and the mids are clear and detailed. The bass lacks something but I guess I shouldn't expect to rock the walls with a small unit. Overall sound in FM and line-in mode is pleasant and easy to listen to. In Bluetooth mode I thought the sound had a "thin" quality.Other input possibilities include a USB drive and a TF card. Sound quality with these is about the same as line-in, which is pretty good. However, as with the radio, position information isn't saved (although that would be much more difficult with these types of input). Seeking is unguided (there is no track display) but this isn't supposed to be a substitute for a high-end MP3 player.The battery takes not quite 4 hours to charge for 90 minutes of play time. This is a major limitation. 90 minutes goes by in a hurry.The instructions are very brief, but if you can read the horrible English, they are surprisingly complete. Hiring a technical editor to fix the English wouldn't have cost much and would really have helped. But the device is easy enough to figure out with 15 minutes of experimentation.Overall evaluation: this speaker is very versatile, with an FM radio and multiple input modes. It's a fascinating gadget with a lot of uses and good sound for the size. The major limitation is short run time.
summary: Fascinating and versatile

reviewText: This is a beautiful natural wood design speaker.  The sound is very clear. Has nluetooth and NFC technology. Digital screen display the working status in bright RED color. Very nice. When the speaker pair with phone, a clear voiceover announces paired. This has 3.5MM Line in, USB and SD Slot. FM radio will automatically search channels after long press the pause button and it was clear. For FM, you need to connect the given microUSB cable which serves as an antenna.This speaker is bigger in size than a typical bluetooth speaker, but the sound quality and construction is awesome. It also has a nice big LCD display. The battery is replaceable, but I did not open it and test it. I am sure these batteries last a long time. The main impressive thing is it has a awesome sound and you an increase sounds in increments from 1 to 31.Overall impressive sound box. I was provided this product in exchange of a fair and honest review.
summary: Excellent Rugged Design

reviewText: This is by far the best speaker that I have reviewed in this price range! It produced loud clear sound. It is a very nice looking speaker, modern and sleek. It sits perfectly on top of my computer tower. I love that it tells you in a woman's voice when you are connected to Bluetooth. The sound quality was so good that I am using it as the only speaker for my computer. It has an audio jack to use for any device that has an audio 3.5 output. It also has a place for a TFT card and USB jack, if you want to play your music from that. It comes with a charging cable that you can plug into the computers USB port to charge or any USB 5V charger. It takes about four hours to charge it all the way from empty. I charged it before using it. The charging cable doubles for a radio antenna and it gets great reception. Phone calls sound clear on both ends. I highly recommend this product. I received this product for a fair and honest review.
summary: Superior Sound!

reviewText: I came to this product rather late. Several previous excellent written and video reviews have covered most aspects of the product. But here is my opinion:Pros -  Elegant design. Sturdy and compact.Good sound.Several choices of music source - Bluetooth; FM; MicroSD card; USB  memory stick; plug-in Auxiliary (male to male cord provided)Bluetooth pairing is easy.NFC (Near Field Communication) capability.Bright crisp screen with vivid Red touch controls, intuitive use.Two speakers, one on each side+ small Bass.Replaceable battery.Cons - Maximum Volume U 32, barely above normal speech.Poor reception as phone speaker.Bass function less than expected.FM requires an efficient antenna.Too bulky as a travel speaker (4.25" x 4.25" x 4.5"), 1lb 4oz.Battery lasts 65 minutes but takes 4 hours to charge.Confusing inadequate instruction manual.Value priced wireless Bluetooth speaker that would complement any decor in a home or office.I was provided with a complimentary sample for review.
summary: Good quality at a fair  price.

reviewText: I grew up in Cleveland, Ohio. While not born there, it was the city where my love for all different types of music developed, even in the face of such horrible radio stations (the Rock n' Roll Hall of Fame is a joke, but I digress). Back then I was proud of my tabletop stereo with the wired speakers as I rotated through my 3!! CD changer and grooved out. Now music lovers have the option of listening to music through Bluetooth wireless speakers, enabling us to play the sound wherever we like! Truly, technology is a marvel. And, of course, that is where the OXA NFC Bluetooth Natural [Wood] Wireless Speaker comes in.FunctionalityThe OXA NFC Bluetooth Natural Wood Wireless Speaker (henceforth referred to as the OXA NFC to save my hands from wearing out by just typing the product name) is a cube roughly the size of a large alarm clock; the nifty part is that you can use this speaker as an alarm by syncing it with a device that has one programmed. This, however, is but one function of this product.At it's heart, the OXA NFC is designed to play sound. Since it is a Bluetooth-enabled product that also happens to include a microphone built in to the top of the unit, there is a great deal of flexibility in how you choose to use this device. If you want it to act as a speakerphone for your cell phone/tablet, you can do that. Want to listen to music saved to a micro-SD memory card? No problem. Heck, it can even support devices that do not have Bluetooth capability by using either a USB or 3.5mm Aux Line-In (the cable is even included in the box).What if you don't have a music device? Never despair: if your pet iguana ate your iPod, this device can even function as an FM radio to help you get through the day(s) until you can get a replacement (or until the iguana gives it back to you, if you know what I mean)!Use/PerformanceWhen you first turn on the OXA NFC, it will automatically enter Bluetooth sync mode; during this time you can have your iPod (or other device) detect the speaker in order to link. Once you have set up a connection to the speaker, the next time that you use it in Bluetooth mode it will connect to the same iPod within the first few seconds after the speaker is turned on, automatically.When using the OXA NFC, the screen on the front of the device will say "Blue" and a voice will advise you when the speaker is connected to your device; command buttons will then appear at the bottom of the screen (it is a touch screen), allowing you to adjust the volume, choose a song, play/pause, and choose the operation mode. With the Bluetooth mode being the first mode, the second is the FM radio, third is Line-In, and finally back to the same voice announcing that you are in Bluetooth mode.Pros:1) Syncing this speaker to your desired Bluetooth-enabled device is a breeze. No fussing around and holding down buttons for a set period of time; the OXA NFC takes care of that for you.2) The sound quality of this unit is amazing; especially considering how lightweight it is!3) The "Mode" button responds quickly and cycles between modes with no issue.4) If you have an audio device plugged into the OXA NFC before you turn it on (i.e. - auxiliary cables and/or the micro-SD card reader), when you do use it, the speaker will detect that device and enter the appropriate mode.5) The volume level is independent of the music device synced to the speaker. While the volume will go up if you raise it through the device, the speaker will respond. However; you can then use the command buttons on the face of the speaker and bump it up/down as desired.Cons:1) While you can change the song playing on your iPod/music player through the control buttons on the touch screen, there seems to be a bit of a lag when doing so. In the long run it is much faster to change songs using your iPod, rather than the speaker.2) The battery takes about four hours to fully charge, and then only lasts roughly 1-1 hours before you need to charge it again.3) While the speaker is of good quality in the design, dropping the OXA NFC would most likely prove disastrous, especially on a hard surface.4) While you can go into FM radio mode wirelessly, you will drain the battery VERY quickly. You must have it plugged in to get the best results.5) The OXA NFC works well as a speakerphone, but the microphone has a tendency to pick up smaller background noises.6) The display screen will always list the mode that the speaker is in, which is great, but I really wish that it would show either the current song title/artist information, or even more basic, a clock, as the default.OverallWhile I think that the sound quality and the bevy of features that are available with the OXA NFC Bluetooth Natural Wood Speaker are great, with the short battery life it is a stretch to justify the cost. Sure, you can keep it plugged in, but that rather defeats the purpose of having a Bluetooth speaker in the first place. If OXA can improve the rechargeable battery's life so that you can use the unit wirelessly for longer than an hour, then I could see paying $40 for this item. Otherwise I would hold off and/or invest in one of the smaller Bluetooth speakers that OXA offers (I have one and LOVE it).**Disclaimer: This speaker was sent to me by the manufacturer at no cost to review. While I do not feel that this influenced me in any capacity, I am legally obligated to disclose this fact so that you can come to your own conclusions about the merit of this analysis.**
summary: Great Sound, Awful Battery Life

reviewText: This OXA BT speaker is quite nice for the price and what it offers.First, you can use Bluetooth, NFC (which is BT that pairs when devices touch), wired via the 3.5mm cable (included) or using a Micro SD card. The other bonus feature, that I haven't yet seen included in other speakers of this type, is FM radio capability. This means that if you want to save your phone's battery, but still have music and don't mind the radio, the OXA speaker will work wonders for you.Another feature, a highly welcomed feature for someone who doesn't think of the things they buy as throw away items, is the inclusion of a removable and replaceable rechargeable battery. The benefits here are two fold. First, when the battery stops holding a charge, you can replace it (in theory - I'm not sure if they sell replacement batteries). The second is that you can also carry a spare battery for the instances where the 6-8 hours of play time just isn't enough. I can't personally think of any situation where I'd need more than 6 hours of music straight, but the nice thing is that it is here if I need it.In terms of sound quality, I am rarely impressed by the sound coming from a Bluetooth speaker. This speaker is not really any different in that regard, despite including two actual speakers. The mids and highs are nice, but the low end bass isn't quite what you'd expect from something this size. That being said, compared to similar BT speakers, the sound is no WORSE, and that's good. With the user replaceable battery, the ability to use micro SD and wired connections for playback, along with a decent display, this speaker deserves 5 stars for offering something above and beyond what has become status quo for these speakers.The design is pretty and a little soft spoken. It isn't ugly, it isn't drop dead gorgeous - it's pretty enough to not be distracting.The only complaint you might have, and you should be aware before buying, is that this speaker isn't really a travel speaker. This would be a great device to have in the kitchen or living room when you just want music but don't want to run cords or have a large receiver. Heck, it can even serve it's purpose when you have all that equipment and just don't want to fire it all up.Overall, this is a nicely designed, good sounding BT speaker with some nice added features.Recommended.I received a free sample for review purposes from the manufacturer.
summary: Fantastic for the price

reviewText: This speaker is quite unique; not only does it allow you to play music through bluetooth or a 3.5 mm audio jack, but it also has a build in FM Radio. First things first, this device is large. I wouldn't recommend this as a portable speaker, but one for a desk or night stand. The device comes in a plethora of colors, and each one looks fairly nice. The speaker also has built in NFC for devices such as the GS5 or Htc one M8. Finally, the product has a built in touch screen which works fairly well, and enables the user to operate the device pretty easily. As for speaker quality, this speaker is REALLY Loud, and for the most part, sounds pretty nice. Currently, I have this speaker connected to my computer via the included 3.5 mm audio cable included in the box. Simply put, if you are looking for a high quality speaker that you won't be taking on the go, this is the one for you.
summary: Interesting Concept

reviewText: The innovative people at OXA asked me to evaluate their NFC Bluetooth Stereo Speaker, and there are a few things that make this product a little different, including a built-in FM radio.  The first time the unit is in radio mode, it does a search to locate the FM stations available in the area, and stores them in memory.The controls are rather unique, as the cube shaped unit has a display panel with red LED's that displays the mode, or radio station frequency.  Six touch sensitive "buttons" are used to adjust the volume, select the mode, tune in radio stations, and perform other functions.  The buttons are rather small, but seem to work fairly well.The OXA has two 2" diameter speakers, which deliver pretty good sound quality, although there can be some distortion at higher volumes.  With such small speakers, this unit isn't intended for a huge space, but they do a nice job in a smaller area.  The speakers face in opposite directions and direct the sound out the sides of the unit, rather than straight ahead, so you do get a less direct sound.  Although there are no provisions for adjusting the tone, the speakers handle most kinds of music well, and really sound solid when listening to podcasts.Bluetooth pairing is simple, and the unit is also capable of playing audio from other sources, via an auxiliary in jack, a USB port, and a slot for a micro-USB card.  The line in function worked fine, as does the USB port.  When playing MP3's stored on a flash drive, while you can fast forward through a track, there does not appear to be a way to skip tracks, or navigate the files on the media.  This is not at all convenient.  I attempted to play files stored on a micro-SD card, but the device did not recognize the card.Accessories include a twin male audio cord, and a USB cord with a mini-USB connector for charging the unit.  There is a battery symbol on the display panel, but mine many not be working properly, as no matter how long it is plugged in, it never shows up as being fully charged.  The stated battery life of about two hours, isn't that impressive.The "manual" consists of information printed on a scrap of paper, slightly larger than a 3x5 card.  There's not a lot of detailed information, and the grammar isn't the greatest.  This is typical for the OXA products I have seen, and I recommend that the company make an effort to make some improvements in this department.  While you can figure out most of what you need to know about these speakers by trial and error, more detailed information and instructions, would have been helpful.The OXA NFC is nicely made, and the "wood design" looks quite attractive.  The unit has a small footprint, audio quality is rich and warm, the controls that are kind of fun to play with, and the FM radio is a nice bonus.  OXA seems to have a progressive approach, and while I really do appreciate some of the innovative features, there are some deficiencies with this unit, that keep it from earning 5 stars.  If you're looking for a small Bluetooth speaker, this one is worth a look, as besides the features I have outlined, the price is competitive, it comes in several colors, and it is backed by a one year guarantee.
summary: a bluetooth speaker, with an FM radio...

reviewText: This review is from: Maxboost Electron Plus 15000mAh Dual-port 3A Premium USB Portable External Battery Pack Power Bank Backup Charger for iPhone 5S 5C 5 4S 4 ; iPad Air 5 4 Retina 3 2 1, The New iPad ; iPad mini retina 1 2; Google Nexus 5 4 7 FHD 2 ; Samsung Galaxy Note 3 , Samsung Galaxy S5 S4 S3, Galaxy S4 Mini S3 Mini; HTC One M7 Mini M4 ; LG Optimus G2 ; Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 7.0 8.0 10.1 ; Nokia Lumia 1520 1020 920 900 (Wireless Phone Accessory)I agree with another reviewer that discovered how helpful this battery can be when one is caught in a horrible traffic jam. It can fully power an iPhone 5 nearly ten and a half times. It can fully power an iPad 4 one and a third times.The way I use this 9.8 ounce battery, I try to keep it in my car's glove box along with a much smaller battery that I can carry in a pocket. The dimensions are 5.4 x 2.8 x .8. It's a way to have access to more charging power than I'm likely to need and even for charging two devices at once. If I get stuck and need a little flashlight, I can use the one in this battery. The digital display window lets me know the current charge percent, and I can always charge it up when driving.The battery is certified by Samsung for 500+ recharges to a period of 12 months. I received a sample.
summary: Large and powerful

reviewText: Test Devices:HTC OneHTC EVO 4G LTESamsung Galaxy S2Samsung Galaxy S3Samsung Galaxy S4Samsing Galaxy NexusiPad MiniiPad AirGoogle Nexus 7 (original)Tegra NoteNVIDIA SHIELD*Disclosure: I was contacted and given a sample of this product by Maxboost*This will be the second such item from Maxboost that I've had the chance to check out, the other being the lower capacityMaxboost Pulse 10000mAhWhile they are very similar, there are some good changes in this version.  Like the previous model, the Electron Pulse housing is gloss plastic, which retains fingerprints like they're going out of style. It too also tends to get scratches and scuffs easily, making the need for using the included pouch. The little LCD remains a prominent feature, is a nice touch, giving more info than I've seen any other product of this type. It displays not only the % of charge remaining, but also if it's charging, if it's charging something else, and which output port is being used when charging something else. When the unit first comes to life, the LCD's blue backlight comes on briefly. This backlight can be triggered again by tapping the unit's one and only button. The LCD's viewing angle, which I complained about in the Pulse, has also been fixed.  I can read it clearly when looking directly at it.  One complaint though is that when the unit is in a cool or cold environment, artifacts appear on the LCD until it warms up a bit.  ~20-30 seconds when the ambient temperature is around 60F.  The LCD readout being in reverse of the logo on the smaller model was fixed in this one. The automatic detection of when something is plugged into it still charms meBesides the list of devices above, I also tried it out with several different kinds of headsets, speakers, fans, lights, and more. Anything that charged or ran off USB power pretty much. Everything worked as it should, no complaints.
summary: A step up

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of stand-alone charging blocks. I know it's overkill, but I always keep at least two external backup batteries in my briefcase at all times. These things have saved me from being powerless so many times. I've tried many different brands and capacities--all different types and sizes, so I have a lot of experience with these devices.Most of these chargers are a commodity. They hold a charge. They have a USB port or two. They do their thing. *Yawn*. That's all there is to it.This one is interesting though. At first it looked a little gimmicky and I thought I wasn't going to be impressed, but I WAS WRONG!The huge difference between this power block and it's competitors is the digital display. Some of the other chargers I own have no power indicator and some have blinking dots. This one actually has a digital display that gives you all sorts of info.
